array.string: New York Islanders' Mike Bossy plays his final game.
NASCAR driver Bill Elliott sets all time fastest lap at Talladega Motor Speedway: 211 mph (340 km/h).
Lou Lamoriello is named New Jersey Devils' president.
Pope John Paul II beatifies Edith Stein, a Jewish-born nun.
113th Kentucky Derby: Chris McCarron aboard Alysheba wins in 2:03.4.
Dicky Fuller, cricket player (one Test for West Indies 1935, one run, 0-12), dies.
Cindy Hill wins LPGA S&H Golf Classic.
Paul Butterfield, American singer/harmonica player, dies of drug abuse at age 44 (born 1942).
Dick Hillenius, Dutch biologist/writer, dies at age 59.
France performs nuclear test at Muruora Island.
Disneyland debuts "Disney Dollars". Mickey Mouse and Sleeping Beauty's Castle are on the $1 bill, Goofy and the Mark Twain Riverboat are on the $5 bill.
The Assemblies of God defrocks PTL's Jim Bakker.
Iran-Contra affair: Start of Congressional televised hearings.
William J Casey, director of US Central Intelligence Agency (1981-87), dies at age 73 (born 1913).
USSR performs nuclear test at Eastern Kazakhstan/Semipalitinsk.
Mario Andretti sets the one-lap speed record at Indianapolis 500 at 218.204 MPH.
Niroslav Milhailovic begins 54 hours of telling jokes.
Japanese Finance Ministry announces sale of 103 metric tons of gold.
U.S. Senator Gary Hart drops out of the running for the Democratic presidential nomination, amid allegations of an extramarital affair with Donna Rice.
The SAS ambushes and kills the Loughgall Martyrs.
Obafemi Awolowo, President of Nigeria (1979-83), dies at age 78.
A Soviet-made Il-62 airliner, operated by LOT Polish Airlines crashes near the Kabacki forest in Poland, killing all 183 people on board.
At Comiskey Park, Baltimore Orioles' Eddie Murray becomes the first Major League Baseball player to hit home runs from both sides of the plate in consecutive games.
A Polish LOT Ilyushin I? 62M "Tadeusz Ko?ciuszko" (SP-LBG). crashes after takeoff in Warsaw, Poland, killing 183 people.
Jody Rosentha wins LPGA United Virginia Bank Golf Classic.
Corazon Aquino is elected President in the Philippines.
First heart-lung transplant takes place (Baltimore, Maryland, USA).
Klaus Barbie goes on trial in Lyon, France, for war crimes committed during World War II.
The first heart-lung transplant takes place (Baltimore, Maryland). The surgery is performed by Dr. Bruce Reitz, of Stanford University School of Medicine
Klaus Barbie goes on trial in Lyon for war crimes committed during World War II.
Victor Feldman, pianist/drummer, dies at age 53.
Colt revolver (Peacemaker) of 1873 sells for US$242,000.
Lieutenant Colonel Sitiveni Rabuka executes a bloodless coup in Fiji.
The Soviet Union launches the Polyus prototype orbital weapons platform, which fails to reach orbit.
John Baur, museum director, dies at age 78.
Record archery score for a pair over 24 hours, is set.
113th Preakness: Chris McCarron aboard Alysheba wins in 1:55.8.
Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish economist (Nobel Prize 1974), dies at age 88 (born 1898).
Ayako Okamoto wins LPGA Chrysler-Plymouth Golf Classic.
An Iraqi fighter jet fires two missiles into the U.S. warship USS Stark (FFG-31), killing 37 and injuring 21 of her crew.
Wilbur J Cohen, first employee of US Social Security System, dies at age 73.
G˜tenborg wins 16th UEFA Cup at Dundee.
Tennessee court rules that WWF can not promote Harley Race as the King of Wrestling in Tennessee, upholding Jerry Lawler's claim.
Military coup in Fiji Islands under Lieutenant Colonel Sitivani Rabuka.
Karel Albert, Flemish composer (Marieken van Nymeghen), dies at age 86.
33rd LPGA Championship won by Jane Geddes.
Al Unser wins the Indianapolis 500 race for a fourth time, the second driver to do so, after A.J. Foyt in 1977.
Cecilia Bolocco, age 22, of Chile, crowned 36th Miss Universe.
Great offensive against Tamil-rebellion in Jaffra, Sri Lanka.
US Supreme Court rules dangerous defendants could be held without bail.
William H Webster replaces Robert M Gates as 14th director of US Central Intelligence Agency.
Postage wins 32nd Europe Cup 1 in Vienna, Austria.
New York Yankees' Phil Niekro is third pitcher to make 700th start.
FC Porto wins the European Cup, defeating Bayern München by 2-1 in Prater Stadion in Wien.
Baltimore Orioles' player Mike Young hits two homeruns in extra innings.
Bob Milacki sets Southern League pitching record 11 1/3 no hit innings.
60th US National Spelling Bee: Stephanie Petit wins spelling "staphylococci".

A 19-year-old German, Mathias Rust, flies a small private plane through Russian security without clearance and lands on Red Square in Moscow. He is immediately detained (but is released August 3, 1988).
Paul Pearman jumps 21 barrels on a skateboard in Augusta, Georgia, USA.
A robot probe finds the wreckage of the USS Monitor near Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
19-year-old West German pilot Mathias Rust evades Soviet Union air defenses and lands a private plane in Red Square in Moscow. He is immediately detained and is not released until August 3, 1988.
Alain Vincx, Belgian stuntman, dies in an accident at age 40.
Robin Ventura sets a college baseball record with hits in 57 games.
North American Philips Company unveils compact disc video.
Turk Murphy, jazz trombonist, dies at age 71.
Tony Tucker TKOs Buster Douglas in ten rounds for International Boxing Federation heavyweight boxing title.
Mike Tyson TKOs Pinklon Thomas in six rounds for World Boxing Council heavyweight boxing title.
Frank Carlson, American politician (Governor/Representative/Senator-Republican-Kansas), dies at age 94.
Stanley Cup: Edmonton Oilers beat Philadelphia Flyers, 4 games to 3.
Cindy Rarick wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Errol W Barrow, Prime Minister of Barbados (1961-76), dies at age 67.
Rashid Karami Lebanon, ten-time Prime Minister of Lebanon, dies at age 65.
AndrTs Segovia, Spanish guitarist, dies at age 94 (born 1893).
Chicago Cubs and Houston Astros tie Baltimore Orioles' and Texas Rangers' record of three grand slams in a game.
Danny Harris beats Edwin Moses, ends streak of 122 consecutive hurdle wins.
Ted Koppel hosts a "National Town Meeting on AIDS" on a special four-hour long live broadcast of Nightline.

New Zealand's Labour government legislates against nuclear weapons and nuclear powered vessels. This makes New Zealand the first and (as at June 2006) only nation to ban these things from its territory.
In Illinois, a magnitude 5.1 earthquake occurs.
Margaret Thatcher is first British Prime Minister in 160 years to win third consecutive term.
During a visit to Berlin, Germany, U.S. President Ronald Reagan challenges Soviet Premier Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall.
The Central African Republic's former Emperor Jean-BTdel Bokassa is sentenced to death for crimes he had committed during his 13-year rule.
Cold War: U.S. President Ronald Reagan publicly challenges Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall at Brandenburg Gate.
Daniel Buettner, Bret Anderson, Martin Engel, and Anne Knabe complete cycling journey of 15,266 miles from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska to Argentina.
Los Angeles Lakers win NBA title with a 106-93, victory over the Boston Celtics.
Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami, Florida opens.
New York subway gunman Bernhard Goetz acquitted on all but gun possession.
With the death of the last individual, the Dusky Seaside Sparrow becomes extinct.
Dick Howser, New York Yankees and Kansas City Royals manager, dies at age 51 of brain cancer.
With the death of the last individual, the Dusky Seaside Sparrow becomes extinct.
The Supreme Court of the United States rules that a Louisiana law requiring that creation science be taught in public schools whenever evolution was taught is unconstitutional.
Geffen Records sign their first artist (Donna Summer).
Wee Willie Keeler's 44-game hitting streak ends.
Tom Seaver retires after third try with New York Mets.
Fred Astaire, American actor/dancer, dies at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles, California at age 88 (born 1899).
Pope John Paul II receives Austrian President Kurt Waldheim.
Losing 9-0 to Boston Red Sox, New York Yankees score 11 in third and win 12-11 in ten innings.
US Supreme Court Justice Powell retires.
Don Baylor sets career hit-by-pitch mark at 244 (Pitcher Rick Rhoden).
An accidental explosion at Hohenfels Training Area in West Germany kills three U.S. troopers.
E F Helin discovers asteroid #3680 Sasha.

In Canada, the Royal Canadian Mint releases the new "Loonie" $1 coin for circulation, depicting a loon resting on a lake. The coin is smaller than the nickel $1 coin, eleven-sided, and made of bronze.
Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden set a new world record in the high jump.
WHN-AM in New York City changes call letters to WFAN, becomes first 24 hour all sports radio.
The Single European Act is passed by European countries.
U.S. President Ronald Reagan nominates former Solicitor General Robert Bork, a controversial conservative judge and legal scholar, to the U.S. Supreme Court (rejected by the Senate in October).
Excavation begins on the Channel Tunnel.
Karl Linnas, accused German, dies of heart failure in Russia.
In the Soviet Union, Vladimir Nikolayev is sentenced to death for cannibalism.
Two men become first hot-air balloon travelers to cross Atlantic.

Greater Manchester Police recover the body of 16-year-old Pauline Reade from Saddleworth Moor after her killers Ian Brady and Myra Hindley help them in their search - almost exactly 24 years since Pauline was last seen alive.
German Klaus Barbie, "Butcher of Lyon" convicted by a French court to life imprisonment for crimes against humanity.
Martina Navratilova wins 6th straight Wimbeldon, defeating Steffi Graf.
In France, former Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie (aka the "Butcher of Lyon") is convicted of crimes against humanity and is sentenced to life imprisonment.
Australian Pat Cash wins Wimbledon, upsets #1 seed Ivan Lendl.
First instance of the LTTE using suicide attacks on Sri Lankan Army. The Black Tigers are born and in the following years continue to use it to deadly effect.
First of three massacres by Sikh extremists takes place in India.
New York Yankees trailing by 7 score 7 in 7th on 7/7 and 5 in 8th; beat Minnesota Twins 12-7.
Kiwanis Clubs end men-only tradition, vote to admit women.
Sun Microsystems introduces its first SPARC-based computer system, the Sun-4/260, with 10 MIPS performance.
Thomas F Waddell, founder of Gay Olympics, dies of AIDS at age 50.
Australian Prime Minister Robert Hawke's government is re-elected for a third term.
World population reaches 5 billion people, according to the United Nations.
According to the United Nations, the world population crosses the 5,000,000,000 mark.
Philadelphia Phillies' Kent Tekulve pitches his 900th game in relief.
National League defeats American League, 2-0 in 13, in 58th All-Star Game in Oakland, California.
Taiwan ends 37 years of martial law.
Steve Miller's star is unveiled on Hollywood's Walk of Fame.
Lieutenant Colonel Oliver North concludes six days of US Congressional testimony.
Greyhound Bus company buys Trailways Bus for US$80 million.
Don Mattingly hits his fourth grand slam of the season and ties American League record.
New York Yankees' first baseman Don Mattingly becomes the first American League player to hit a home run in seven consecutive games.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above the 2,500 mark for the first time, at 2,510.04.
Ten teens die in Guadalupe River flood (Comfort, Texas).
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above the 2,500 mark for the first time at 2510.04.
Molly Yard elected new president of US National Organization for Women.
New York Yankees' Don Mattingly ties major league record (Dale Long, 1956) of home runs in eight consecutive games.
New York Yankees' Don Mattingly ties first base majors fielding record (Hal Chase, 1906) with 22 put-outs.
President Ronald Reagan signs legislation, Public Law 100-75, designating August 3 "International Special Olympics Day".
President Ronald Reagan appoints Larry Kramer, co-founder of Gay Men's Health Crisis, to a federal panel on AIDS.
Palestinian cartoonist Naji Salim al-Ali is shot in London; he dies August 28.
US begins escorting re-flagged Kuwaiti tankers in Persian Gulf.
Soyuz TM-3 launched with three cosmonauts (one Syrian).
Said Aouita of Morroco sets the 5km record (12:58.39) in Rome, Italy.
Petra Felke (East Germany) throws javelin 78.89 metres (women's record).
Said Aouita of Morocco runs world record 5,000 metres (12:58.39).
Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce, dies of internal injuries.
Sherri Martel beats Fabulous Moolah for WWF Woman's Championship Belt.
John Demjanjuk, accused German "Ivan the Terrible" testifies in Israel.
James Burnham, philosopher (Coming Defeat of Communism), dies at age 81.
Ben and Jerry's ice cream parlour and Jerry Garcia agree on a new flavor: Cherry Garcia.
British PM Margaret Thatcher and French president François Mitterrand sign the agreement to build the tunnel under the English Channel (Eurotunnel).
Four hundred Iranian pilgrims are killed in clashes with Saudi Arabian security forces in Mecca.
Docklands Light Railway, the first driverless railway in Great Britain, is formally opened by Queen Elizabeth II.

A Force 4-rated tornado devastates eastern Edmonton, Alberta. Hardest hit are an industrial park and a trailer park. 27 people are killed and hundreds injured. Hundreds more are left homeless and jobless.
Rockwell International awarded contract to build a 5th space shuttle.
A rare, class F-4 tornado rips through Edmonton, Alberta, killing 27 people and causing $330 million in damage.
Mike Tyson beats Tony Tucker to become undisputed boxing champ.
Crossbow flight record (2,005 yards 1 foot 9 inches) set by Harry Drake in Nevada.
Don Brown sets flight record for handbow (1,336 yards 1 foot 3 inches).
Michael Andretti runs fastest Indy car race in history (171.49 MPH).
Kevin Seitzer (Kansas City Royals), gets six hits in one baseball game.
Cincinnati Reds' Eric Davis becomes 7th and earliest 30 home run 30 steal man.
Chicago Bears beat Dallas Cowboys 17-6 in London, England (NFL expo).
The US Federal Communications Commission votes 4-0 to rescind the Fairness Doctrine, which had required radio and television stations to "fairly" present controversial issues.
The Federal Communications Commission rescinds the Fairness Doctrine which had required radio and television stations to "fairly" present controversial issues.
Five Central American presidents sign peace accord in Guatemala.
Bill Mazeroski's uniform jersey #9 is officially retired from active service by the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Milwaukee Brewers' Rob Deer struck-out five times in a game.
In Northern Chile, a magnitude 6.9 earthquake occurs. Five people killed, 112 injured and more than 1,000 houses destroyed.
Lynne Cox becomes first to swim from US to Russia across Bering Strait.
Nine people die and 17 are injured when 19-year-old Julian Knight goes on a shooting rampage in Melbourne, Australia.
Los Angeles Rams beat Dallas Cowboys 28-27 in London, England (NFL expo).
9 People are shot dead and 17 more injured as 19-year old Julian Knight opens fire at random in the Hoddle Street Massacre in Clifton Hill
Clara Peller, actress (Where's the Beef), dies at age 86.
Economist Alan Greenspan takes office as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Alan Greenspan becomes Chairman of the United States Federal Reserve.
Charles Cole climbs 870-foot Tyrolean Traverse from top of Elephant Rock.
The British Royal Mint begins to issue the Britannia 1-ounce 0.9167 fine gold bullion coin.
U.S. President Ronald Reagan assumes responsibility for his role in the Iran-Contra scandal.
US beats Cuba in the Pan-Am baseball.
New York Mets beat Chicago Cubs, 23-9.
Northwest Airlines Flight 255 (a McDonnell Douglas MD-82) crashes on takeoff from Detroit Metropolitan Airport in Romulus, Michigan, killing 155 people on-board.
Astrological Harmonic Convergence-Dawn of New Age.
A McDonnell Douglas MD-82 carrying Northwest Airlines flight 255 crashes on takeoff from Detroit Metropolitan Airport killing 155 people onboard, with the sole survivor four-year old Cecelia Cichan).

Rudolf Hess is found dead in his cell in Spandau Prison in Berlin, Germany, where he served 46 years. Hess, age 93, is believed to have committed suicide by hanging himself with an electrical flex. He was the last remaining prisoner at the complex. Hess served the Nazi Party as deputy Fnhrer; he flew to England in 1941 hoping to convince Winston Churchill to join with Germany in the war.
Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 2,700 for first time (2,700.57).
Philip Rush of New Zealand sets record for triple crossing English Channel. His time, 28:21, is ten hours faster than the first man to do it.
ABC News Chief Middle East Correspondent Charles Glass escapes his Hizballah kidnappers in Beirut, Lebanon, after sixty-two days in captivity.
In Hungerford, Berkshire, England, 27-year-old Michael Ryan kills 16 with an assault rifle before committing suicide.
In London, The Order of the Garter is opened to women.
Hungerford Massacre: In the United Kingdom, Michael Ryan kills sixteen people with an assault rifle and then commits suicide.
Mack Lobell sets harness racing's trotting mile (1:52).
Clayton Lonetree, first US Marine court-martialed for spying, convicted.

At the Laguna Seca Raceway in Monterey, California, the 14th Annual Monterey Historic Automobile Races are held, over three days. About 50,000 people attend. Chevrolet holds its official 75th birthday party. Many historic Corvettes are on display and 34 participate in races, including the 1957 Corvette SS, 1960 Le Mans Corvette, CERV I, CERV II, 1959 Stingray, 1970 Manta Ray, 1977 Aerovette, two 1956 Corvette SR-2s, 1969 Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corvette, 1971 ZR-2 Corvette, 1963 Z06 Corvette, 1956 Sebring Corvette, 1962 Sebring coupe, and two 1963 Grand Sports (#003 and #004). Attending the event are Zora Arkus-Duntov, Ed Cole, Dave McLellan, Dick Thompson, Phil Hill, Jim Hall, Joe Pike, John Fitch, Augie Pabst, Roger Penske, Bill Mitchell, Hap Sharp, and Bob D'Olivio.
Hard rock band Guns N' Roses release their classic debut Appetite for Destruction.
Heavy rains and floods in Bangladesh kill hundreds of victims.
President Ronald Wilson Reagan proclaims September 11, 1987 as 9-1-1 Emergency Number Day.
Lee Marvin, American actor, dies in Tucson, Arizona at age 63 (born 1924).
Ben Johnson of Canada runs 100 m in world record 9.83 seconds.
Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria sets high jump women's record (6 feet 10.25 inches).
Yves Pol of France runs complete marathon backwards (3:57:57).
Curtis Strange sets golf's earning for the year record (US$697,385).
Kevin Bass is first National League member to switch hit home runs in a game twice in one season.
West German pilot Mathias Rust, who flew a private plane to Moscow's Red Square, goes on trial in Russia.
In Moscow, the trial begins of 19-year-old pilot Mathias Rust, who flew his Cessna aircraft into Red Square in May 1987.
Saskatchewan Rough Riders' Dave Ridgway kicks a Canadian Football League record 60-yard field goal.
East German leader Erich Honecker visits West Germany.
(to September 21) The world's first conference on artificial life is held at Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Nolan Ryan strikes out his 4,500th batter.
CBS Evening News anchor Dan Rather, angry over being preempted for a tennis match, marches off the set, leaving affiliates with six minutes of an empty news desk.
Reggae musician Peter Tosh is murdered in his own home in Kingston.
Vince Coleman steals his 100th base for third straight year.
Paul Lynch of Great Britain does 32,573 push-ups in 24 hours.
Goiânia accident: A radioactive object is stolen from an abandoned hospital in Goiânia, Brazil, contaminating many people in the following weeks and leading some to die from radiation poisoning.

The Toronto Blue Jays beat the Baltimore Orioles 18-3; the Blue Jays set a major league record of ten home runs; Orioles' player Cal Ripken Jr. sets record consecutive-innings streak of 8,243, spanning 904 games.
ITV Schools was brodcast on Channel 4 for the very first time.
U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze sign a treaty to establish centers to reduce the risk of nuclear war.
The Montreal Protocol is signed to protect the ozone layer from depletion.
At a small rally in Harlem, televangelist Marion Robertson announces his candidacy for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination.
Detroit Tigers' Darrell Evans is first 40-year-old to hit 30 home runs.
Ronald Reagan announces joint destruction of nuclear war heads by USA and USSR.
Alain Prost wins record 28th Formula one auto race.
Walter Payton scores NFL record 107th rushing touchdown.
Boston Red Sox' Wade Boggs gets his 200th hit in five straight seasons.
Second regular-season National Football League players' strike begins.
Encounter at Farpoint, the first episode of TV show Star Trek: The Next Generation airs.
New York Yankees' Don Mattingly hits Major league record sixth grand slam of the year.
Henry Ford II, president of Ford Motor Company, dies in Detroit, Michigan at age 70 (born 1917).

In Southern California, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. Eight people killed, many injured, about 2,200 homeless and more than 10,400 buildings damaged. Felt strongly in much of southern California.
In Peru, a magnitude 5.4 earthquake occurs.
Michael Pruffer of France skis 135.26 MPH at Portillo, Chile.
Toronto Blues Jays lose final seven games of the season, allowing Detroit Tigers to win the American League pennant in four straight games.
First "Scrub Sunday" of NFL football with replacement players.
James Jefferson of Winnipeg Blue Bombers scores two touchdowns on interception returns without making an interception. (He scored on laterals).

The Bharati (Indian) Annexed Punjab, (East Punjab state) which is military forcibly and illegally Occupied by the Hindu centralist government, is currently held and proclaimes the Independnece of the Thecratic nation-state of the 'Sikh Republic' of Khalistan; Recognition is not admitted to the UN.
The Reverend Jesse Jackson launches his second campaign for U.S. President.
200,000 march in second National March on Washington, D.C. for Lesbian and Gay Rights.

March on Washington for Lesbian and Gay Rights attracts between 500,000 and 600,000 people to protest the Bowers v. Hardwick decision and the U.S. government's handling of the AIDS epidemic; first public display of the NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt.
Philleo Nash, US Bureau of Indian Affairs (1961-67), dies at age 77.
Minnesota Twins beat Detroit Tigers for American League pennant.
Alfred M Landon, former Kansas Governor, dies at his Topeka home at 100.
First military use of trained dolphins (US Navy in Persian Gulf).
Costa Rican President Oscar Arias wins Nobel Peace Prize.
In Midland, Texas, 1.5-year-old Jessica McClure falls 22 feet (7m) down a well.
18-month-old Jessica McClure ("Baby Jessica") falls down an abandoned well in Midland, Texas (her nationally televised rescue takes 58 hours).
NFL Players Association orders an end to the 24-day strike.
The Great Storm of 1987 hits France and England.
Dana Suesse, songwriter ("You Ought to be in Pictures"), dies at age 75.
175-kph winds cause blackout in London and much of southern England.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average for the first time falls more than 100 points.
Jessica McClure rescued 58 hours after falling 22 feet into a well shaft.
Great Storm of 1987: hurricane force winds to hit much of the South of England killing 23 people.
First World Series game in a covered stadium (Minnesota Metrodome) (World Series #84).
Billy Martin hired as manager of New York Yankees for fifth time.

Black Monday: stock markets around the world suffer an unexpected dramatic drop, with the American Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 22.6 percent (508 points), the largest one-day drop in recorded stock market history, and first financial crisis of the modern globalized era.
Canada's TSX stock market index drops a record 11.3 percent.
US warships destroy two Iranian oil platforms in the Persian Gulf.
(Black Monday) Dow Jones Industrial Average falls by 22%.
In retaliation for Iranian attacks on ships in the Persian Gulf, the U.S. Navy disables three of Iran's offshore oil platforms.
Ten die as US Air Force jet crashed into a Ramada Inn near Indianapolis, Indiana.
New York subway gunman Bernhard Goetz sentenced to six months in jail.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 10.15 percent.
Ying-Chin Ho, Taiwan government official, dies at age 88.
Former Miss America Bess Myerson is arrested on charges of bribery, conspiracy, and mail fraud, all involving an alimony-fixing scandal. She is later found not guilty.
On a vote of 58-42, the United States Senate rejects President Ronald Reagan's nomination of Robert Bork to the U.S. Supreme Court.
The U.S. Senate rejected the Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork on a 58-42 vote.
NBC technicians accept pact, end 118 day strike.
Constantin Alajalov, Russian artist, dies at age 86.
Cecil Brown, news correspondant (CBS), dies at age 80.
Minnesota Twins win their first World Series championship beating Saint Louis Cardinals, 4 games to 3 in 84th World Series.
Head of Salvadoran Human Rights Commission assassinated by death squads.
Jean HTlion, artist/author, dies at age 83.
South Korean voters overwhelmingly approve a new constitution.
AndrT Masson, French surrealist artist (Labyrinth), dies at age 91 (born 1896).
Thomas Hearns wins unprecidented fourth different weight boxing title.
Woody Herman, American bandleader/composer (Thundering Herds), dies at age 74 (born 1913).
In Japan, NEC releases the first 16-bit home entertainment system, the TurboGrafx-16, known as PC Engine.
In Japan, NEC releases the first 16-bit home entertainment system, the PC-Engine.
A pair in Coventry, England ties the world record for the longest singles tennis match at 80 hours 21 minutes.
First jockey to win nine races in one day (Chris Antley at Belmont).
New Orleans Saints shut out Atlanta Falcons 38-0.
RenT LTvesque, Canadian politician and premier of Quebec (1976-85), dies at age 65 (born 1922).
New York Jets retire Don Maynards number 13.
22,000 run in New York City Marathon (won by Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya 2:11:01).
Raphael Soyer, artist (Depression scenes in New York City), dies at age 87.
NBA announces four new franchises; Charlotte and Miami for 1988 and Minneapolis and Orlando for 1989.
Iceberg twice the size of Rhode Island sighted in Antarctic.
US Supreme Court nominee Douglas H Ginsburg admits using marijuana.

Apartheid: In South Africa, Govan Mbeki is released from custody after serving 24 years in the Robben Island prison. He had been sentenced to life for treason against the white minority South Africa government.
William C Pahlmann, interior decorator (Four Seasons, New York City), dies at age 80.
Ross R Barnett, American lawyer/politician (Governor-Democrat-Mississippi), dies at age 89.
In Tunisia, president Habib Bourguiba is overthrown and replaced by Prime Minister Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.
Eleven die as a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army explodes at Ulster Remembrance Day Service at Enniskillen.
Remembrance Day Bombing: In Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, an Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb explodes, at a ceremony honouring Britain's war dead, killing eleven people.
Judge Anthony M Kennedy nominated to the US Supreme Court.
L T Coggeshall, medical scientist (Secretary of HEW 1956-58), dies at age 86.
Heavy snow closes schools from Washington DC to Maine.
Roger Lewis, aviation executive (Lockheed, C Wright, Pan Am), dies at age 75.
28 of 82 aboard Continental Airlines DC-9 die in crash at Denver, Colorado, USA.
Continental Airlines Flight 1713, a Douglas DC-9-14 jetliner, crashes in a snowstorm at Denver, Colorado Stapleton International Airport, killing 28 occupants, while 54 survive the crash.
In the Gulf of Alaska, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs.
31 die in a fire at King's Cross, London's busiest subway station.
U.S. Senate and House panels release reports charging President Ronald Reagan with 'ultimate responsibility' for the Iran-Contra affair.
Iran-Contra scandal: The U.S. Congress issues its final report on the Iran-Contra affair.
King's Cross fire: In London, 31 people die in a fire at the city's busiest underground station at King's Cross St Pancras.
James E Folsom, American politician (Alabama-Governor, 1947-51, 1955-59) dies at age 79.
New England Patriots shutout Indianapolis Colts 24-0.

In Southern California, magnitude 6.5 and 6.7 earthquakes occur, about 12 hours apart. Felt throughout much of southern California from San Diego and Los Angeles to Las Vegas, Nevada and Tempe, Arizona. Also felt at Tijuana and Ensenada, Mexico.
Harold Washington, mayor of Chicago (Democrat, 1983-87), dies at age 65.
Category 5 Typhoon Nina smashes the Philippines with 165 mph (266 km/h) winds and devastating storm surge, causing destruction and 1,036 deaths.
Supertyphoon Nina pummels the Philippines with category 5 winds of 165 mph and a surge that swallows entire villages. at least 1,036 deaths attributed to the storm.
Choh Hao Li, bio-chemist professor (isolated growth hormones), dies at age 74.
South African Airways Boeing 747 crashes into Indian Ocean, 159 die.
South African Airways flight 295 crashes into the Indian Ocean, killing all 159 people on-board.
Tawana Brawley is allegedly raped by six white men, some of them police officers, in Wappingers Falls, New York.
New York Rangers' Bob Frosse becomes second goalie to score a goal (vs New York Islanders). It is later ruled that he should not be credited with the goal.
Korean Air Boeing 707 Flight 858 disappears over the Andaman Sea off Myanmar, on route to Seoul. All 115 crew and passengers killed.
Howard Pyle, American politician (Governor-Republican-Arizona, 1951-55), dies at age 81.
A Korean Air Boeing 707 explodes over the Thai-Burmese border, killing 155.
Arthur H Dean, lawyer/advisor to US President Franklin Roosevelt, dies at age 89.
In the Gulf of Alaska, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs.
Digging begins to link England and France under the English Channel.
Joh Bjelke-Petersen resigns as Premier of Queensland. He is replaced by Mike Ahern, the only premier never to contest an election as premier.

NASA announces the names of four companies who were awarded contracts to help build Space Station Freedom: Boeing Aerospace, General Electric's Astro-Space Division, McDonnell Douglas, and the Rocketdyne Division of Rockwell.
Donn Fulton Eisele, Colonel US Air Force/astronaut, dies of a heart attack at age 57.
NASA announces the names of four companies who were awarded contracts to help build Space Station Freedom.
Jennifer Steele, age 17, of Colorado becomes Miss Teen America.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
334 club forms as 334 brave New Jersey Devils' fans journey through 20 inches of snow to attend New Jersey Devils 7-5 victory over Calgary Flames at Meadowlands colliseum.
Sch˜nbrunn skates world record 3 km ladies (4:16.76).
David Boon's 5th Test Cricket century, 143 versus New Zealand at Brisbane.
53rd Heisman Trophy Award: Tim Brown, Notre Dame (world record).
Fat Larry James, US drummer (Fat Larry's Band-Zoom), dies at age 38.
Three satanist Missouri teenagers bludgeon comrade to death for "fun".
Christa Rothenburger skates female world record 500 metre (39.39 seconds).
Jane Crafter/Steve Jones win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.

Pacific Southwest Airline Flight 1771 crashes near Paso Robles, California, killing all 43 on board, after a disgruntled passenger shoots his ex-supervisor on the flight, then shoots both pilots and himself.
