Mario Andretti records fastest Indianapolis 500 lap (221.565 mph).
Chet Baker, American jazz trumpeter, falls to death out of a hotel window at age 59 (born 1929).
Wimbledon wins the English FA Cup after beating Liverpool 1-0 at Wembley.
First non-pitcher (Jose Oquendo) in 20 years to get a decision in a baseball game, he and Saint Louis Cardinals lose to the Atlanta Braves 7-5 in 19 innings.
Near Carrollton, Kentucky, a drunk driver going the wrong way on Interstate 71 hits a converted school bus carrying a church youth group from Radcliff, Kentucky. The resulting fire kills 27.
Willem Drees, Prime Minister of Netherlands (1948-58), dies at age 101.
Carrollton bus disaster - A drunk driver going the wrong way on a Kentucky highway hits a bus carrying a church youth group, causing the deaths of 27 people in the resulting fire.
Second American Comedy Awards: Robin Williams and Tracey Ullman.
Nancy Lopez wins LPGA Chrysler-Plymouth Golf Classic.
Soviet war in Afghanistan: After more than eight years of fighting, the Red Army begins its withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Kay Baxter, Best Bodybuilder in the World (1983-85), dies in car crash at age 42.
US Surgeon General C Everett Koop reports nicotine as addictive as heroin.
US Supreme Court rules trash may be searched without a warrant.
Louise Wood, director of Girl Scouts of USA (1961-72), dies at age 78.
A report by United States' Surgeon General C. Everett Koop states that the addictive properties of nicotine are similar to those of heroin and cocaine.
In the Oakland Athletics' 39th game of the season, pitcher Dave Stewart breaks major league record with his 12th balk en route to 16.
In Torino, Italy a building is struck by a falling meteorite.
Daws Butler, cartoon voice (Yogi Bear, Huckleberry Hound), dies at age 71 (born 1916).
Bayer Leverkusen wins 17th UEFA Cup at Leverkusen.
Carlos Lehder Rivas, of Colombia's Medell?n drug cartel, is convicted in Florida for smuggling more than three tons of cocaine into US.
Boston Red Sox retire Bobby Doerr's number 1.
Mike Schmidt hits his 535th homerun, moving into 8th place.
Apple Computer contracts with Quantum Computer Services to create AppleLink - Personal Edition.
114th Preakness: Eddie Delahoussaye aboard Risen Star wins in 1:56.2.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
Dino Conte Grandi, Italian delegate to League of Nations, dies at age 92.
Kﬂroly Gr=sz succeeds party leader Jﬂnos Kﬂdﬂr in Hungary.
Giorgio Almirante, Italian fascist (member of parliament), dies at age 73.
34th LPGA Championship won by Sherri Turner.
David Schoenbrun, CBS broadcast bureau head (Washington, Paris), dies at age 73.
Tom Burtt, cricket player (New Zealand slow left-armer in 11 Tests 1947-53), dies.
Porntip Nakhirunkanok, 19, of Thailand, crowned 37th Miss Universe.
John Moschitta sets record for fast talking: 586 words per minute.
Power outage in Boston Garden in NHL's Stanley Cup finals.
James "Hamish" Hamilton, British publisher (Salinger/Mitford), dies at age 87.
Section 28 (outlawing promotion of homosexuality in schools) is passed as law by Parliament in the United Kingdom.
Section 28 is passed as law by Parliament in the United Kingdom.
NHL Stanley Cup: Edmonton Oilers sweep Boston Bruins in four games.
US Senate ratifies a treaty eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles.
Melvin J "Cy" Oliver, US jazz composer/orchestra leader, dies at age 77.
Graeme Hick scores his 1,000th run of first-class cricket season.
Sherri Turner wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
President Zia ul-Haq fires government/disbands parliament in Pakistan.
U.S. President Ronald Reagan addresses 600 Moscow State University students, during his visit to the Soviet Union.
Horace A Hildreth (Governor-Maine, 1945-49), dies at age 85.
Longest game in Baltimore Orioles at Memorial Stadium (5:46) 14 innings, beating New York Yankees 7-6.
Clarence M Pendleton, US chairman of committee on Civil Rights (1981-88) dies.
Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom strips jockey Lester Piggott of his Order of the British Empire following his jailing for tax irregularities.
US Presidential candidate George Bush makes campaign promise to support reparations for WW II.
US Attorney General Edwin Meese orders Joseph Doherty deported to the United Kingdom.
Greatest number of participants (31,678) on a bicycle tour (London, England).
Louis L'Amour, western writer, dies at age 80 of cancer.
Giuseppe Saragat, president of Italy (1964-71), dies at age 89.
Galina Chistyakova of USSR sets long jump woman's record (24 feet 8.25 inches).
New York Yankees' Rick Rhoden becomes first pitcher to designate hit (0 for 1 with an RBI).
Wembley Stadium hosts a concert featuring stars from the fields of music, comedy and film, in celebration of the 70th birthday of imprisoned African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela.
The name of the General Public License (GPL) is mentioned for the first time.
Nelson Mandela 70th Birthday Tribute Wembley Stadium, London.
Rusty Wallace wins the last Nascar Winston Cup race at the Riverside International Raceway
US Supreme Court refuses to hear Yonkers argument they aren't racist.
First launch of the European Space Program of the Ariane rocket.
Women sentenced to 90 years in first product tampering murder case.
New York City WABC-AM becomes the flagship radio station of the New Jersey Devils.
Los Angeles Lakers beats Detroit Pistons, for the NBA championship.
New York Yankees' manager Billy Martin's 5th term ends, Lou Pinella named manager.
Charlotte Hornets and Miami Heat begin their NBA expansion draft.
Cleveland Indians' pitcher Doug Jones sets record of 14 consecutive saves.
The Netherlands defeats the Soviet Union 2-0 to win Euro 88.
Mike Tyson knocks out Michael Spink in 91 seconds, in Atlantic City (US$67 million).
59 are killed and 55 are injured as a runaway train in Gare de Lyon, France plows into a packed rush-hour train.
Four workers are asphyxiated at a metal-plating plant in Auburn, Indiana (a fifth victim dies two days later).
The worst confined-space industrial accident in U.S. history occurs at a metal-plating plant in Auburn, Indiana, killing five.
The United States Supreme Court upholds the law allowing special prosecutors to investigate suspected crimes by executive branch officials.
Roman Catholic Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre consecrates four bishops at Ec?ne, Switzerland for his apostolate, along with Bishop Antonio de Castro Mayer, without a papal mandate.
Bologna, Italy: Quartetto Cetra's last concert after over forty years' musical career.
Steffi Graff beats Martina Navratilova for Wimbeldon crown.
Spink-Taisei in Tokyo sells a British 1847 Victoria Gothic, Plain Edge gold crown pattern graded AU (one of two known) for the equivalent of US$210,000, a record for a UK coin.
The Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge in Istanbul, Turkey is completed, providing the second connection between the continents of Europe and Asia over the Bosporus.
United States Navy warship USS Vincennes shoots down Iran Air Flight 655 over the Persian Gulf, killing all 290 people aboard.
Steffan Edberg beats Boris Becker for Wimbeldon crown.
The Piper Alpha drilling platform in the North Sea is destroyed by explosions and fires, killing 165 oil workers and two rescue mariners.
Carlos Salinas de Gortari elected president of Mexico.
The Piper Alpha drilling platform in the North Sea is destroyed by explosions and fires. 167 oil workers are killed, making it the world's worst offshore oil disaster.
The Israeli 405 Bus slaughter in which 14 bus passengers were killed as an Arab assaulted the bus driver as the bus was driving by the edge of a cliff.
Soviet Union launches Phobos 1 to probe Martian moon (unsuccessful).
Stevie Wonder announces he will run for mayor of Detroit in 1992.
Barbara Woodhouse, dog trainer, dies at age 78 of a stroke.
Joshua Logan, Broadway producer, dies at age 79 of palsy.
USSR launches Phobos II for Martian orbit.
200,000 demonstrate in Soviet Armenia for incorporation of Nagorno-Karabak.
Volkswagen closes its Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania plant after 10 years of operation (the first factory built by a non-American automaker in the U.S.).
Mike Schmidt passes Mickey Mantle with his 537th home run into 7th place.

Volkswagen's automobile plant in Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania - the first auto assembly plant operated by a non-American car manufacturer in the United States - closes after little more than a decade of operation. The plant built Volkswagen's Rabbit model in its first six years, then produced the Golf and some Jetta models until its closing.
San Antonio (Texas League) beats Jackson 1-0 in 26 innings.
Jackie Joyner-Kersee sets women's hepathlete record of 7,215 points.
Florence Griffith Joyner of USA sets the 100m woman's record (10.49s).
Highest temperature ever recorded in San Francisco, California: 103 degrees F (39 degrees C).
The Democratic National Convention in Atlanta, Georgia nominates Michael Dukakis for U.S. President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President.
ESA's Ariane-3 launches two communications satellites (one Indian).
500 US scientists pledge to boycott Pentagon germ-warfare research.
Luigi Lucioni, Italian landscape painter (opera stars), dies at age 87.
Saskatchewan Roughriders' Dave Ridgway kicks record eight field goals versus Edmonton Eskimos.
US and Jamaica play scoreless tie, in second round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Mike Schmidt sets National League record appearing in 2,155 games at third base.
Radio Shack announces the Tandy 1000 SL computer.
Israeli diplomats arrive in Moscow for first visit in 21 years.
Jordan cancels $1.3 billion development plan in West Bank.
Winnie Mandella's home in Soweto, South Africa destroyed by arson.
New York Yankees' Tommy John makes three errors on one play yet beats Milwaukee Brewers 16-3.
Ellin Berlin (MacKay), Mrs Irving Berlin, dies at age 86.
Last US Playboy Club (Lansing, Michigan) closes.
Judge orders NASA to release unedited tape from Challenger cockpit.
Gorbachev pushes plan electing president and parliament in March, 1989.
FDIC bails out First Republic Bank, in Dallas, Texas with $4 billion.
Cincinnati Reds' pitcher John Franco sets a record of 13 saves in one month.
Ronald J Dossenbach begins world record ride, pedaling across Canada.
Thirty-two people are killed and 1,674 injured when a bridge at the Sultan Abdul Halim Ferry terminal collapses in Butterworth, Malaysia.
Willie Stargell became 200th man inducted in Baseball's Hall of Fame.
Miami Dolphins beat San Francisco 49ers 27-21 in London.
32 people were killed and 1,674 injured when a bridge at the Sultan Abdul Halim ferry terminal collapsed in Butterworth, Malaysia.
John Cardinal Dearden, US cardinal, dies at age 80.
Rush Limbaugh was syndicated nationally as a two hour radio show
US Congress votes $20,000 to each Japanese-American interned in WW II.
Hertz car rental company will pay out US$23 million in consumer fraud case.
The Malaysian constitutional crisis culminates in the ouster of the Lord President of Malaysia, Salleh Abas.

(to August 7) A riot erupts in Tompkins Square Park (New York City) when police attempt to enforce a newly-passed curfew for the park. Bystanders, artists, residents, homeless people and political activists are caught up in the police action.
In Myanmar, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs. Five people killed, 42 injured. Felt throughout Bangladesh and northeastern India.
Police riot in New York City's Tompkins Square Park
A record five sacrifice flies are hit by the Seattle Mariners (D. Coles, A. Davis, J. Presley, J. Buhner, and R. Quinones) in a 12-7 victory over the Oakland Athletics.
Rioting in New York City's Tompkins Square Park
Chicago Cubs starts first home game under lights (rained-out).
In England, Duchess of York gives birth to 6-pound 12-ounce baby girl, Beatrice.
Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics becomes 11th player to get 30 home runs and 30 steals in a season.
Pitcher Goose Gossage registers career save number 300.
Discovery of most distant galaxy (15 * 10 ^ 12 light years away) announced.
Minnesota Twins pull second triple-play of year and beat Cleveland Indians 6-2.
Renovated New York City Central Park Zoo reopens after four years.
US Secretary of State George Shultz narrowly escapes assassination attempt in Bolivia.
South Africa declares cease-fire in Angola.
Russian troops begin pull-out of Afghanistan after nine-year war.
Thousands of protesters in Myanmar are killed during anti-government demonstrations.
General Ne Win, ruler of Burma since 1962, suddenly resigns.
Chicago Cubs beat New York Mets 6-4 in their first official night game at Wrigley Field.
Edmonton Oilers trade Wayne Gretzky to Los Angeles Kings for $15-$20 million.
Just one day after 8/8/88 New York lottery's daily number is 888.
Wayne Gretzky is traded from the Edmonton Oilers to the Los Angeles Kings in one of the most controversial transactions in hockey history.
Baseball's all-day-game era officially came to an end when the Cubs beat the Mets 6-4 in Wrigley Field's first night game.

In Solomon Islands, a magnitude 7.4 earthquake occurs. One person killed and about 100 homes washed away in 13 villages along the southwestern coast of San Cristobal where a tsunami flooded 50-100 metres inland.
Arias Arnulfo, three-time president of Panama, dies at age 86.
United Nations estimates Asia's population at three billion.
Adela Rogers Saint John, journalist (Free Soul, Honeycomb), dies at age 94.

Japanese American Internment: US President Ronald Reagan signs the Civil Liberties Act of 1988, providing $20,000 payments to Japanese-Americans who were either interned or relocated by in the United States during World War II.
Gary Carter (New York Mets) becomes 59th player to hit 300 career home runs.
Meir Kahane renounces US citizenship to stay in Israeli Parliament.
Anne Ramsey, American actress, dies of cancer at age 59 (born 1929).
Boston Red Sox set American League consecutive home victories at 23.
Richard Thornburgh becomes US Attorney General.
Otto E Passman, American politician (Representative-Democrat-Louisiana, 1947-77), dies at age 88.
US beats Jamaica 5-1, in second round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Ronald J Dossenbach sets world record for pedaling across Canada from Vancouver, British Columbia to Halifax, Nova Scotia in 13 days, 15 hours, 4 min.
Boston Red Sox win American League record 24 straight home games.
Enzo Ferrari, Italian sportscar manufacturer (Ferrari), dies at age 90 in Italy (born 1898).
Jailed South African nationalist Nelson Mandela struck with tuberculosis.
New York City first case of Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (9-year-old Bronx boy).
The Pakistani president, Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, and the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, Arnold Raphel, are killed when the president's air force plane crashes on takeoff from Bhawalpur.
Butch Reynolds of USA sets the 400m record (43.29) in Zurich, Switzerland.
Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr, American lawyer and politician (Representative-Democrat-New York, 1949-55) dies on 74th birthday (born 1914).
Pakistani President Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq and US Ambassador Arnold Raphel are killed in a plane crash.
The Republican National Convention in New Orleans, Louisiana nominates George H.W. Bush for President and James "Dan" Quayle for Vice President of the United States of America.
American FDA approves Minoxidil as a hair loss treatment.
New York Rangers sign ex-Montreal Canadiens' great Guy Lafleur.
Iran and Iraq begin a cease-fire after eight years of war.
Yordanka Donkova of Bulgaria sets 100m hurdle woman's record (12.21).

In the Nepal-India border region, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. 721 people killed, 6,553 injured and 64,470 buildings damaged in eastern Nepal. At least 277 people killed, thousands injured and extensive damage in northern Bihar, India. Felt in large parts of northern India from Delhi to the Burma border and in much of Bangladesh.
Peru becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
The Australian koala, the first platinum coin, is issued
Price Daniel, American politician (Governor/Senator-Democrat-Texas), dies at age 77.
A fire destroys part of Chiado quarter, in Lisbon's historical center in Portugal.
The historical center of Lisbon is destroyed by a fire.
Mehran Karimi Nasseri, "The terminal man", is stuck in the De Gaulle Airport in Paris, France, where he will continue to reside until August 1, 2006.
Merhan Karimi Nasseri arrives at Charles de Gaulle International Airport.

At Germany's Ramstein Air Base, three jets from the Italian air demonstration team Frecce Tricolori, collide, sending one of the aircraft crashing into the crowd of spectators. Seventy-five people are killed and three-hundred and forty-six injured in one of the worst airshow disasters in history.
At an air show in Ramstein, West Germany, three stunt fighters collide; 69 people die.
Tennis star Chris Everett weds skier Andy Mills.
Five-day power blackout of downtown Seattle, Washington, USA begins.
Leonor Sullivan, American politician (Representative-Democrat-Missouri, 1955-77), dies at age 86.
Amnesty International's Human Rights Now! tour begins in Wembley, England.
Phoenix Cardinals play first regular-season NFL game.
Canadian Football League's Earl Winfield (Hamilton Tiger-Cats) scores touchdowns on 101-yard punt return, 100-yard kickoff return, and 58-yard pass reception.
Jerry Lewis' 23rd Labor Day telethon raises record US$41,132,113.
With US$2 billion in federal aid, the Robert M. Bass Group agrees to buy the United States' largest thrift, American Savings and Loan Association.
With US$2 billion in federal aid, the Robert M. Bass Group agrees to buy the United States's largest bankrupt thrift, American Savings and Loan Association.
Crippled Soviet Soyuz TM-5 lands safely with two cosmonauts aboard.
Security and Exchange Commission accuses Drexel of violating security laws.
Guy Lafleur, Tony Esposito and Brad Park inducted in NHL Hall of Fame.
Abdul Ahad Mohmand, the first Afghan in space, returns aboard the Soviet spacecraft Soyuz TM-5 after 9 days on the Mir space station
Javier Sotomayer of Cuba high jumps world record 2.43m.
US swamps New Zealand at 27th America's Cup: New Zealand set to appeal.
George Alpert, railroad executive, dies at age 90.
Luis W Alvarez, physicist (Nobel Prize-1968), dies at age 77.
Peter Tosh, reggae singer, shot dead at age 43 in Jamaica.
Hurricane Gilbert, strongest ever (160 mph), devastates Jamaica.
First NFL regular-season game played in Phoenix, Arizona; Dallas Cowboys beat Arizona Cardinals.
Alan Bible, American politician (Senator-Democrat-Nevada, 1954-74), dies at age 78.
Lauris Norstad, NATO commander/CEO Corning Fiberglass, dies at age 71.
William Mitchell dies of a heart attack from a brain tumor.
10th time, four players hit baseball major-league record grand slams.
Hurricane Gilbert becomes strongest (26.13 barometer) hurricane in Western Hemisphere.
Hurricane Gilbert is the strongest recorded hurricane in the Western Hemisphere (based on barometric pressure).
Lillehammer, Norway upsets Anchorage, Alaska to host 1994 Winter Olympics.
Tom Browning of the Cincinnati Reds pitches a perfect game against the Los Angeles Dodgers, in his 1-0 victory. Over three starts he retires 40 consecutive batters - one shy of a major league record.
(to October 2) The Games of the XXIV Olympiad are held in Seoul, Korea.
Jeff Reardon becomes first to record 40 or more saves in both American League and National League.
Opening ceremony of the Games of the XXIV Olympiad in Seoul, South Korea.
Israel launches first satellite, for secret military reconnaissance.
Oren Lee Staley, first president of US National Farmers Organization (1955-79), dies at age 65.
Greg Louganis suffers a head injury while qualifying for the Seoul Olympics and goes on to win two gold medals.
Robert Gwathmey, artist, dies at age 85.
South Korean coaches attack the New Zealand referee after disputing his decision; the Olympic Korean boxer stages a 67 minute sit-in.
The Ocean Odyssey drilling rig suffers a blowout and fire in the North Sea.
Jose Canseco becomes Major League Baseball's first to steal 40 bases and hit 40 home runs.
Canada's Ben Johnson runs (drug-assisted) 100m in 9.79 seconds.
Jackie Joyner-Kersee of USA sets the heptathlon woman's record (7,291).
(to September 26) Large, militant protests against the World Bank and IMF meetings take place in West Berlin, Germany.

Summer Olympics: Ben Johnson beats Carl Lewis and Linford Christie in 100 metres sprinting in a record time of 9.79 seconds. (Johnson would later be disqualified in a high profile case of doping in sports.)
Billy Carter, US President Jimmy Carter's brother, dies of cancer at age 51.
Florence Griffith Joyner runs Olympic record 100m in 10.54 seconds.
Monty Python member Michael Palin sets out from London's Reform Club to start his BBC documentary Around the World in 80 Days.
New York City's Rockefeller Center is declared a national landmark.
Canada's Ben Johnson stripped of his Olympic 100m gold for failing drug test.
Polish communist party picks propaganda chief Rakowski as new Prime Minister.
Ben Johnson is stripped of his gold medal in the 100 m sprint at the Seoul Olympics for failing a drug test.
William V Shannon, US ambassador to Ireland (1977-81), dies at age 61.
US Senate votes for major federal tax code changes.
Lab tests reportedly show Shroud of Turin not Christ's burial cloth.
The National League for Democracy, led by Aung San Suu Kyi is founded.
Bronx Museum for the Arts opens in New York.
United Nations peacekeeping forces win Nobel Peace prize.
Florence Griffith Joyner of USA sets the 200m woman's record (21.34).
NASA resumes space shuttle flights, grounded after the Challenger disaster.
Los Angeles Dodgers' Orel Herschiser breaks former Dodger Don Drysdale mark by pitching 59 consecutive scoreless innings.
Joachim Prinz, author/Rabbi of Berlin (1926-37), dies at age 86.
IBM announces shipment of three millionth PS/2 personal computer.
American Louise Ritter jumps 6 feet 8 inches to win the Olympic gold medal.
Lowest batting average for National League champion (Tony Gwynn .313).
Mikhail Gorbachev is named head of the Supreme Soviet.
Lebanese kidnappers release Mithileshwar Singh (held for 30 months).
Franz Josef Strauss, German Federal Republic minister of defense (1956-62), dies at age 73.
26th Space Shuttle Mission, Discovery 7 returns to Earth after four days.
Ted Turner's Turner Network Television cable channel launches on US television.
Pillsbury stock soars $18.37 to $57.37 on takeover bid.
U.S. televangelist Jim Bakker indicted for fraud.
Israel bans Meir Kahane's Kach Party on grounds of racism.
Thousands riot in Algiers, Algeria against the National Liberation Front government.
Chilean president Augusto Pinochet is defeated in a national plebiscite which sought to renew his mandate.
Oakland Athletics sweep Boston Red Sox in four games for American League pennant.
Latvian flag raised in Riga for first time since annexation by USSR.
Fire in Seattle's Space Needle causes evacuation, $2,000 damage.
Edward Chodorov, playwright/director (Louis Pasteur), dies at age 84.
Dennis Eckersley is first to save all four games in a championship series.
Felix Wankel, developer of the Wankel rotary engine, dies in Lindau, Germany.
Women are allowed to study at Magdalene College, Cambridge, for the first time. Male students wear black armbands and the porter flies a black flag.
Waylon Flowers, puppeteer, dies at age 48.
Israel and China sign trade deal, plan diplomatic relations.
Two Victoria Police officers are gunned down, execution style, in Australia.
NeXT launches its first public debut of the NeXT Computer at Davies Symphony Hall in San Francisco, California.
two officers of the Victoria Police are gunned down executional style in the Walsh Street police shootings, Australia
Concert at Masada ends Israel's 40th-anniversary fest.
Mike Venezia, jockey, dies in 5th-race fall at Belmont Race Track, New York.
New Jersey Devils raise their first pennant (Patrick Division Playoff Champions).
Amnesty International's Global Concert Tour ends in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
With two outs in bottom of 9th, an injured Kirk Gibson hits dramatic two run home run to gives Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-4 win in first game of 85th World Series.
Orel Hirsheiser, first to pitch shutout in playoff and world series (World Series #85).
Rockin Robin beats "Sensational" Sherri Martel for WWF women's title.
Phillip Morris announces US$11 billion tender offer for Kraft.
Dallas Green replaces Lou Pinella as manager of the New York Yankees.
31 reported dead as Ugandan jetliner crashes in fog near Rome, Italy.
Israel's supreme court uphold's ban on Kahane's Kach Party as racist.
Green Day plays their first ever concert.
Car bomb kills 7 Israelis, wounds 11 near Lebanon border.
Britain bans broadcast interviews with Irish Republican Army members.
South Africa anti-apartheid leader Sisulu wins $100,000 Human Rights prize.
Three Americans win Nobel Prize in physics; three West Germans win chemistry Nobel Prize.
US Senate passes bill curbing ads during children's TV shows.
Reggie Rogers, Detroit Lions' number one pick, kills three by driving intoxicated.
Britain ends suspects right to remain silent in crackdown on Irish Republican Army.
Gastineau sacks New York Jets, retires from football "for personal reasons".
Los Angeles first to have both NBA and baseball champions as Los Angeles Dodgers beat Oakland Athletics, four games to one in 85th World Series.
Man armed with explosives blows self up in 125 Steet subway station (New York City).
Boston Celtics beat Yugoslavia 113-85 in Madrid, Spain.
Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos indicted on racketeering charges.
Boston Celtics play Spain in Madrid.
Typhoon Ruby sinks Philippine ferry; hundreds drown.
New York Islanders' and NHL high scorer, Mike Bossy retires.
The Callaway Sledgehammer Corvette reaches a top speed of 254.76 MPH at the Transportation Research Center in Ohio. making it the fastest street car.
S.B. Fuller, founder of Fuller products, dies at age 83.
48 hours after announcing it was abandoning RU-486, French manufacturer Roussel Uclaf states that it would resume distribution of the abortion drug, bowing to pressure from the government of France.
Microsoft cofounder Paul Allen gives US$10 million to University of Washington library.
French manufacturer Roussel Uclaf states that it will resume distribution of the abortion drug RU-486.
2,000 US anti-abortion protesters arrested for blocking clinics.
China announces a herbal male contraceptive.

Pakistan's General Rahimuddin Khan resigns from his post as the governor of Sindh, following attempts by the President of Pakistan, Ghulam Ishaq Khan, to limit the vast powers General Rahimuddin had accumulated.
In Japan, the Sega Megadrive is released for the first time.
Expo '88 in Brisbane, Australia, draws to a close after a six month spectacular.

Ayrton Senna clinches his first Formula One World Championship with a phenomenal drive in the Japanese Grand Prix, recovering from 16th place on the first lap to win the race and beat rival Alain Prost into second place.
New York Jets finally beat Pittsburgh Steelers for first time.
Jim Elliott (US) completes 24-hour paced outdoor race for 548.9 miles.
Two gambling clubs and one player share US$61.38 million California lotto jackpot.
Philip Morris buys Kraft Foods for US$13.1 billion.
Philip Morris buys Kraft Foods for US$13.1 billion.
First Monday Night NFL game in Indianapolis, Indianapolis Colts beat Denver Broncos 55-23.
John Houseman, Romanian-born actor and producer, dies of spinal cancer at age 86 (born 1902).
Journalists demand greater press freedom in Yugoslavia.
Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand jointly receive the Charlemagne Prize (Karlspreis) of the city of Aachen for their efforts on behalf of European unity.
Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud party wins election in Israel.
Walt Weiss wins American League rookie of the year (third straight for Oakland Athletics).
Robert Tappan Morris Jr. unleashes a "worm" program on the ARPAnet computer network (Internet). Over two days, it crashes 10-20 percent of all connected computers.
The Morris worm, the first internet-distributed computer worm to gain significant mainstream media attention, was launched from MIT.
Soviet Union agrees to allow teaching of Hebrew.
Pakistan claims it downed Afghan warplane.
Talk-show host Geraldo Rivera's nose is broken as Roy Innis brawls with skinheads at TV taping.
(to November 5) Thousands of South Korean students demonstrate against former president Chun Doo Hwan.
US President Ronald Reagan signs credit-card disclosure-bill.
Sri Lankan Tamil mercenaries try to overthrow the Maldivian government. At President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom's request, the Indian military suppresses the coup attempt within 24 hours.
Japan beats Major League Baseball All-Stars 2-1 in Tokyo (Game 1 of 7).
Cornell confirms grad student (Robert Tappan Morris, Jr) source of worst computer sabotage.
Japan and Major League Baseball All-Stars play to a 6-6 draw (Game 2 of 7).
Steve Jones wins New York men's marathon; Grete Waitz 9th women's title.

In the Burma-China Border Region, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs. 730 people killed, 3,900 injured, 267,000 homeless, 29 reservoirs severely damaged and 67 percent of the public buildings destroyed in the Lancang-Menglian area, China.
Beatle Ringo Starr checks into an alcohol rehabilitation centre.
Major League Baseball All-Stars beat Japan 16-8 (Game 3 of 7).
Sugar Ray Leonard knocks out Donnie LaLonde.
George Bush (Republican) beats Mike Dukakis (Democrat) for American Presidency.
U.S. presidential election, 1988: George H. W. Bush is elected over Michael Dukakis.
John Mitchell, former American Attorney General and convicted Watergate criminal, dies of heart attack in Washington (born 1913).
Major League Baseball All-Star team beats Japan 8-2 in Nishinomya, (Game 4 of 7).
Orel Hershiser wins National League Cy Young award unanimously.
Major League Baseball All-Star team beats Japan 3-1 in Tokyo (Game 5 of 7).

In Sacramento, California, police find a body buried in the lawn of 60-year-old boardinghouse landlady Dorothea Puente (seven bodies are eventually found and Puente is convicted of three murders and sentenced to life in prison).
Japan beats Major League Baseball All-Star team 5-4 in Tokyo (Game 6 of 7).
91-metre radio telescope dish at Green Bank, West Virginia collapses.
An independent State of Palestine is proclaimed at the Palestinian National Council meeting in Algiers, by a vote of 253 to 46.
Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: An independent State of Palestine is proclaimed by the Palestinian National Council.
In the Soviet Union, the unmanned Shuttle Buran is launched on her first and last space flight.
In the first open election in eleven years, voters in Pakistan choose populist candidate Benazir Bhutto to be Prime Minister.
The Supreme Soviet of the Estonian SSR declares that Estonia is "sovereign" but stops short of declaring independence.
Robin Givens sues Mike Tyson for US$125 million for libel.
The Supreme Soviet of the Estonian SSR declares that the Estonia was "sovereign" but stopped short of declaring independence.
In the first open election in more than a decade, voters in Pakistan choose populist candidate Benazir Bhutto to be Prime Minister.
Sheilah Graham, gossip columnist, dies of heart failure at age 84.
U.S. President Ronald Reagan signs a bill providing the death penalty for drug traffickers.
War on Drugs: US President Ronald Reagan signs a bill into law providing the death penalty for murderous drug traffickers.
Christine Onassis, American shipping heiress, dies of heart failure at age 37 (born 1950).
Ted Turner officially buys Jim Crockett Promotions, known as NWA Crockett, and turns it into World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Brian Mulroney and the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada win a second majority government.
In Palmdale, California, the first prototype B-2 Spirit stealth bomber is revealed.
In Palmdale, California, the first prototype B-2 Spirit stealth bomber is revealed.
Former Korean president Chun Doo Hwan publicly apologizes for corruption during his presidency, announcing he will go into exile.
New York Yankees sign free agent second-baseman Steve Sax to three-year contract.
In South Africa President Botha reprieves the Sharpeville Six.
Wayne Gretzky scores his 600th NHL goal.
In southern Quebec, Canada, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. Felt to the east coast, and as far south as Washington, D.C.
Convention on exploitation of Antarctic mineral resources signed.
Pioneer 6's closest approach to Earth since 1965 launch (1.87 million km).
Alexander Volkov, Sergei Krikalev, and Jean-Loup Chretien launch.
John Carradine, American actor, dies at age 82 of kidney failure (born 1906).
Rich Gedman becomes the highest paid catcher in the American League when he signs a one-year contract with the Boston Red Sox for US$1.2 million.
Six Kansas City firefighters are killed in an explosion at a construction site.
United Nations General Assembly (151-2) censures US for refusing Palestinian Liberation Organization's Arafat visa.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. buys RJR Nabisco for US$25.07 billion in the biggest leveraged buyout deal of all time.
Cyclone lashes Bangladesh, Eastern India; 317 killed.
Soviets stop jamming Radio Liberty; first time in 38 years.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. buys RJR Nabisco for $25.07 billion.
New York Islanders greatest shutout loss (8-0) versus Saint Louis Blues.
NBC bids record US$401 million to capture rights to 1992 Barcelona Olympics.
Benazir Bhutto named first female Prime Minister of a Muslim country (Pakistan).
596 dead after cyclone hits Bangladesh, half a million homeless.
Chinese minister of Foreign affairs Qian Qichen visits Moscow, Russia.
United Nations votes 151-2 (Israel and US against, Britain abstains) to move Palestinian Liberation Organization debate to Geneva.
Five gunmen who hijacked Soviet Aeroflot jet surrender in Israel.
A cyclone in Bangladesh leaves 5 million homeless and thousands dead.
Benazir Bhutto is sworn in as Prime Minister of Pakistan.
Benazir Bhutto is sworn in as Prime Minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman to head the government of an Islam-dominated state.
New York Lotto pays US$45 million to twelve winners (numbers are 1-8-13-18-28-48).
54th Heisman Trophy Award: Barry Sanders, Oklahoma State (RB).
Amy Benz/John Huston win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
USSR performs nuclear test at Novaya Zemlya.
Baltimore Orioles trade veteran first baseman Eddie Murray to Los Angeles Dodgers.
North Carolina federal grand jury indicts PTL founder Jim Bakker on fraud and conspiracy.
Shuttle Atlantis (STS-27) launches world's first nuclear-war-fighting satellite.
Milwaukee Bucks win their 1,000th NBA game (second fastest).
Nelson Mandela is transferred to Victor Vester Prison, Capetown, South Africa.
Roy Orbison, American rock singer ("Pretty Woman", "Only the Lonely"), dies of a massive heart attack at age 52 (born 1936).
Agnes Neil Williams purchases Baltimore Orioles for $70 million; Eli Jacobs becomes CEO.
In southern Iran, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs.
Yasser Arafat meets prominent American Jews in Stockholm, Sweden.
Bill Harris, US guitarist (Clovers - "Love Potion No 9"), dies at age 63.
Merv Hughes takes 13 wickets versus West Indies at the WACA but Australia lose.
Carlos AndrTs PTrez re-elected President of Venezuela.
Texas Rangers sign free-agent pitcher Nolan Ryan to a one-year contract.
Estonian becomes the official language of Estonia.
Peter Langan, Irish restaurateur (Langans London), dies in fire.
New York Islanders fire Terry Simpson; Al Arbour new coach.
Andrei P Ershov, Russian computer pioneer, dies.
In Armenia, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. At least 25,000 people killed, 19,000 injured and 500,000 homeless. Damage totals US$16.2 billion.
Gorbachev announces ten percent unilateral Soviet troop reductions at United Nations.
Mikhail Gorbachev cheered by Wall Street crowds upon arrival in New York City.
Spitak Earthquake: In Armenia an earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale kills nearly 25,000, injures 15,000 and leaves 400,000 homeless.
Yasser Arafat recognizes the right of Israel to exist.
New York Knicks set NBA record of eleven 3-pointers and sink Milwaukee Bucks, 113-109.
Herbert "Tubo" Rhoad, US singer (Persuasions - "Good news"), dies at age 44.
The last Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliant roll off the assembly line in a Chrysler factory.
New York Yankees sign 12-year television contract with Madison Square Garden for US$500 million.
Washington Capitals' first NHL scoreless tie, versus Montreal Canadiens.
New York City Subway system adds new stations (the Z line).
Palestinian Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat accepts Israel's right to exist.
In London, England, three trains collide at the Clapham Junction killing 35 and injuring 132.
Clapham Junction rail crash killed 35 and injured 100's after two collisions of three commuter trains. One of the worst train crashes in Britain.
Palestinian Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat addresses United Nations in Geneva, Switzerland.
Three men end 29-hour all-466-station subway ride in New York City, New York.
NBA's Miami Heat wins first game ever, 89-88 (Los Angeles Clippers), after 17 losses.
US agrees to talk to Palestine Liberation Organization (first time in 13 years).
Spanish general strike to protest austerity measures.
CBS' US$1.1 billion bid wins exclusive 1990-94 Major League Baseball rights.
Political cult leader Lyndon LaRouche convicted of tax, mail fraud.
H "Stork" Hendry, cricket player (11 Tests for Australia 1921-29), dies.
USSR performs nuclear test at Eastern Kazakhstan/Semipalitinsk.
77th Davis Cup: Germany beats Sweden in Gothenburg (4-1).
Bryan Murray becomes the 17th NHL coach to win 300 games (Washington Capitals).
New York Islanders break 12-game losing streak, beat New Jersey Devils 5-2.
Seattle Seahawks win their first ever division title with 9-7 record.
5th meeting of San Francisco Giants-New York Jets, Jets win and eliminate Giants from playoffs.
NASA unveils plans for lunar colony and manned missions to Mars.
Oklahoma's College football team gets three year probation.
Unexploded WWII bomb found in Frankfurt, Germany-5,000 evacuated.
Lawn darts are banned from sale in the United States by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
NBC signs lease to stay in New York City for 33 more years.
The United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna, Austria.
Animal rights terrorists fire-bomb Harrod's department store, London, England.
Max Robinson, network (ABC) TV anchor, dies of AIDS at age 49.
Premier Ranasinghe Premadasa elected President of Sri Lanka.
The United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna.
Vladimir Titov, Anatoly Levchenko, and Musa Manarov return to Earth (after a year) with Chretien.

Pan Am Flight 103 from London to New York explodes in midair over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing all 243 passengers and 16 crew members aboard, as well as 11 Lockerbie residents on the ground. A bomb hidden inside an audio cassette player detonated in the cargo area when the plane was at an altitude of 31,000 feet.
Drexel agrees guilt to security felonies, pays a US$650 million fine.
A bomb explodes on board Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Dumfries and Galloway, killing 270.
Brazilian union and environmental activist Chico Mendes is assassinated.
Tug hits oil barge, spreads 231,000 gallons on 300 miles of Western Australia and British Columbia coast.
South Africa signs accord granting independence to South-West Africa.
Two robbers wearing police uniforms rob armored truck of US$3 million in New Jersey.
Chico Mendes, a Brazilian rubber tapper, unionist and environmental activist, is assassinated.
In Spain, the El Gordo lottery draw first prize is US$194 million, shared by 72 winners.
Anti-African student rebellion in People's Republic of China.
The Nanjing Anti-African protests in Nanjing, China begin.
Bulgaria stops jamming Radio Free Europe after more than three decades.
USSR performs nuclear test at Eastern Kazakhstan/Semipalitinsk.
A couple in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, holds 28 tickets for the Lotto 6/49 lottery draw that day. Every one wins, with between 3 and 5 winning numbers per ticket. Total win is CDN$5260.
US second Circuit Court of Appeals affirms Yonkers is guilty of racism.
Soviet Red Army hockey team edges New York Islanders, 3-2 at Nassau Coliseum.
Victorian Post Office Museum in Australia closes.
Former Soviet President Brezhnev's son-in-law sentenced to 12-years (bribery).
Canadian Senate okays free trade pact with US.
Oliver North subpoenas Ronald Reagan and George Bush as defense witnesses for upcoming trial.
Mercedes-Benz pays US$20.2 million fine, failed to meet 1986 US government fuel standard.
NHL player Mario Lemieux scores a goal in each of the five different ways possible in one game (even-strength, power-play, shorthanded, penalty shot, and empty-net)
Year of the Young Reader begins.
UCLA wins a record 7th consecutive bowl game.
Notre Dame beats West Virginia for college football championship.
Russian newspaper Izvestia gets its first commercial advertisement.
A pair of Libyan MiG-23 "Floggers" are shot down by a pair of US Navy F-14 Tomcats during an air-to-air confrontation.
US Vice President George Bush is first since Vice President Van Buren to declare himself President.
Over the Gulf of Sidra, two Libyan MiG-23 "Floggers" are engaged and shot down by two US Navy F-14 Tomcats.
Majoe League Baseball signs US$400 million with ESPN, to show 175 games in 1990.
Two French TV newsmen are arrested for trying to plant fake bombs on three airlines at JFK airport in security test.
Akihito, Emperor of Japan during World War II, dies.

In Japan, the Showa period ends with the death of Emperor Hirohito (aka Emperor Showa) after 62 years and 14 days of his reign. Akihito becomes Emperor of Japan, beginning the Heisei period the following day.
Cleveland Cavaliers block 21 New York Knicks' shots tying NBA regulation game record.
International Conference on Limitation of Chemical Weapons opens in Paris.
In England, a British Midland Boeing 737-400 plane crashes on approach to East Midlands Airport, leaving 47 dead.
Johnny Jordaan [Jan van Musscher], Dutch folk singer, dies at age 64.
Soviet Union promises to eliminate stockpiles of chemical weapons.
Kegworth air disaster kills 47 in Great Britain.
Johnny Bench and Carl Yastrzemski elected to Baseball Hall of Fame.
Cuban troops begin withdrawing from Angola.
In Australia, Assistant AFP Police Commissioner Colin Winchester gunned down in driveway of Canberra home.
Cuban troops begin withdrawing from Angola.
140 nations agree to ban chemical weapons (poison gas, etc.).
Denver Nuggets' rookie Jerome Lane misses seven free throws in a game against Milwaukee Bucks, one missed by two feet.
Kindergarten student caught with loaded handgun at Bronx school, New York.
George Bush names William Bennett to be his Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy and James Watkins as Secretary of Energy.
Ruins of Mashkan-shapir (occupied 2050-1720 BC) found in Iraq.
Jerry Parks, Oklahoma defensive back, charged with shooting a teammate.
Friday the 13th virus strikes hundreds of personal computers in Britain.
New York subway gunman Bernhard Goetz begins one-year jail sentence.
29-year-old French woman gives birth to sextuplets in Paris.
Former Belgian premier Paul Vanden Boeynants kidnapped.
Wilf Slack, cricket player (whilst bat in Gambia England player 1986), dies.
Big John Studd wins WWF's first Royal Rumble.
10th ACE Cable Awards: HBO wins 35 awards.
Betsy King wins LPGA Jamaica Golf Classic.
(to January 18) Race riots occur in Overtown, Miami, Florida.
USSR announces plan for two-year manned mission to Mars.
Police arrest writer Vaclav Havel in Prague, Czechoslovakia.
Phoenix Suns cancel game at Miami Heat, due to racial unrest in Miami, Florida.
Sterling A Brown, US poet/critic (Southern Road), dies at age 87.
Al Arbour wins his 600th NHL game as coach.
Victoria Murden and Shirley Metz are first women to reach South Pole overland (on skis).
Patrick Edward Purdy kills five children, wounds 30 and then shoots himself in Stockton, California.
Bruce Chatwin, British writer, dies at age 49.
Otis Redding, Dion, Rolling Stones, Temptations, and Stevie Wonder inducted into Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
West Indies beat Australia 2-1 to win the World Series Cup.
Astronomers discover pulsar in remnants of Supernova 1987A (LMC).
The Communist Party of Poland votes to legalize Solidarity.
President Reagan pardons George Steinbrenner for illegal funds for Nixon.
The Soviets begin to airlift supplies to Afghanistan as they pull out.
George H.W. Bush succeeds Ronald Reagan as the 41st President of the United States of America.
Wayne Holdsworth takes a wicket first ball in first-class cricket.
George H. W. Bush is inaugurated as the 41st President of the United States.
Wayne Gretzky passes Marcel Dionne to become NHL's second all time scorer.
USSR performs nuclear test at Eastern Kazakstan/Semipalatinsk.
Super Bowl XXIII: San Francisco 49ers beat Cincinnati Bengals, 20-16 in Miami; Most Valuable Player: Jerry Rice, San Francisco, Wide Receiver.
In Tajikistan, a magnitude 5.3 earthquake occurs. Two hundred seventy-four people killed, many injured, extensive damage.
Challenge to "who is a Jew" law filed in Israeli Supreme Court.
Salvador Dal?, Spanish Surrealist painter, dies in Spain at age 84 (born 1904).
NBA New Jersey Nets begin a 32+ game road losing streak.
Serial killer (100 women) Ted Bundy is executed in Florida's electric chair.
Michael Jordan scores his 10,000th NBA point in his 5th season.
AT&T reports first loss in 103 years; US$1.67 billion in 1988.
StTphane Steinier, Belgian journalist, kidnapped and murdered.
Paul Daels, Flemish chairman (IJzerbedevaart committee), dies.
Madison Square Gardens sports arena in New York announces two-year US$100 million renovation plan.
Allan Border takes 7-46 against the West Indies at the Sydney Cricket Ground.
Test debut of Mark Taylor, Australia versus West Indies, Sydney.
Boon completes 7th Test century, 149 versus West Indies at Sydney Cricket Ground.
63rd Australian Open Women's Tennis: Steffi Graf beats Helena Sukova (6-4, 6-4).
Dottie Mochrie wins Oldsmobile LPGA Golf Classic.
Cleveland Cavaliers' Chris Dudley misses five free throws during one foul attempt.
Episcopal church appoints first female bishop.
Game-winning RBI, official statistic dropped after nine years of use, New York Mets' Keith Hernandez is the all-time leader with 129.
NFL Pro Bowl: NFC beats AFC 34-3.
USSR's Phobos II enters Martian orbit.
77th Australian Open Men Tennis: Ivan Lendl beats Miloslav Mecir (6-2, 6-2, 6-2).
Dow Jones Industrial Average jumps 38.06 to hit 2256.43; recoups 508-point loss since October 1987.
16th American Music Awards: Randy Travis and George Michael win.
American Olympic medalist Bruce Kimball is sentenced to 17 years in prison for killing two teenagers in a drunk driving accident.
Last day of first class cricket for Dav Whatmore.
Five pharoah sculptures from 1470 BC found at temple of Luxor.
The American embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan closes.
Joan Kirner becomes Victoria's first female Deputy Premier, after the resignation of Robert Fordham over the VEDC (Victorian Economic Development Co-operation) Crisis.
The Western Australian towns of Kalgoorlie and Boulder amalgamate to form the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder.
Satellite television service Sky Television PLC is launched in Europe.
The last Soviet Union armored column leaves Kabul, Afghanistan, ending nine years of military occupation.
Soviet war in Afghanistan: The last Soviet Union armored column leaves Kabul, ending nine years of military occupation.
Start first Test Cricket, New Zealand versus Pakistan, washed out.
A military coup overthrows Alfredo Stroessner, dictator of Paraguay since 1954.
After a stroke, Pieter Willem Botha resigns his party's leadership and the presidency of South Africa. Frederik Willem de Klerk replaces Botha as South Africa's Nationalist Party leader.
After a stroke, P.W. Botha resigns party leadership and the presidency of South Africa.
Dean Jones scores 216 versus West Indies at the Adelaide Oval.
Kenneth "Jethro" Burns, country singer (Homer and Jethro), dies at age 69.
Kareem Abdul-Jabar becomes first NBA player to score 38,000 points.
Lech Walesa begins negotiating with the Polish government.
The Los Angeles, California, City Council bans the sale or possession of semiautomatic weapons.
40th NHL All-Star Game: Campbell beat Wales 9-5 at Edmonton, Alberta, Canada.
US Boeing 707 crashes into Santa Maria mountain, 145 die.
An Independent Air Boeing 707 crashes into Santa Maria mountain in Azores Islands off the coast of Portugal, killing 144.
Michael Manley's Socialist Party wins Jamaica parliamentary election.
Kevin Johnson (Phoenix Suns) ends NBA free throw streak of 57 games.
Minor League Football System opens organizational meeting, Saint Louis, Missouri.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
Boston Celtics' KC Jones and Cleveland Cavaliers' Lenny Wilkens elected to NBA Hall of Fame.
Dan Kelly, NHL sportscaster ("He shoots, he scores!"), dies at age 52.
To gain deregulation, WWF admits pro wrestling is an exhibition and not a sport, in a New Jersey court.
Test Cricket debut of Aaqib Javed, Pakistan versus New Zealand age 16 years 189 days.
Ron Brown is elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee becoming the first African American to lead a major American political party.
US female Figure Skating championship won by Jill Trenary.
Barbara Clementine Harris is consecrated as the first female bishop of the Episcopal Church in the USA.
US male Figure Skating championship won by Christopher Bowman.
Wayne Gretzky sets two records, his 45th hat trick and 10th 40+ goal season.
50th PGA Seniors Golf Championship: Larry Mowry.
Mauritius Balfoort, French/Flemish director, dies at age 83.
Thomas Bernhard, Dutch/Austrian writer (Heldenplatz), dies at age 58.
39th NBA All-Star Game: West beats East 143-134 at Houston, Texas.
Kidnapped Belgian Premier Vanden Boeynants is freed.
Oklahoma football player Charles Thompson is charged with selling cocaine; he is later sentenced to two years in prison.
African National Congress (ANC) opens office in Amsterdam, Netherlands.
Union Carbide agrees to pay US$470 million to the Indian government for damages it caused in the 1984 Bhopol disaster.
The first of 24 Global Positioning System satellites is placed into orbit.
The first of 24 satellites of the Global Positioning System is placed into orbit.
Union Carbide agrees to pay $470 million to the Indian government for damages it caused in the 1984 Bhopal Disaster.
Iranian leader Ruhollah Khomeini issues a fatwa encouraging Muslims to kill the author of The Satanic Verses, Salman Rushdie.
The Soviet Union officially announces that all of its troops have left Afghanistan. Fifteen thousand Soviet soldiers were killed during the ten years of Soviet occupation.
Israel attacks border strip Taba near Egypt.
Soviet Union invasion of Afghanistan: The Soviet Union officially announces that all of its troops had left Afghanistan.
Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, and North Yemen form common market.
Pan Am flight 103 crash investigators announce that the cause of the crash was a bomb hidden inside a radio-cassette player.
Roger Clemens, Boston Red Sox pitcher signs record US$7.5 million, three-year contract.
William Hayden becomes governor-General of Australia.
Orel Hershiser, Dodger pitcher signs record US$7.9 million, three-year contract.
Lefty Gomez, New York Yankees pitching great, dies at age 80.
Former baseball player/manager Leo Durocher injured in a car crash.
Six-week study of Arctic atmosphere shows no ozone "hole".
Mauritania, Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Libya form common market.
USSR performs nuclear test at Eastern Kazakhstan/Semipalitinsk.
Sherri Turner wins LPGA Orix Hawaiian Ladies Golf Open/Itoki Pro-Am.
Jaap van de Merwe, Dutch journalist/cabareter (Hadjememaar), dies.
Members of 1949 Oklahoma football team cancel an April reunion because of the deplorable conduct of Oklahoma players.
Pete Rose meets with Commissioner Ueberroth to discuss his gambling.
US bust Chinese heroin ring, capture record 820 pounds heroin ($1 billion street value).
31st Grammy Awards: "Don't Worry Be Happy", Faith, Tracy Chapman.
First Spanish commercial on US network TV (Pepsi-Cola-CBS Grammy Award).
New York Lotto pays US$26.9 million to one winner (numbers are 1-5-12-19-44-50).
United Kingdom physicist Stephen Hawking calls US Strategic Defence Initiative a "deliberate fraud".
After protracted testimony, the U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee rejects, 11-9, President Bush's nomination of John Tower for Secretary of Defense.
Harold E Ballard sells Canadian Football League team Hamilton Tiger-Cats to David Braley.
After 44 years, the Estonian flag is raised to the Pikk Hermann castle tower.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
United Airlines Flight 811, a Boeing 747 bound to New Zealand from Honolulu, Hawaii, rips open during flight, sucking nine passengers and crew out of the first class section.
United Airlines Flight 811, bound for New Zealand from Honolulu, Hawaii, rips open during flight, sucking 9 passengers out of the business-class section.
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini offers a USD $3 million bounty for the death of The Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie.
First independent blue-collar labor union in Communist Hungary forms.
Dallas Cowboys fire coach Tom Landry after a 29-year career.
Javed Miandad scores 271 versus New Zealand at Eden Park.
Mike Tyson TKOs Frank Bruno in five rounds for heavyweight boxing title.
California court throws out most of Margo Adams's US$12 million breach-of-contract suit against Boston Red Sox third baseman Wade Boggs.
New York Yankees announce that Tom Seaver is their new TV sportscaster.
Betsy King wins LPGA Women's Kemper Golf Open/Helene Curtis Pro-Am.
Konrad Lorenz, Austrian zoologist (Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1973), dies at age 85 (born 1903).
Venezuela is rocked by the Caracazo.
Gretchen Polhemus, age 23, of Texas, crowned 38th Miss USA.
Red Schoendienst and Al Barlick elected to Baseball Hall of Fame.
James D. Watkins starts his term of office as U.S. Secretary of Energy.
Louis Wade Sullivan starts his term of office as U.S. Secretary of Commerce.
Ben Johnson's coach testifies Johnson began using steroids in 1981.

The Politieke Partij Radicalen, Pacifistisch Socialistische Partij, Communistische Partij Nederland and the Evangelische Volks Partij amalgamate to form Netherlands political party the GroenLinks (GL, GreenLeft).
The Berne Convention, an international treaty on copyrights, is ratified by the United States.
A curfew is imposed in Kosovo, where protests continue over the alleged intimidation of the Serb minority.
Henk van Stipriaan, Dutch radio host, dies at age 64.
The United States becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
New York Mets' Darryl Strawberry swings at teammate Keith Hernandez.
Twelve European Community nations agree to ban the production of all chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) by 2000.
Madonna's "Like a Prayer" premieres on worldwide Pepsi commercial.
NBA's Cleveland Cavaliers win 22nd straight home game.
Twelve European Community nations agree to ban the production of all chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) by the end of the century.
Jammu Siltavuori abducts and murders two 8-year old girls in Myllypuro suburb in Helsinki, Finland.
Portugal wins the FIFA U-20 World Cup defeating Nigeria on the final by 2-0 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
Robert McFarlane gets $20,000 fine, two years probation for Iran-Contra.
Machinists strike Eastern Airlines; pilots honor picket lines.
Javier Sotomayor high jumps indoor world record (2.43 metre).
The first Australian Capital Territory elections are held.
Time, Inc. and Warner Communications announce plans for a merger, to form Time Warner.
The Purley Station rail crash in London, England, leaves five dead and 94 injured.
Actress Phoebe Cates marries actor Kevin Kline.
Six people die and 80 are injured, some of them seriously, at the Purley Station rail crash in Surrey, England.
Time, Inc. and Warner Communications announce plans for a merger forming Time-Warner.
Blaine McCallister wins Honda Golf Classic shooting 266.
Elly Verhulst runs world record 3000 metre indoor (8:03.82).
New York Yankees beat New York Mets 6-4 in exhibition game (first meeting since 1985).
Partial eclipse of the Sun (Hawaii, North West North America, Greenland).
In Geneva, Switzerland, the Geneva international auto show is held, over eleven days. Chevrolet introduces the Corvette ZR-1 and LT5 engine.
The State Council of the People's Republic of China declares martial law in Lhasa, Tibet.
Roger Kingdom runs world record 60 metre hurdles indoor (7.36 seconds).
Robert Mapplethorpe, American photographer, dies at age 42 (born 1946).
Soviet Union officially submits to jurisdiction of the World Court.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
US Senate rejects Bush's nomination of John Tower as Defense Secretary.
A strike forces financially-troubled Eastern Air Lines into bankruptcy.
In Malawi, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 9 people killed, 100 injured, about 50,000 left homeless.
Johan Fleerackers, Flemish linguist, dies at age 57.
Two cyanide-contaminated Chilean grapes found (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA).
Madagascar AREMA party wins parliamentary election.

A geomagnetic storm causes the collapse of the Hydro-Quebec power grid. Six million people are left without power for nine hours. Some areas in the northeastern U.S. and in Sweden also lose power, and auroras are seen as far south as Texas.
US Food and Drug Administration orders recall of all Chilean fruit in US.
Edward Abbey, American author and environmentalist, dies after surgery at age 62 (born 1927).
Zita, Empress of Austria/Queen of Hungary, dies at age 96.
Christian General Michel Aoun declares a 'War of Liberation' to rid Lebanon of Syrian forces and their allies.
U.S. President George H. W. Bush bans the importation of certain guns deemed assault weapons into the United States.
Stack's auctions a $1000 US Treasury note for US$100,000, a record price for paper money.
Gun control: President George H. W. Bush bans the importation of certain guns deemed assault weapons into the United States.
New York Rangers retire goalie Eddie Giacomin's number 1 uniform.
The United States Department of Veterans Affairs is established.
Dino Ciccarelli sets Washington Capitals' record of 7 points in a game.

Piet Kruiver, Dutch soccer player, dies at age 51.
In Egypt, a 4,400-year-old mummy is found in the Great Pyramid of Giza.
27th space shuttle mission, STS-29 (Discovery 8), returns to Earth.
California Quake amusement ride opens at Universal Studios.
In Egypt, a 4,400-year-old mummy is found in the Pyramid of Cheops.
Lori Garbacz wins Circle K LPGA Golf Open Tucson.
World Ice Dance Championship in Paris, France won by M Klimova and S Ponomarenko (USR).
World Men's Figure Skating Championship in Paris, France won by Kurt Browning (Canada).

Boeing V-22 Osprey VTOL (vertical take-off and landing) aircraft makes maiden flight.
World Ice Pairs Figure Skating Championship in Paris, France won by E Gordeeva and S Grinkov (USSR).
Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, announces an inquiry is being conducted into gambling allegations concerning Cincinnati Reds' manager, Pete Rose.
Richard J Kerr replaces Robert M Gates as deputy director of US Central Intelligence Agency.
First sea test of Trident 2 missile self-destructs, Cape Canaveral.
Sports Illustrated reports allegations that tie baseball player Pete Rose to baseball gambling.
Clint Malarchuk of the NHL Buffalo Sabres suffers an almost fatal injury when another player accidentally slits his throat.
Asteroid 4581 Asclepius approaches the Earth at a distance of 700,000 kilometres.

NFL commissioner Pete Rozelle announces retirement as NFL commissioner after 29 years.
Fawn Hall, Oliver North's former secretary, begins two days of testimony at North's Iran-Contra trial in Washington.
Stanley Pons and Martin Fleischmann announce that they have achieved cold fusion at room temperature at the University of Utah.
A 300m (1,000 feet) diameter Near-Earth asteroid misses the Earth by 500,000km (400,000 miles).
A 1,000-foot diameter Near-Earth asteroid misses the Earth by 400,000 miles.
Stanley Pons and Martin Fleischmann announce cold fusion at the University of Utah.
Exxon Valdez oil spill: In Alaska's Prince William Sound the Exxon Valdez spills 240,000 barrels (42,000 m³) of petroleum after running aground.
Allison Finney wins LPGA Standard Register Turquoise Golf Classic.
The first free elections for the Soviet parliament go against the Communist Party; Boris Yeltsin wins.
Delhi beats Bengal by innings and 210 to win Cricket's Ranji Trophy.

Michael Milken, junk bond king, indicted in New York for racketeering.
I M Pei's pyramidal entrance to the Louvre opens in Paris France.

Donald Trump purchases Eastern Airlines' Northeast Shuttle.
First New York Mets - New York Yankees game in New York City since 1983, New York Yankees win 4-3.
Former Yale University and National League president Bart Giamatti becomes seventh commissioner of Major League Baseball.
Henk Gortzak, Dutch Member of Parliament (CPN/PSP), dies at age 57.

In Canada, four people share a Canadian record CDN$15.5 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.

New York Yankees beat New York Mets 4-0, sweeping 1989 mayor's trophy series in two games.
8th NCAA Women's Basketball Championship: Tennessee beats Auburn 76-60.
In WrestleMania V at Trump Plaza, Hulk Hogan defeats Randy "Macho Man" Savage to become the WWF Champion.

51st NCAA Men's Basketball Championship: Michigan beats Seton Hall 80-79 in overtime.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's last NBA game in Seattle.
Orel Hershiser ends his 59 consecutive scoreless pitched inning streak.
Solidarity granted legal status in Poland.
