Soviet submarine Komsomolets sinks in the Barents Sea off the coast of Norway killing 42 sailors.
One-handed pitcher Jim Abbott's debut, but lasts only 4 2/3 innings.

South Africa: In Johannesburg, the Progressive Federal Party, Independent Party, National Democratic Movement and the force of "Ontevrede Afrikaners" or dissatisfied Afrikaners merge to form the Democratic Party.
Scott Hoch chokes on 18-inch putt and loses Masters golf tournament.
Washington DC march supporting 1973 Roe versus Wade decision (allowing abortions).
Rickey Henderson steals his 800th career base in New York Yankees' 4-3 loss to Cleveland Indians.
Patti Rizzo wins LPGA Red Robin Kyocera Inamori Golf Classic.
53rd Golf Masters Championship: Nick Faldo wins, shooting a 283.
Georgian demonstrators are massacred by Red Army soldiers in Tbilisi's central square during a peaceful rally; 20 citizens are killed, many injured.
April 9 tragedy in Tbilisi, Georgia: An anti-Soviet demonstration was quashed by the Soviet army.

Intel announces the 25 MHz i486 microprocessor. It integrates the 386 processor, 387 math coprocessor, and adds an 8 kB primary cache. It uses 1.2 million transistors, employing 1-micron technology. Initial price is US$900. Speed is 20 MIPS.
H J Heinz, Van Camp Seafood and Bumble Bee Seafood say they will not buy tuna caught in nets that also trap dolphins.
24th Academy of Country Music Awards: Hank Williams Jr, Alabama win.
First playoff goal scored by a goalee, Ron Hextall of the Philadelphia Flyers.
Philadelphia Flyers score short-handed into an empty net beating Washington Capitals 8-5.
Henk van Galen Last, Dutch journalist, dies at age 68.
Third Soul Train Music Awards: Anita Baker wins.
In Canada, four people share a CDN$14.2 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
Sugar Ray Robinson [Walker Smith Jr], world welterweight champion (1946-51)/5-time middleweight champion, dies of Alzheimers at age 67.
Abbie Hoffman, yippie peace activist of the 1960s, dies at age 52.
Lance Pierre, cricket player (Test West Indies versus England 1948, DNB, 7 overs 0-28), dies.
In the Iran-Contra trial, Oliver North's case goes to the jury.
Sue Marchiano wins third World Cup female marathon (2:30:48).
At the Sheffield Soccer Stadium in England, 96 Liverpool fans are crushed to death.
Largest lottery win to date in North America (US$69 million) drawn in Illinois.
Hu Yaobang, General Secretary of Chinese Commnist Party, dies (born 1915).
Hillsborough disaster: A human stampede occurs at Hillsborough, a football stadium in Sheffield, England, resulting in the loss of 96 lives.
Upon Hu Yaobang's death, the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989 begin in the People's Republic of China.
Costa Rica beats US 1-0, in third round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Zeleka Metaferia wins third World Cup marathon (2:10:28).
Pat Bradley wins LPGA AI Star/Centinela Hospital Golf Classic.
Berendrechtsluis opens in Antwerp, biggest flood lock in world.
First Seniors Golf Tradition: Don Bies wins.
Tawfieq Yusuf Awwaad, Lebanese writer, dies.
93rd Boston Marathon won by Abebe Mekonen of Ethiopia in 2:09:06.
Polish labor union granted legal status.
18th Boston Women's Marathon won by Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway in 2:24:33.
The Hillsborough disaster claims its 95th victim when 14-year-old Lee Nichol dies in hospital from his injuries.
Kevin Elster (New York Mets), sets errorless shortstop mark at 73.
A gun turret explodes on the USS Iowa, killing 47 sailors.
NATO debates modernising short range missiles; although the U.S. and UK are in favour, West German chancellor Helmut Kohl obtains a concession deferring a decision.
Thousands of students from Beijing, Shanghai, Xian, and Nanjing begin protesting in China's Tiananmen Square, demanding greater political freedom.
Nintendo begins selling the Game Boy handheld video game system in Japan.
Tiananmen Square Protests of 1989: In Beijing, around 100,000 students gather in Tiananmen Square to commemorate the late Chinese reform leader Hu Yaobang.
Nolan Ryan strikes out his 5,000th batter (Rickey Henderson).
Huey Newton, American Black Panther leader, shot dead at age 47.
Betsy King wins LPGA USX Golf Classic.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar plays his last game with the Los Angeles Lakers.
Nolan Ryan blows a no hitter in 9th inning.
Students in Beijing, China announce class boycotts.
Tens of thousands of students strike in Beijing, China.
Massachusetts declares today "New Kids on the Block Day".
Near the coast of Guerrero, Mexico, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs.
The term of Baginda Almutawakkil Alallah Sultan Iskandar Al-Haj ibni Almarhum Sultan Ismail as the 8th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia ends.
Motorola introduces the Motorola MicroTAC Personal Cellular Telephone, the world's smallest mobile phone.
Pittsburgh Penguins' player Mario Lemieux ties NHL playoff record of four goals in first period.
James Richardson is freed from a Florida prison 21 years after being wrongfully convicted of the murder of his seven children.
Sultan Azlan Muhibbudin Shah ibni Almarhum Sultan Yusuff Izzudin Shah Ghafarullahu-lahu, Sultan of Perak, becomes the 9th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
Beijing students take over Tiananmen Square in China.
Mandatory automobile seatbelt law goes into effect in Italy.
Argentina, hit by rocketing inflation, runs out of money.
Olaff J de Landell [JB van Sparwoude], Dutch writer, dies at age 77.
Second Netherlands government of Ruud Lubbers falls.
Pope John Paul II beatifies Victoire Rasoamanarivo of Madagascar.
US beats Costa Rica 1-0, in third round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Critics Siskel and Ebert film their 500th TV movie-review show.
Kathy Postlewait wins LPGA Sara Lee Golf Classic.

The Disney-MGM Studios Theme Park at Walt Disney World opens to the public. It covers 135 acres. Total construction costs were over US$500 million. Advertising and promotions for the opening cost US$30 million. Entrance prices are US$29 for adults, and US$23 for children aged 3-9.
David Webster, South African white anti-apartheids activist, murdered.
US Supreme Court rules employees have legal burden to prove non-discriminatory reasons for not hiring or promoting.
Jockey Chris Antley ends record of 64 consecutive winning days.
The coat of arms of Greenland was adopted.
The first crack in the Iron Curtain - Hungary dismantles 150 miles of barbed wire fencing along the border with Austria.
Christine Jorgensen, first transsexual, dies at age 62.
Junior Felix of Toronto Blue Jays becomes 53rd to hit homerun on first at bat.
Iran-Contra Affair: Former White House aide Oliver North is convicted of three crimes and was acquitted of nine other charges. The convictions, however, are later overturned on appeal.
Frank Easton, cricket wicketkeeper (New South Wales 1933-39), dies.
115th Kentucky Derby: Pat Valenzuela on Sunday Silence wins in 2:05.
In the Burma-China border region, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs. At least one person killed, 91 injured and 5,300 houses destroyed.
Panamanian voters reject dictator Manuel Noriega's bid for presidency.
Juli Inkster wins LPGA Crestar Golf Classic.
Mark Merrony of Wales cycles for 30 minutes in Nepal at 21,030 feet.
New York Mets' Rick Cerone errs after 159 errorless games as catcher.
Andrew Peacock deposes John Howard as Australian federal opposition leader.
Journalists petition Chinese Government for freedom of press.
Keith Whitley, American country singer ("Don't Close Your Eyes"), dies at age 33 (born 1955).
New York Mets' Kevin Elster errs after 88 errorless games at shortstop.
FC Barcelona wins 29th Europe Cup II.
General Manuel Noriega's Panama government nullifies country's elections, which the opposition had won by a 3-1 margin.
President Bush orders nearly 2,000 troops to Panamﬂ.
Kenya announces worldwide ban on ivory to preserve its elephant herds.
France performs nuclear test at Muruora Island.
The Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly meets for the first time.
Joe Valdez Caballero, creator of hard taco shell, dies at age 81.
Last graffiti-covered New York City subway car retired.
Retired British pilot Jack Mann is kidnapped by Islamic fundamentalists.
A Southern Pacific Railroad freight train crashes on Duffy Street in San Bernardino, California.

A Southern Pacific Railroad freight train derails on Duffy Street on the very steep Cajon Pass in San Bernardino, California, killing both crew members and 2 children, ages 7 and 9, also in the accident, 11 homes were severely damaged or completely destroyed. a memorial for the accident is now found on Tehachapi Loop facing the main hill.
Trinidad and Tobago ties US 1-1, in third round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Minnesota Twins' Kirby Puckett becomes the 35th to hit four doubles in a game.
Approximately 2,000 students begin hunger strike in Tiananmen Square, China.
First time since 1948 a Major league baseball player hits six consecutive doubles (Kirby Puckett).
First Tour de Trump bicycle race run (Atlanta, Georgia, USA).
Demonstration for democratic reforms in Beijing's Tiananmen square, China.
Cindy Rarick wins LPGA Chrysler-Plymouth Golf Classic.
John Waldo, Green composer, dies at age 80.
Australia's first private tertiary institution, Bond University, opens on the Gold Coast.
Toronto Blue Jays fire manager Jimy Williams and replace him with Cito Gaston.
US Basketball League cancels its summer schedule.
Hassan Khaled, sheik of Lebanon, is murdered.
Soviet President Mikhail S Gorbachev and Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping end a 30-year rift when they formally meet in Beijing.
Longest taxicab ride ever: 14,000 miles, cost $16,000.
Napoli wins 18th UEFA Cup in Stuttgart, Germany.
In China, Zhao Ziyang meets the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square.
Able J Herzberg, Russian/Netherlands lawyer (Adolf Eichmann in Jerusalem), dies.
United States Senator Albert Gore introduces a U$1.75 billion bill in Congress to finance creation of a nationwide "data super highway" to link supercomputers.
Dow Jones average passes 2,500 mark for first time, closes at 2,501.1.
John R Hicks, English economist (Nobel Prize 1972), dies (born 1904).
The Chinese government declares martial law in Beijing.
Walter McConnel, 57, is oldest to reach 27,000-foot Mount Everest top.
115th Preakness: Pat Valenzuela aboard Sunday Silence wins in 1:53.8.
The Chinese authorities declare martial law in the face of pro-democracy demonstrations, setting the scene for the Tiananmen Square massacre.
35th Mazda LPGA Championship won by Nancy Lopez (her third LPGA championship).
In Russia, the Nordland Days in Leningrad region (Leningrad oblast) opens.
Lincoln Square in the Bronx, New York is named.
Angela Visser, 22, of Holland, crowned 38th Miss Universe.
Third American Comedy Award: Paula Poundstone wins.
Richard von WeizScker is re-elected president of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany).
New York Yankees' pitcher Lee Gutterman sets record of pitching 30-2/3 innings before giving up his first run of the season.
NHL's New York Rangers fire general manager and coach Phil Esposito.

In Nice, France, French police arrest Paul Touvier. He was charged in 1973 with crimes against humanity in connection with deportation of Jews from France to German death camps, and persecution of Resistance leaders. Touvier was head of intelligence for a pro-German militia in Lyons during the war.
AC Milan wins 34th Europe Cup 1 at Barcelona, Spain.
Herwig Hensen [Flor Mielants], Flemish dramatist/poet, dies at age 72.
Sonia Sutcliffe, wife of the Yorkshire Ripper, is awarded a six-figure sum in damages after winning a libel action against Private Eye.
The Calgary Flames of the National Hockey League win their first Stanley Cup with a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.
Mikhail Gorbachev is elected Executive President in the Soviet Union.
Seattle Mariners trade Mark Langston to Montreal Expos for Randy Johnson.
Eastern Airlines graduates its first class of non-union pilots.
Thirteen days after a Southern Pacific train derails, a Calnev pipeline explodes at the same section of Duffy Street in San Bernardino, California.
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
Danish parliament allows legal marriage among homosexuals.
Emerson Fittipaldi wins the Indianapolis 500 with an average speed of 167.581 mph.
Ayako Okamoto wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman Mike Schmidt, 39, retires.
Student protesters in Tiananmen Square, China unveil a 10m (33 feet) high Goddess of Democracy statue.
Zinka Milanov, Metropolitan Opera diva, dies of a stroke at age 83.
Tiananmen Square protests of 1989: The 33-foot high "Goddess of Democracy" statue is unveiled in Tiananmen Square by student demonstrators.
C L R James, cricket writer (distinguished Trinidadian), dies.
US Speaker of the House Jim Wright resigns.
Terry Drinkwater, CBS news correspondent, dies at age 53 of cancer.
Dr Charles A Hufnagel, artificial heart valve pioneer, dies at age 72.
Typhoon Lagoon water park opens at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Florida, covering 56 acres.
The SkyDome is opened in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
Rolling Stones' Bill Wyman marries Mandy Smith.
Fourteen-year old Scott Isaacs spells "spoliator" to win US National Spelling Bee.
Cincinnati Reds player Eric Davis hits for the cycle.
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Supreme Leader of Iran, dies at age 86 of internal bleeding (born 1900).
Houston Astros beat Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-4, in 22 innings (7:14:09).
Chinese troops kill hundreds of pro-democracy students in Beijing.
Country singer Rebe McEntire weds her manager Narvel Blackstone.
The government of China sends troops to force protesters out of Tiananmen Square after seven weeks of occupation.
The Tiananmen Square massacre takes place in Beijing on the army's approach to the square, and the final stand-off in the square is covered live on television.
Solidarity victorious in the first partly free parliamentary elections in post-war Poland.
Beijing cop shoots and wounds Chinese priemer Li Ping.
Largest parade in Bronx, New York, history honors 350th anniversary.
A natural gas explosion near Ufa, Russia kills 645 as two trains passing each other throw sparks near a leaky pipeline.
Boston Red Sox lead Toronto Blue Jays 10-0 in 7th, but lose 12-11 in 12 innings.
Ali Khamenei is elected the Supreme Leader of the Islamic Republic of Iran after the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
Ufa train disaster: A natural gas explosion near Ufa, Russia, kills 575 as two trains passing each other throw sparks near a leaky pipeline.
The Tiananmen Square protests are violently suppressed in Beijing and are covered live on television.

Solidarity's victory in the first partly free parliamentary elections in post-war Poland sparks off a succession of peaceful anti-communist revolutions in Eastern Europe and leads to creation of the so-called Contract Sejm.
The Unknown Rebel halts the progress of a column of advancing tanks for over half an hour after the Tiananmen Square protests.
In Ontario, Canada, the Toronto Skydome stadium opens for its first game; Milwaukee Brewers beat Toronto Blue Jays 5-3.
The Unknown Rebel halts the progress of a column of advancing tanks for over half an hour after the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989.
The Inuvialuit Final Agreement is signed in Canada to give the Inuit of western Canada the first comprehensive land claim agreement north of the 60th parallel.
23-year-old Olympic barefoot South African runner Zola Budd retires.
Atlanta Fulton County Committee approves US$210 million stadium for the Atlanta Falcons.
Wayne Gretzky wins his 9th NHL Hart Trophy (Most Valuable Player) in ten years.
176 people are killed in Surinam's worst air disaster.
A Suriname DC-8 Super 62 crashes near Paramaribo Airport, Suriname, killing 168.
Kurt Waldheim is elected president of Austria.
Michael Chang's French Open win makes him youngest male (age 17) to go to finals.
Rare tornado in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA kills one.
Barry Switzer resigns as head coach of University of Oklahoma's football.
Major French Open upset, as Spain's Arantxa Sanchez, 17 beats heavily Steffi Graf, also first Spaniard to win a grand slam title.
Youngest (age 17) male French Open champion and first US champion since 1955, Michael Chang upsets Stefan Edberg in the finals in five sets.
In Opotiki, New Zealand a building is hit by a falling meteorite.
Ben Johnson, Canadian Olympian, admits using steroids.
Corcoran Gallery of Art removes Robert Mapplethorpe's photography exhibition.
Nolan Ryan becomes second pitcher to defeat all 26 teams.
Detroit Pistons sweep Los Angeles Lakers for NBA title, Kareem Abdul Jabber's final NBA game.
Ground-breaking begins in Minnesota on the world's largest mall.
Rocker Carole King gets a star in Hollywood's Walk of Fame.
Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
Baltimore Orioles pull their 9th triple play (versus New York Yankees).
A crowd of 250,000 gathers at Heroes Square in Budapest for the historic reburial of Imre Nagy, the former Hungarian prime minister who had been executed in 1958.
Four golfers shoot a hole-in-one on the same hole at the US Open.
Historic reburial of Imre Nagy, the former Hungarian Prime Minister in Budapest.
John Matusek, Oakland Raiders player/actor, dies at age 38 of a heart attack.
US beats Guatemala 2-1, in third round of 1990 world soccer cup.
David S Griggs, astronaut, dies in crash of WW II vintage plane.
Curtis Strange wins his second US golf open.
Hy Gardner, newspaper columnist, dies at age 80.
I.F. Stone author, dies at age 81 of heart failure.
Walt Disney World welcomes its 300-millionth guest, Matt Gleason.
British police arrest 250 people for celebrating the summer solstice at Stonehenge.
US Supreme Court rules it is okay to burn US flag as political expression.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules in Texas v. Johnson that flag burning is protected speech under the United States Constitution.
Ireland's first universities established since independence in 1922 open: Dublin City University and the University of Limerick.
In Hawaii, a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occurs. Two events about 5 seconds apart. Five people injured slightly, 5 homes destroyed and about 100 homes damaged.
Don Henley's "The End of the Innocence" released.
New York State Legislature passes Staten Island seccession bill.
NASA closes down tracking stations in Santiago, Chile, and Guam.
US Attorney General Thornburgh orders Joseph Doherty deported to the United Kingdom.
NFL owners vote unanimously to form the WLAF.
Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece, resigns. A new government is formed under Tzannis Tzannetakis.
Andrei Gromyko, Soviet diplomat, dies just short of his 80th birthday.
US Supreme Court rules states do not have to provide funds for abortions.
Peter Koech of Kenya sets 3k steeplechase record (8:05.39) in Stockholm, Sweden.
Barry Bonds' home run sets father-son (with Bobby) home run record at 408.
Mark McGwire gets 100th home run, second fastest (1400 at bats) (to Kiner).
The sitcom Seinfeld aired its first episode.
Iran-Contra Affair: Oliver North is sentenced by U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell to a three-year suspended prison term, two years probation, $150,000 in fines and 1,200 hours community service.
After nine years, WHOT (Brooklyn pirate radio station) is busted by the US Federal Communications Commission.
(to July 12) U.S. President George H. W. Bush travels to Poland and Hungary, pushing for U.S. economic aid and investment.
First time Wimbeldon has both men and women's final on same day.
Two bombs explode in Mecca, killing one pilgrim and wounding 16 others.
Mel Blanc, voice of cartoon characters (Bugs Bunny), dies at age 81 (born 1908).
Sir Laurence Olivier, English stage and screen actor and director, dies at age 82 (born 1907).
American League beats National League 5-3, (third of last four All Star Games) in California.
US President Ronald Reagan sportscasts the All Star Game.
New York Yankees' pitching great Ron Guidry retires (170-91 .651, 3.29 ERA).
(to July 16) At the annual G-7 Summit, leaders call for restrictions on greenhouse gas emissions.
F-16 first kill by an Israeli Air Force pilot shooting dawn a Syrian MIG-21.

The Splash Mountain attraction opens in Critter Country at Disneyland, after five years of planning. The ride features 103 Audio-Animatronic characters, some from the former America Sings attraction. This is the longest flume chute ride in the world.
The B-2 Spirit Stealth Bomber first flies.
Rebecca Schaeffer is shot by a crazed fan, prompting California to pass America's first anti-stalking law in 1990.
United Airlines Flight 232 (Douglas DC-10) crashes in Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112; 184 on board survive.
A Douglas DC-10 carrying 296 aboard crashes in Sioux City, Iowa killing 112 but due to extraordinary efforts by the pilot and his crew, 184 on board survive. (See United Airlines flight 232)
Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi is placed under house arrest.
Photographer Robert Mapplethorpe's show opens at Washington, D.C.'s Project for the Arts after the Smithsonian Institution's Corcoran Gallery cancels it.
The United States Senate voted 73-26 to privatize the Energy Department's uranium enrichment program by creating a private company, the United States Enrichment Corporation.
Burma's ruling junta puts opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest.
Greg LeMond (US) wins Tour de France in fastest time.
Mike Tyson TKOs Carl "the Truth" Williams in 1:33 of first round.
Winds gust to 85 MPH at Fort Smith, Arkansas.
Rock/Hip-hop trio The Beastie Boys release the classic Paul's Boutique.

A federal grand jury indicts Cornell University student Robert Tappan Morris, Jr. for releasing a computer virus, making him the first person to be prosecuted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

A federal grand jury indicts Cornell University student Robert T. Morris, Jr. for releasing the Morris worm, thus becoming the first person to be prosecuted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.
Atlanta Braves' player Dale Murphy is 10th to get six RBIs in an inning (6th).
Atlanta Braves' player Dale Murphy hits two 3-run home runs in an inning, 14th man to hit.
Philadelphia Phillies retire Steve Carlton's number 32.
Vince Coleman's record streak stopped at 50 straight stolen bases.
Javier Sotomayor of Cuba sets high jump record (8 feet) in San Juan.
In Papua, Indonesia, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurs. About 120 people killed and 125 injured by landslides which buried two villages.
Cincinnati Reds send record 20 men to bat with a record 16 hits in one inning as they score 14 runs in the first inning.
Rickey Henderson sets American League mark of 50 steals in nine seasons.
Toronto Blue Jays' Dave Steib's perfect game is broken up in 9th inning with two outs by New York Yankees' player Roberto Kelly.
Boston Red Sox retire Carl Yastrezemski's number 8.
U.S. Congressman Mickey Leland (Democrat-Texas) and 15 others die in a plane crash in Ethiopia.
Federal Express purchases Flying Tigers for about US$800 million.
U.S. Congressman Mickey Leland (D-TX) and 15 others die in a plane crash in Ethiopia.
STS-28: Space Shuttle Columbia takes off on a secret five-day military mission.
STS-28: The Space Shuttle Columbia takes off on a secret five-day military mission.
The asteroid 4769 Castalia is the first asteroid directly imaged by radar from Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico.
Kaifu Toshiki becomes Prime Minister of Japan.
A hot air balloon accident near Alice Springs, Australia kills 13.
Tim Richmond, American race car driver (won 13 NASCAR races), dies of AIDS (born 1955).
The Sega Genesis is released in North America.
In Sixiangkou, People's Republic of China, a building is hit by a falling meteorite.
Roger Kingdom of USA sets the 110m hurdle record (12.92) in Zurich, Switzerland.
Leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galﬂn is assassinated near Bogotﬂ in Colombia.

The Soviet Government acknowledges for the first time since the end of World War II that they and Germany secretly and illegally divided Eastern Europe into spheres of influence before the start of the war.
Arturo Barrios of Mexico sets the 10 km record (27:08.23) in Berlin, Germany.
Bucky Dent replaces Dallas Green as New York Yankees' manager.
Leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galﬂn is assassinated near Bogotﬂ in Colombia.
Polish president Wojciech Jaruzelski nominates Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki to be Prime Minister, the first non-communist in power in 42 years.
Polish president Wojciech Jaruzelski nominates Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki to be the first non-communist Prime Minister in 42 years.
In Ethiopia, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake occurs.
Fifty-one people die when the Marchioness pleasure boat collides with a barge on the River Thames adjacent to Southwark Bridge.
In Beverly Hills, California, Lyle and Erik Menendez shoot and kill their wealthy parents.
Nolan Ryan strikes out his 5,000th batter.
The first complete ring around Neptune is discovered.
A commission of the Lithuanian Parliament declares that Moscow's annexation of the country in 1940 was invalid, achieved by way of secret agreements between Stalin and Hitler.
The first ring of Neptune is discovered
Nolan Ryan strikes out Rickey Henderson to become the first Major League Baseball pitcher to record 5000 strikeouts.
All of Australia's 1,645 domestic airline pilots resign over an airline's move to sack and sue them over a dispute.
Hungary removes border restrictions with Austria.
Yusef Hawkins is shot in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, New York, sparking racial tensions between African Americans and Italian Americans.

Two million indigenous people of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, then still occupied by the Soviet Union, join hands to demand freedom and independence, forming an uninterrupted 600 km human chain called the Baltic Way.
Los Angeles Dodgers beat Montreal Expos, 1-0, in 22 innings.
All of Australia's 1,645 domestic airline pilots resign after the airlines threaten to sack them and sue them over a dispute.
Singing Revolution: two million people from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania stand on the Vilnius-Tallinn road, holding hands (Baltic way).
Record-setting baseball player Pete Rose agrees to a lifetime ban from the sport following allegations of illegal gambling, thereby preventing his induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Indonesia's first privately owned television station, Rajawali Citra Televisi Indonesia, (RCTI) begins broadcasting.
Colombian drug barons declare "total war" on the Colombian government.
Cincinnati Reds manager Pete Rose is banned from baseball for gambling by Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti
Tadeusz Mazowiecki chosen as the first non-communist Prime Minister in Central and Eastern Europe.
Voyager 2 spacecraft flies by Neptune, the last major planet it could visit before leaving the Solar System.
Mayumi Moriyama becomes Japan's first female cabinet secretary.
The Trumbull (Connecticut) All-stars become the first American team to win the Little League World Series since 1983.
Off the coast of Jalisco, Mexico, a magnitude 6.7 earthquake occurs.
Princess Anne and Mark Phillips announce their separation.
Reverend Al Sharpton leads a civil rights march through Bensonhurst.
In Semidi Islands, Alaska, a magnitude 6.9 earthquake occurs.
U.S. President George H. W. Bush holds up a bag of cocaine purchased across the street at Lafayette Park in his first televised speech to the nation.

England holds Sweden to a 0-0 draw in Sweden, qualifying for the 1990 FIFA World Cup. The game became famous after Terry Butcher sustained a deep cut to his forehead early in the game. He received stitches but played on the entire game. By the end of the game, the front of Butcher's white shirt and shorts where almost entirely covered in blood.
Amateur Atheletic Federation strips Ben Johnson of all track records.
The South African general election (the last under apartheid) returns the National Party with a much-reduced majority.
Steffi Graf beats Martina Navratalova for the US Open championship.
The Hungarian government opens the country's western borders to refugees from the German Democratic Republic.
Boris Becker beats Yvan Lendl for the US Open championship.
Drexel formally pleads guilty to security fraud.
Hungary officially opens its border to Austria.
The iron curtain opens between the communist Hungary and Austria. From Hungary thousands of East Germans throng to Austria and West Germany.

Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki announces to parliament the Polish economy would undergo a shock therapy, including privitization of state industry, creation of a stock exchange, shift from heavy industry to consumer goods, and budget cuts.
Fay Vincent becomes Major League Baseball's eighth commissioner when he succeeds the late Bart Giamatti.
Largest anti-Apartheid march in South Africa, led by Desmond Tutu.
Agreement of cooperation between Leningrad oblast (Russia) and NordlandCounty (Norway) is signed in Leningrad, by the chairmen Lev Kojkolainen and Sigbj∞rn Eriksen.
Calgary Flames become first NHL team to play in USSR, win 4-2.
The U.S. Congress recognizes Terry Anderson's continued captivity in Beirut.
Hurricane Hugo begins four day sweep through Caribbean, killing 62.
Hurricane Hugo causes extensive damage in Puerto Rico.
Charles Keating jailed in Los Angeles after being indicted on criminal fraud charges concerning saving-and-loans.
Ontario NDP Leader Bob Rae arrested with 15 others in Temagami Wilderness Society anti-logging blockade.
Hurricane Hugo hits Puerto Rico, killing six.
Chase Manhattan Discovery Center at Brooklyn Botanic Garden opens.
Appeals court restores America's Cup to US after New York Supreme Court gave it to New Zealand (New Zealand protested US's use of a catamaran).
A terrorist bomb explodes UTA Flight 772 in mid-air above the Tùnùrù Desert, Niger, killing 171.
Hurricane Hugo makes landfall in the U.S. state of South Carolina.
F. W. de Klerk is sworn in as State President of South Africa.
Miss Saigon makes its world premeire in London
Hurricane Hugo makes landfall in South Carolina, causing US$7 billion in damage.
Poland's Sejm (National Assembly) approves prime minister Mazowiecki.
An Irish Republican Army bomb explodes at the Royal Marine School of Music in Deal, United Kingdom, leaving 11 dead and 22 injured.
In Sichuan Province, China, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake occurs. At least 54 people injured, about 4,270 houses destroyed.
Irving Berlin, American composer, dies at age 101 (born 1888).
Sony purchases Columbia Pictures for US$3.4 billion cash.
A.A. Busch Jr, brewer/baseball owner (Saint Louis Cardinals), dies at age 90.
NASA closes down tracking stations in Hawaii and Ascension.
Nolan Ryan's perfect game is broken with one out in the 8th, but he strikes-out his 300th of the year.
Foreign Minister of West Germany Hans-Dietrich Genscher's speech from the balcony of the German embassy in Prague.
Dallas Cowboys' Ed "Too Tall" Jones records his 1,000th NFL tackle.
USPS issues a stamp labeling an apatosaurus as a brontosaurus.
Thousands of East Germans flee to West Germany.
Panamanian Defense Force attempts coup of Manuel Noriega; fails.
U.S. televangelist John Nunes is found guilty of embezzling US$158 million.
Rickey Henderson steals a record 8 bases in a play off (5 games).
Radio talk show host Larry King weds Julie Alexander.
First NFL game coached by a black man (Art Shell), his Los Angeles Raiders beat New York Jets 14-7 on Monday Night Football.
In Leipzig, East Germany, protesters demand the legalization of opposition groups and democratic reforms.
An official news agency in the Soviet Union reports the landing of a UFO in Voronezh.
An official news agency in the Soviet Union reports the landing of a UFO in Voronezh.
In Leipzig, East Germany, 70,000 protesters demand the legalization of opposition groups and democratic reforms.
Herschel Walker is traded from Dallas Cowboys to Minnesota Vikings for 12 players.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunges 190.58 points, or 6.91 percent, to close at 2,569.26 most likely after the junk bond market collapses. This mini-crash becomes known as the Friday the 13th mini-crash.
Texas A&I, Johnny Bailey sets NCAA season rush record at 6,085 yards.
Wayne Gretsky passes Gordie Howe as NHL's all time top scorer.
Billy Graham is given the 1,900th star on Hollywood Boulevard.
South Africa president FW de Klerk frees Sisulu and four other political prisoners.
Wayne Gretzky becomes the all time leading points scorer in the NHL.
A drawing is held by American music video station VH-1, giving away 36 Corvettes, one from each model year. Dennis Amodeo is the winner. He later sells the cars for US$1.5 million.

In Loma Prieta, California, an earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale occurs. Three events are about 1.5 and 3.0 seconds apart. Sixty-two people killed, 3,757 injured and damage estimated at US$5.6 billion.
Loma Prieta earthquake (7.1 on the Richter scale) hits the San Francisco Bay Area.
In Northeastern China, a magnitude 5.3 earthquake occurs. At least 29 people killed, 150 injured and about 27,500 houses damaged.
The Communist leader of East Germany, Erich Honecker, is forced to step down as leader of the country after a series of health problems. He is replaced by Egon Krenz.
US 62nd manned space mission STS 34 (Atlantis 5) launches into orbit.
East German leader Erich Honecker resigns.
The Wonders of Life pavilion opens at Walt Disney World's Epcot in Orlando, Florida.
Guildford Four convictions are quashed by the Court of Appeal - they had spent 15 years in prison through a miscarriage of justice.
US Senate impeaches US District Judge Alcee L Hastings.
The Heads of Government of the Commonwealth of Nations issue the Langkawi Declaration on the Environment, making environmental sustainability one of the Commonwealth's main priorities.
Houston becomes first major college team to gain 1000 yards in a game.
Buck Helm found alive after being buried four days, in San Francisco earthquake.
Betram Lee and Peter Bynoe purchase Denver Nuggets for US$65 million.
Denver Nuggets beat Jugoplastika Split 135-129 in third McDonald Open.
Phillips Disaster in Pasadena, Texas kills 23 and injures 314 others.
The Hungarian Republic is officially declared by president Mﬂtyﬂs Szur˜s (replacing the Hungarian People's Republic).
US 62nd manned space mission STS 34 (Atlantis 5) returns from space.
The Hungarian Republic is officially declared by president Mﬂtyﬂs Sz?rös (replacing the Hungarian People's Republic).
After a week's delay due to earthquake, World Series game three is played (World Series #86).
Reverend Jim Bakker is sentenced to 50 years for fraud.
In Canada, four people share a CDN$14 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
The Oakland Athletics sweep of the San Francisco Giants winning baseball's World Series.
In Algeria, magnitude 5.9 and 5.6 earthquakes occur 12 minute apart. At least 30 people killed, 245 injured.
After years of delays, the 63rd Street Tunnel opens for service, the first expansion of the New York City subway system since 1967.
The qualification for the 1990 Football World Cup ends.
Scandinavian Airlines System bans smoking on many flights.
South Dakota begins legal gambling in Deadwood city.
Minnesota Timberwolves' first NBA game, lose to Seattle SuperSonics, 106-94.
Orlando Magic's first NBA game, loses to Nets, 111-106.
Typhoon Gay devastates the Thai province of Chumphon.
The congress of the Solidarity Party is inaugurated in Sweden. The congress decides, contrary to the proposal of the central committee, not to disband the party.
US plays El Salvador in third round of 1990 world soccer cup.
Barry Sadler, singer (Green Berets), dies at age 49 in Murfreesboro, Tennessee.
Vladamir Horowitz, Russian pianist, dies at age 85 (born 1903).
20th New York City Marathon (J Kanganaa 2:08:01 and Ingrid Kristiansen 2:25:28).
Kitty Dukakis, wife of presidential candidate and Massachusetts governor Michael Dukakis, is hospitalised for drinking rubbing alcohol.
The Communist government of East Germany resigns, although SED leader Egon Krenz remains head of state.
In California, convicted murderer Richard Ramirez (the "Night Stalker") is sentenced to death.
Douglas Wilder is elected as first US black governor (Democrat-Virginia).
David Dinkins becomes the first African American mayor of New York City.
Douglas Wilder wins the governor's seat in Virginia, becoming the first elected African American governor in the United States.
East German Prime Minister Willi Stoph, along with his entire cabinet, is forced to resign after huge anti-government protests.
East Germany opens checkpoints in the Berlin Wall, allowing its citizens to freely travel to West Germany for the first time in decades. Overnight, thousands flood over the border.
Cold War: Communist-controlled East Germany opens checkpoints in the Berlin Wall allowing its citizens to freely travel to West Germany.

After 45 years of Communist rule in Bulgaria, Bulgarian Communist Party leader Todor Zhivkov is replaced by Foreign Minister Petar Mladenov, who changes the party's name to the Bulgarian Socialist Party.
Germans begin punching holes in the Berlin Wall.
Gaby Kennard becomes the first Australian woman to fly non-stop around the world.
Guerrillas battle with government forces in El Salvador.
After ruling for 33 years , Bulgarian Communist Party leader Todor Zhivkov is replaced by foreign minister Petar Mladenov, who in 1990 changes the party's name to Bulgarian Socialist Party.
Canadian swimmer Victor Davis is hit by a car outside a nightclub in Montreal, Quebec. He dies two days later.
Brazil holds its first free presidential election since 1960.
Hans Modrow becomes East German President.
Sachin Tendulkar makes his Test cricket debut playing for India against Pakistan.
UNESCO adopts the Seville Statement on Violence at the twenty-fifth session of its General Conference.
Six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter are shot in San Salvador, El Salvador.
South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the scrapping of the Separate Amenities Act.
A death squad composed of El Salvadoran army troops kill six Jesuit priests and two others at Jose Simeon Canas University.
Bret Saberhagen signs record $2,966,667 per year Kansas City Royals contract.
In Czechoslovakia a student demonstration in Prague is severely beaten back by riot police. This sparks a revolution aimed at overthrowing the Communist government (it succeeds on December 29).

Cold War: Velvet Revolution begins - In Czechoslovakia a student demonstration in Prague is quelled by riot police. This sparks an uprising aimed at overthrowing the communist government (it succeeds on December 29).
US beats Trinidad 1-0 qualifying for the 1990 world soccer cup finals. It is US' first qualification since 1950.
The number of potesters assembled in Prague, Czechoslovakia swells to an estimated half-million.
In Sichuan Province, China, a magnitude 5.2 earthquake occurs. Four people killed, 161 injured and at least 1,000 homes destroyed.
In southern Iran, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs.
Velvet Revolution: The number of protestors assembled in Prague, Czechoslovakia swells from 200,000 the day before to an estimated half-million.
In West Beirut, a bomb explodes near the motorcade of Lebanese President Rene Moawad and kills him.
Kirby Pucket signs record US$3 million per year (for three years) Minnesota Twins' contract.
The Mirage hotel and casino opens in Las Vegas, Nevada. On the opening night, Elmer Sherwin wins US$4.6 million on a Megabucks spin. About 200,000 people attend the opening.
Eastern Airlines pilots and flight attendants end their strike, but most are not rehired.
Conjunction of Venus, Mars, Uranus, Neptune, Saturn and the Moon.
In West Beirut, a bomb explodes near the motorcade of Lebanese President Rene Moawad, killing him.
Pilots Union give up sympathy strike against Eastern Airlines.
US 63rd manned space mission STS 33 (Discovery 9) returns from space.
A Colombian jetliner is bombed, killing 107.
Rickey Henderson signs record US$3 million per year Oakland Athletics contract.
Cold War: Velvet Revolution - In the face of protests, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia announces they will give up their monopoly on political power.
In Bad Homburg, Germany, Deutsche Bank board member Alfred Herrhausen is killed by a bomb (the Red Army Faction claims responsibility for the murder).
Deutsche Bank board member Alfred Herrhausen is killed by a Red Army Faction terrorist bomb.
Richard Mallory of Palm Harbor, Florida becomes female serial killer Aileen Wuornos's first victim.
Mark Langston signs record US$3.2 million per year California Angels contract.
East Germany's parliament abolishes the constitutional provision granting the Communist-dominated SED its monopoly on power.
USSR President Mikhail S Gorbachev meets Pope John Paul II at the Vatican.
Day Without Art - Artists demonstrate against AIDS.
Alvin Ailey, American choreographer (Blues Suite, Revelations), dies at age 58 (born 1931).
Right-wing military rebel Reform the Armed forces Movement (RAM) attempt to oust Philippine President Corazon Aquino by a bloody coup attempt.
Cold War: East Germany's parliament abolishes the constitutional provision granting the communist party the leading role in the state.
55th Heisman Trophy Award: Andre Ware, Houston Oilers (quarterback).
Vishwanath Pratap Singh sworn in as President of India.

In a meeting off the coast of Malta, U.S. President George H. W. Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev release statements indicating that the Cold War between their nations may be coming to an end.
Pat Bradley/Bill Glasson win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.

Cold War: In a meeting off the coast of Malta, US President George H. W. Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev release statements indicating that the cold war between their nations may be coming to an end (some commentators from both nations exaggerated the wording and independently declared the Cold War over).
John M Pritchard, British conductor, dies at age 68 (born 1921).
France TGV train reaches world record speed of 482.4 kph.
Mafia drug kingpin bombs security force at Bogotﬂ, Colombia, kills 52.
In Montreal, Quebec, Canada, Marc LTpine, an anti-feminist gunman, murders 14 young women at the +cole Polytechnique, then kills himself.
ÿcole Polytechnique Massacre: Marc LTpine kills 14 young women in Montreal, Quebec.
In their third and final fight, Sugar Ray Leonard retains the WBC Super-Middleweight Championship of the World, defeating Roberto Duran.
President Gustav Husﬂk of Czechoslovakia resigns.
Tsakhiagiyn Elbegdorj announces the establishment of Mongolia's democratic movement, that peacefully changes the second oldest communist country into a democratic society.
Tsakhiagiyn Elbegdorj announced the establishment of Mongolia's democratic movement that peacefully changed the second oldest communist country into a democratic society.
Mark Davis signs record US$3.25 million per year Kansas City Royals contract.
Forced repatriation of Vietnamese in Hong Kong.
Walter Davis (Denver Nuggets) ends NBA free throw streak of 53 games.
The last issue of Gnistan (The Spark), the organ of the Solidaritetspartiet, is published in Sweden.
Chile holds its first free election in 16 years.
Andrei D Sakharov, Soviet physicist/dissident/1975 Nobel peace prize winner, dies in Moscow at age 68 (born 1921).
Patricio Aylwin is elected President of Chile.
Drug baron JosT Gonzalo Rodr?guez Gacha is killed by Colombian police.
Geoff Marsh completes 355 for Western Australia against South Australia.
Commencement of first Test Cricket play at Bellerive Oval, Hobart (versus Sierra Leone).
Protest breaks out in Timi?oara in response to an attempt by the government to evict dissident Hungarian pastor, Lﬂszl= T?kTs.
In Timisoara, Romania, an uprising begins against the communist regime, sparking the Romanian Revolution.
Patti Rizzo/Mike Hill win LPGA Mazda Golf Championship.
Michael Bevan scores cricket century on first-class debut (114 South Africa versus Western Australia).
78th Davis Cup: Germany beats Sweden in Stuttgart (3-2).
Brazil holds its first free election in 29 years, electing conservative Fernando Collor de Mello president.
Dorothea "Stella" Gibbons, English journalist/author, dies at age 87.
American Airlines purchases Eastern Airline's Latin American route.
American forces launch Operation Just Cause in an attempt to overthrow Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. 13,000 U.S. troops are sent to occupy Panama City, along with the 12,000 already there.
Premier Lubbers sees CDA-party leader Elco Brinkman as successor.
United States invasion of Panama: United States sends troops into Panama to overthrow government of Manuel Noriega.
Romania's dictator Nicolae Ceausescu makes his final speech (he is executed four days later).
US Vice-President Dan Quayle sends out 30,000 Christmas cards with word "beacon" spelled "beakon".
Ion Iliescu takes over as president of Romania, ending Nicolae Ceausescu's communist dictatorship, who flees his palace in a helicopter to escape inevitable execution.
Two tourist coaches collide on the Pacific highway north of Kempsey, Australia, killing 35.
After a week of bloody demonstrations, Ion Iliescu takes over as president of Romania, ending Nicolae Ceau?escu's Communist dictatorship.
Berlin's Brandenburg Gate re-opens after nearly 30 years, effectively ending the division of East and West Germany.
Two tourist coaches collide on the Pacific Highway north of Kempsey NSW (Kempsey Bus Crash).
Panamﬂ's dictator, Manual Noriega, seeks asylum at the Vatican embassy.
Charles Taylor enters Liberia to unseat President Samuel K Doe.
Ton Regtien, Dutch student leader, dies at age 51.
Bank of Japan governors announce a major interest rate hike.
Romanian dictator (1945-89) Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena are executed after their unsuccessful escape attempt.
Japanese scientist achieves -271.8 degrees C, coldest temperature ever recorded.
Billy Martin, New York Yankees' baseball manager, killed in a car accident at age 61 in Binghamton, New York.
Nicolae Ceau?escu, former communist dictator of Romania, and his wife Elena are condemned to death and executed under a wide range of charges.
ODI debut for Mark Taylor and Sanath Jayasuriya at cricket Melbourne Cricket Ground.
Oregon begins taking bids on NBA games.
A magnitude 5.5 earthquake hits Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia, killing 13 people. Estimated damage: US$1.1 billion.
A magnitude 5.6 earthquake hits Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia, killing 13 people.
Vﬂclav Havel is elected President of Czechoslovakia.

In Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, the provincial government opens the Crystal Casino, the first permanent casino in the country, on the 7th floor of the Fort Gary Hotel, with 19,000 square feet (589 m2) of gaming space.
Riots break-out after Hong Kong decides to forcibly repatriate Vietnamese refugees.
Wayne Gretzky and Martina Navratilova are named athletes of the decade by the Associated Press.
On the last day of stock trading in Japan, the Nikkei 225 stock market index closes at a peak of 38,915.
Riots break-out after Hong Kong decides to forcibly repatriate Vietnamese refugees.
Vﬂclav Havel becomes President of Czechoslovakia.
On the final day of trading for the year and decade, the Japanese Nikkei 225 Average closes at an all-time high of 38,915.87.
Dmitri Volkov swims world record 50 metre freestyle (27.15 seconds).
Fog Bowl: Heavy fog rolls in on Chicago Bears 20-12 victory over Philadelphia Eagles.
Jockey Kent Desormeaux sets record with 598 wins in a year.
David Dinkins was sworn in as New York City's first black mayor
Charles Boost, Dutch film critic, dies at age 82.
US Federal Communications Commission implements "SYNDEX" giving independent stations more rights over cable TV outlets for exclusive syndicated programs.
Joe Hardstaff Jr, cricket player (23 Tests for England, 1636 runs), dies.
Gerhard Schr˜der, West German minister of Defense, dies at age 79.
Mitsuko Nishiwaki beats Nakano to become Japan Women wrestling champ.
Sports News Network begins operation on cable TV.
David Dinkins sworn in as first black mayor of New York City, New York.
Suzuki Sochu, Zen teacher (Rinzai line)/abbot of Ryutakuji, dies.
Vladimir Alexis Ussachevsky, Manchuria composer (Creation), dies at age 78.
Belcampo [Herman Sch˜nfeld Wichers], Dutch lawyer/writer, dies at age 87.
Dow Jones Industrial Average hits record 2,800 (2,810.15).
Former leader of Panama Manuel Noriega surrenders to American forces.
Panamﬂ's leader General Manuel Noriega surrenders to US military troops to face charges of drug trafficking.
A crowded passenger train collides with a standing freight train in Pakistan's Sindh province, killing 300 people.
Alberto Lleras Camargo, President of Colombia (1945-46, 1958-62), dies.
Over 300 people are killed in a train accident in Ghotki, Pakistan.
Robert F Adams, American sci-fi author (Castaways in Time), dies at age 57.
J Donald Crump appointed 8th Commissioner of Canadian Football League.
New York Lotto pays US$35 million to one winner (numbers are 18-25-26-32-42-44).
In Italy, the Leaning Tower Of Pisa closed to the public due to safety concerns.
Lynn Jennings runs world record 5km indoor at 15:22.64.
The Leaning Tower of Pisa is closed to the public due to safety concerns.
Joseph Robbie, lawyer/NFL owner (Miami Dolphins), dies at age 73.
Horace Stoneham, baseball owner (San Francisco Giants), dies at age 86.
Bronislau "Bronko" Nagurski, football hall of famer, dies at age 81.
Demonstrations in Leipzig, Germany, demand reunification; "Wir sind ein Volk!" is the chant used on this day during the demonstrations.
Ugandan Lt. Gen. Bazilio Olara-Okello, who led a coup against Dr. Apolo Milton Obote's government, dies in Ormduruman Hospital in Khartoum, Sudan.
Boston Celtics worst-ever (6 points in second versus New Jersey Nets) and lose 87-78.
Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan are elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
China lifts martial law (imposed after Tiananmen Square massacre).
NCAA approves random drug testing for college football players.
Time Warner is formed from the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.
Time Warner is formed from the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.
Pat Lafontaine sets New York Islanders record of scoring goals in 11 straight.
Bobby Knight becomes basketball's Big 10 winningest coach (229).
300,000 march in favor of Lithuanian independence.
Civil Rights activist Reverand Al Sharpton is stabbed in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.
Romania bans Communist party (first Warsaw Pact member to do so).
First elected US black governor inaugurated (Douglas Wilder-Virginia).
The Walt Disney World Swan Hotel opens in Walt Disney World.
In Maryland, a magnitude 2.6 earthquake occurs, the largest historical earthquake in Maryland.
L. Douglas Wilder becomes the first elected African American governor as he takes office in Richmond, Virginia.
Perez de Cuellar says he has lost all hope for peace in the Persian Gulf.
42-year-old George Foreman knocks out George Cooney in two rounds.
Thousands storm the Stasi headquarters in Berlin in an attempt to view their government records.
New York Knicks' Trent Tucker scores with 1/10 second remaining, beats Chicago Bulls, 109-106.
Toronto Blue Jays' player Cecil Fielder signs with Detroit Tigers as a free agent.
AT&T experiences long distance problems due to a computer glitch.
AT&T's long distance telephone network suffers a cascade switching failure.
Two Bank of Credit and Commerce members plea guilty to money laundering.
Dave Stewart signs record US$3,500,000 per year Oakland Athletics contract.
The Who, Simon and Garfunkel, Four Seasons, Four Tops, Hank Ballard, Platters and Kinks inducted into Cleveland's Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
Charles Hernu, French minister of Defense (1981-85), dies.
Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry is arrested for drug possession in an FBI sting.
Melanie Appleby, rocker (Mel and Kim), dies of liver cancer at age 23.
South Africa says it is reconsidering ban on African National Congress.
Former preschool operators Raymond Buckey and his mother Peggy McMartin Buckey are acquitted in a Los Angeles, California court of 52 child molestation charges.
Washington, DC, Mayor Marion Barry is arrested for drug possession in an FBI sting.
Test debut of Mushtaq Ahmed, versus Australia at Adelaide.
Herbert Wehner, German ex-communist/chairman (1958-73), dies at age 83.
Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, Indian guru, dies at age 58.
US 64th manned space mission STS 32 (Columbia 10) returns from space.
Soviet troops occupy Baku, Azerbaijan, under the state of emergency decree issued by Gorbachev, and kill over 130 and wound over 700 protesters for national independence.
Naruhito Higashi-Kuni, Japanese Prime Minister (1945), dies.
Black January - bloody crackdown of Azerbaijani peaceful pro-independence demonstrations by Soviet army in Baku.
The East German political party, the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, changes its name to the Party of Democratic Socialism to minimize negative association with East Germany.
Bob Goodenow succeeds Alan Eagleson as NHL players association executive director.
41st NHL All-Star Game: Wales beat Campbell 12-7 at Pittsburgh.
Patty Sheehan wins LPGA Jamaica Golf Classic.
John McEnroe becomes the first ever expelled from the Australian Open for throwing a tantrum and swearing at an official.
Robert Tappan Morris, Jr. is convicted of releasing the 1988 Internet worm.
Wasim Akram scores Test century (123) at Adelaide.
Will Clark, National League's Most Valuable Player signs a $15 million four-year contract with San Francisco Giants.
Robert Tappan Morris, Jr. is convicted of releasing the 1988 Internet worm.
Allen Larkin Collins, guitarist, dies of pneumonia at age 37. Collins was one of the founding members and guitarists of Southern US rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd.
Dean Jones scores twin Test tons versus Pakistan at Adelaide Oval.
Mariano Rumor, Italy's Prime Minister (1968-70, 1973-74), dies.
(to January 26) The Burns' Day storm kills 97 in northwestern Europe.
Former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega is transferred to a Miami Florida jail.
Avianca Flight 52 runs out of fuel and crashes into Cove Neck, Long Island, after a miscommunication between the flight crew and JFK Airport officials. 73 die.
Honduras becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
The Burns' Day storm hits Northwestern Europe.
Annular eclipse visible over Antarctica and South Atlantic.
Boston Red Sox hires Elaine Weddington as assistant general manager (highest-ranking black female in a major-league front office).
The city of Tiraspol in the Moldavian SSR briefly declares independence.
64th Australian Open Women's Tennis: Steffi Graf beats Mary Jo Fernandez (6-3, 6-4).
East German agreement to form all-party government.

The San Francisco 49ers defend their NFL Championship, winning their fourth Super Bowl overall with a 55-10 win over the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXIV at the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana. Most Valuable Player is quarterback Joe Montana of the 49ers.
78th Australian Men's Tennis: Ivan Lendl beats Stefan Edberg (4-6, 7-6, 5-2-retire).
First McDonald's fast-food restaurant in Russia opens in Moscow, world's biggest McDonald's.
Jushin "Thunder" Liger beats Naoki Sano to become New Japan IWGP champ.
The first McDonald's opens in Moscow, Russia.
In South Africa, President F.W. de Klerk allows the African National Congress to legally function again and promises to free Nelson Mandela.
Apartheid: In South Africa President F.W. de Klerk allows the African National Congress to legally function again and promises to set Nelson Mandela free.
New York Mets' Darryl Strawberry voluntarily enters Smither Center for alcohol rehabilitation.
Jockey Billy Shoemaker (58) retires after 40,350 horse races.
Richard Hadlee takes his 400th Test Cricket wicket (Sanjay Manjrekar).
Lyudmila Narozhi-Lenko runs world record 60 metre hurdles indoor (7.69).
Danny Everett runs world record 400 metre indoor (45:04).
Ten Israeli tourists murdered near Cairo, Egypt.
Anders Holmertz swims world record 400 metre freestyle (3 minutes 40.81 seconds).
Pat Bradley win Oldsmobile LPGA Golf Classic.
NFL Pro Bowl: NFC beats AFC 27-21.
The Saint Petersburg Pelicans defeat the Palm Beach Tropics to win the first Senior Professional Baseball Association Championship, 12-4.
Manuel Fraga becomes the president of Galicia (Spain).
Notre Dame becomes first team to sell its game to a major network (NBC).
Brett Hull becomes first son of NHL 50 goal scorer (Bobby) to score 50.
Ground breaking begins on Baltimore Orioles' new $102 million stadium.
Nathan Wartels, publisher (Crown), dies from pneumonia at age 88.
The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party agrees to give up its monopoly of power.
Dom Heider Camara, nonviolent/human rights Bishop of Brazil, dies.
Collapse of the Soviet Union: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party agrees to give up its monopoly of power.
Del Shannon, in Coopersville, Michigan, American rock vocalist ("Runaway"), shoots self at age 55 (born 1934).
Doina Melinte runs world indoor record 1.5km (4:00:27) and mile (4:17:13).
South Africa President F.W. de Klerk announces Nelson Mandela will be free February 11th.
US female Figure Skating championship won by Jill Trenary.
James "Buster" Douglas KO's Mike Tyson In what perhaps was one of the greatest upsets in sports history .
US male Figure Skating championship won by Todd Eldredge.
James "Buster" Douglas knocks out Mike Tyson to win the World Heavyweight Boxing crown.
40th NBA All-Star Game: East beats West 130-113 in Miami.
Nelson Mandela is released from Victor Verster Prison, near Cape Town, South Africa, after 27 years behind bars.
Nelson Mandela, a political prisoner for 27 years, is freed from Victor Verster prison outside Cape Town, South Africa.
Larry Bird (Boston Celtics) ends NBA free throw streak of 71 games.
50 killed at Inkatha-UDF battle in Natal, South Africa.
US, France, and England give consent to German reunification.
German reunification: An agreement is reached for a two-stage plan to reunite Germany.
Graeme Hole, cricket player (18 Tests for Australia, 789 runs), dies.
Perrier recalls 160 million bottles of sparkling water after traces of benzene, a carcinogen, are found in some.
A lockout begins as Major League Baseball owners refuse to open spring training camp without reaching a new Basic Agreement with the players.

IBM unveils its new RISC-based workstation line, the RS/6000. Development work had been done under code name "America" for the RISC chip research, and "RIOS" for systems using the America technology. The architecture of the systems is given the name POWER, standing for Performance Optimization With Enhanced RISC.

The United Kingdom and Argentina restore diplomatic relations, after severing them eight years ago. The UK had severed ties in response to Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands, a British Dependent Territory, in 1982.
Keith Haring, American artist/cartoonist (brilliant baby), dies of AIDS at age 31 (born 1954).
Jane Crafter wins LPGA Phar-Mor at Inverrary Golf Tournament.
Police kill eight demonstrators for multi-party system in Nepal.
32nd Grammy Awards: "Wind Beneath My Wings", Nick of Time win.
First day India versus New Zealand cricket at Auckland New Zealand 5-78 at lunch, 9-387 stumps.
Annelien Kappeyne van de Coppello, Dutch Member of Parliament (Liberal), dies at age 53.
Jose Napoleon Duarte, President of Salvador (1984-89), dies at age 62.
Ian Smith 173 New Zealand versus India, 136 balls, world record for no 9 bat.
James Gavin, commandant US 82nd Airborn Division (Normandy), dies at age 82.
Sandro Pertini, President of Italy (1978, 1985), dies at age 93.
Tony Conigliaro, American baseball player (Boston Red Sox), dies in Salem, Massachusetts at age 45 of pneumonia and kidney failure.
Malcolm Forbes, CEO (Forbes Publishing), dies of a heart attack at age 70 (born 1919).
Johnnie Ray, singer (Cry), dies of liver failure at age 61.
Beth Daniel wins LPGA Orix Hawaiian Ladies Golf Open.
Australia beats Pakistan 2-0 to win the Cricket World Series Cup.
The Sandinistas are defeated in the Nicaraguan elections.
Maurine Stuart, Zen teacher (head of Cambridge Buddhist Association), dies.
Leslie Ames, cricket player (47 Tests, 2434 runs 8 centuries), dies.
USSR agrees to withdraw all 73,500 troops from Czechoslovakia by July, 1991.
Cornell Gunther, US musician (Coasters, Poison Ivy), dies at age 53.
The Sandinistas are defeated in Nicaraguan elections.
Exxon Valdez oil spill: Exxon and its shipping company are indicted on five criminal counts.
Colin Milburn, cricket player (9 Tests for England, 654 runs), dies.
In Southern California, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs.
Tuppy Owen-Smith, South Africa cricket player (batsman versus England 1929), dies.
In Texas, near-stock ZR-1 and L-98 Corvettes set a dozen land speed records. Average speed for all runs is 170- to 175-MPH.
Luis Alberto Lacelle sworn in as President of Uruguay.
The Royal New Zealand Navy discontinues its daily rum ration.
A fire at the Sheraton Hotel in Cairo, Egypt, kills 16 people.
Steve Jackson Games is raided by the U.S. Secret Service, prompting the later formation of the Electronic Frontier Foundation.
Steve Jackson Games is raided by the United States Secret Service, prompting the later formation of the Electronic Frontier Foundation.
Greyhound Bus workers go on strike.
Mark Tewsksbury swims world record 50 metre backstroke (25.06 seconds).
Nelson Mandela elected deputy President of the African National Congress.
Gerard Blitz, Belgian swimmer/founder (Club MTd), dies at age 88.
Frans Goedhart, Dutch journalist/founder (Parool), dies at age 86.
Beth Daniel wins LPGA Women's Kemper Golf Open.
In Pakistan, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake occurs. At least 11 people killed, about 40 injured and many homes and buildings damaged.
Space Shuttle program: STS-36 (Space Shuttle Atlantis) U.S. 65th manned space mission returns from space.
Gloria Carter Spann, President Carter's sister, dies at age 63 from cancer.
American SR-71 sets a transcontinental record, flying 2,404 miles in 1:08:17.
Three passengers killed and 162 injured as subway train derails in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA.
H Wayne Huizenga buys half Joe Robbie Stadium and 15 percent of Miami Dolphins for US$30 million.

The German Parliament, Bundestag issues a resolution concerning the border with Poland which, "will at no time, either today or in the future, be questioned through territorial claims on the part of the Germans."
New York City's Zodiac killer shoots first victim, Mario Orosco.
Police seal off Brixton in South London after another night of protests against the poll tax.
In Canada, Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells confirms he will rescind Newfoundland's approval of the Meech Lake Accord.
Antonia Novello is sworn in as Surgeon General of the United States, becoming the first female and Hispanic American to serve in that position.
Dr. Antonia Novello is sworn in as Surgeon General of the United States, becoming the first female and Hispanic American to serve in that position.
Newfoundland and Labrador Premier Clyde Wells confirms he will rescind Newfoundland's approval of the Meech Lake Accord, effectively killing the Accord.
World Ice Pairs Figure Skating Championship in Halifax won by Ekaterina Gordeeva and Sergei Grinkov (USSR).
World Men's Figure Skating Championship in Halifax won by Kurt Browning (Canada).
US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site.
Lieutenant General Avril resigns as President of Haiti, eighteen months after seizing power in a coup.
Michael Stewart, United Kingdom Secretary of State (1965-66, 1968-70), dies.
World Ice Dance Championship in Halifax won by Marina Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko (USSR).

Lithuanian Parliament declares incorporation into the Soviet Union was illegal, and declares independence.
Maggie Will wins Desert Inn LPGA Golf International.

Los Angeles Raiders announce they are returning to Oakland.
Nicholoas Braithwaite elected premier of Grenada.
Bruno Bettelhelm, Austrian/American child psychoanalyst, commits suicide at age 86 in Silver Spring, Maryland (born 1903).

Iraq hangs British journalist Farzad Bazoft for spying. Daphne Parish, a British nurse, is sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment as an accomplice.
Fernando Collor de Mello sworn in as President of Brazil.

Gulf War: Iraq hangs British journalist Farzad Bazoft for spying.
Mikhail Gorbachev is elected as the first executive president of the Soviet Union.

The ethnic clashes of Targu Mures begin on the anniversary of the Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas.
Rick Grech, British rock bassist (Blind Faith, Traffic), dies at age 44 (born 1946).
PBA National Championship Won by Jim Pencak.
After a 32-day lockout, Major League Baseball players and owners reach an agreement on a four-year contract.
A Tampa Florida little league player dies after being struck by a pitch.
Colleen Walker wins Circle K Tucson LPGA Golf Open.

Twelve paintings, collectively worth US$100+ million, are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts by two thieves posing as police officers. This is the largest art theft in US history, and the paintings (as of 2007) have not been recovered.
Loyola Marymount beats Michigan Wolverines 149-115, highest NCAA score.
First free elections in German Democratic Republic (East Germany); Conservatives beat Communists.
12 paintings, collectively worth $100 million, are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts. This is the largest art theft in US history.
First world ice hockey tournament for women held (Ottawa, Canada).
Jannetje Visser-Roosendaal, Dutch writer, dies at age 90.
Jev Jasjin (Lev Yashin), Russian soccer goalie, dies at age 60 (born 1929).
Los Angeles Lakers retire Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's number 33.
Ferdinand Marcos's widow, Imelda Marcos, goes on trial for bribery, embezzlement, and racketeering.
Ferdinand Marcos's widow, Imelda Marcos, goes on trial for bribery, embezzlement, and racketeering.
After 75 years of South African rule, Namibia becomes independent; Sam Nujoma first president.
Namibia becomes independent after 75 years of South African rule.
The Major League Baseball umpires announce that they will boycott exhibition games.
Howard Spira is arrested for extorting money from George Steinbrenner. The New York Yankees' owner paid Spira US$40,000 in January.
Former Exxon Valdez Captain Joseph Hazelwood ordered to help clean up Prince William Sound and pay $50,000 in restitution for 1989 oil spill.
The government of Australian prime minister Bob Hawke is re-elected for a fourth term.
Tom Hunter swims world record 50-metre freestyle (21.81 seconds).
Ray Goulding, comedian (Bob and Ray), dies from kidney failure at age 68.
An Wang, computer manufacturer (Wang), dies at age 70 from cancer.
Bob Hawke and the ALP defeats Andrew Peacock and the Liberal Party of Australia in his final election as Prime Minister of Australia.
In New York City, a fire due to arson at an illegal social club called "Happy Land" kills 87.
In Costa Rica, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs. Felt throughout Costa Rica and southwestern Nicaragua, and parts of Panama.
Pat Bradley wins LPGA Standard Register Turquoise Golf Classic.
In the Bronx, New York City, a fire at an illegal social club called "Happy Land" kills 87 people.
Roy "Halston" Frowick, fashion designer, dies of AIDS at age 68.
Bus accidentally touches high voltage wire in Karagpur, India; 21 die.
New South Wales beats Queensland by 345 runs to win Sheffield Shield Final.
The United States begins broadcasting TV Mart? to Cuba.
Propaganda: The United States begins broadcasting TV Martf to Cuba.
Bengal beats Delhi in rained-out cricket Ranji Trophy final on quotient.
U.S. President George H. W. Bush posthumously awards Jesse Owens the Congressional Gold Medal.
Michael Jordan scores 69 points, fourth time he scores 60 points in a game.
President George H. W. Bush posthumously awards Jesse Owens the Congressional Gold Medal.
New York City's Zodiac killer shoots second victim, Germaine Montenesdro.
Houston Rockets' Akeen Olajuwan scores the third NBA quadruple double 18 points, 16 rebounds, ten assists and 11 blocks versus Milwaukee Bucks.
Jack Nicklaus makes his debut in the "Seniors" golf tournament.
Dionisio Castro cycles world record 20 km (57:18.4).
A massive anti-poll tax demonstration in Trafalgar Square, London, turns into a riot; 471 people are injured, and 341 arrested.
The Comedy Channel on cable TV begins transmitting.
19th Nabisco Dinah Shore Golf Championship won by Betsy King.
9th NCAA Women's Basketball Championship: Stanford beats Auburn 88-81.

Wrestlemania VI (67,678 in Toronto); Ultimate Warrior beats Hulk Hogan for championship.
The largest prison riot in Britain's history begins at Strangeways Prison in Manchester, continuing for three weeks and three days.
52nd NCAA Men's Basketball Championship: Nevada-Las Vegas beats Duke 103-73.
Sarah Vaughan, American jazz singer, dies of lung cancer at age 66 (born 1924).
Nico Scheepmaker, Dutch columnist/poet, dies at age 59.
New York Rangers beat New York Islanders 2-1 in first game of preliminaries.
John Stockton reaches 1000-assist mark for NBA record three years in a row.
Ronald E Evans, astronaut (Apollo 17), dies of a heart attack at age 57.
Lady Nancy Hawkes (1946 best-dressed woman) dies at age 73.
BPAA US Open won by Ron Palombi Jr.
Thirty die in a ferry flip-over in Burma.
In Enschede, Netherlands, a house is hit by believed fragment of comet Midas.
John Poindexter (US National Security Advisor) is found guilty of five charges for his part in the Iran Contra scandal; the convictions are later reversed on appeal.
New York Rangers beat New York Islanders 5-2, New York Rangers lead 2-0 in preliminary NHL playoff.
Iran Contra Affair: John Poindexter is found guilty of five charges for his part in the scandal (the conviction was reversed on appeal).
King Birendra of Nepal lifts 30-year ban on political parties.
54th Golf Masters Championship: Nick Faldo wins, shooting a 278.
Kris Monaghan wins LPGA Red Robin Kyocera Inamori Golf Classic.
Ryan White, hemophiliac AIDS sufferer, dies at age 18 (born 1971).
World's largest bunny hop at Radio City Music Hall (New York City).
Don Mattingly signs a US$19.7 million 5-year contract with the New York Yankees.
New York Islanders beat New York Rangers 4-3 in double overtime-Rangers lead 2-1.
Houston Astros' Glen Davis is hit by a pitch three times, tying a major league record, in a 8-4 Opening Day loss to the Cincinnati Reds.
Curtly Ambrose takes 8-45 in cricket versus England at Bridgetown.
CUNY/Lehman College, Bronx, opens a branch campus in Hiroshma, Japan.
New York Rangers beat New York Islanders 6-1, Rangers lead 3-1 in preliminary.
New York Lotto pays US$35 million to two winners (numbers are 6-14-24-32-34-51).
California Angels' Mark Langston and Mike Witt, no-hit Seattle Mariners, 1-0.
First meeting of East German democratically elected parliament, acknowledges responsibility for German holocaust and asks for forgiveness.
Greyhound Bus hires new drivers to replace strikers.

Fourth largest NBA crowd (45,458) see Orlando Magic play at Minneapolis Timberwolves.
Final episode of Pat Sajak's late night TV show on CBS.
The Soviet Union apologizes for the Katyn Massacre of Polish officers during World War II.
The first sellout in Seattle Mariners' history occurs when 54,597 fans attend the season opener at the Kingdome.
Food poisoning kills 450 guests at an engagement party in Uttar Pradesh.
Greenidge and Haynes make 298 opening stand (versus England), their best.
19th Boston Women's Marathon won by Rosa Mota of Portugal in 2:25:23.
Maximum New York State unemployment benefits raised to $260 per week.
US Supreme Court rejects appeal from retarded man, Dalton Prejean, condemned to death for murdering a Louisiana state trooper in 1977.
94th Boston Marathon won by Gelindo Bordin of Italy in 2:08:19.
Reverend Ralph David Abernathy, American civil rights activist, dies at 64 (born 1926).

Birmingham Fire issued an original franchise in the WLAF.
Bankruptcy court forces Frank Lorenzo to give up Eastern Airlines.

Detroit Pistons and Philadelphia 76'ers get into a fight accruing $162,500 in fines (an NBA record).
Vladislav Ivanovich Gulyayev, Russian cosmonaut, dies at age 52.
Eight and 2/3 inning perfect game pitched by Brian Holman of the Oakland Athletics is spoiled by a home run hit by Ken Philips.
Horst Sinderman, RDA first minister (1973-76), dies.

National League umpire is arrested for stealing baseball cards.
Johnny Beagley, winner of two 1942 World Series games, dies.
Cincinnati Reds win, running their record to 9-0, best start in club history.
Lebanon releases US hostage Robert Polhill after 39 months.

In an election in Karl-Marx-Stadt over 75 percent of the voters vote to change the name of the city back to Chemnitz. The name had been changed on May 5, 1953 in honor of the 135th birthday of Karl Marx.
Namibia becomes the 160th member of the United Nations and the 50th member of the Commonwealth of Nations.
Security law violator Michael Milken pleads guilty to six felonies.
West and East Germany agree to merge currency and economies on July 1.
Gruinard Island, Scotland, is officially declared free of anthrax after 48 years of quarantine.

50th annual barbershop quartet singing convention held (Michigan).

Seattle Mariners' Brian Holman's perfect game broken up with two outs in 9th.

Agreement is reached between East and West Germany on the exchange of currency as the East takes on the Deutsches-mark as its currency. The currencies are to be exchanged 1:1 with some variations for given categories of exchange. At a maximum 6,000 east marks may be exchanged at the 1:1 rate.
South African government and African National Congress open talks to end apartheid.
In London, England, a man brandishing a knife robs courier Nicholas Lane of bearer bonds worth 292 million pounds sterling (the largest mugging to date).
Pimen [Sergei Irzyekov], patriarch of Russian-orthodox church, dies at age 79.
Latvia's parliament votes 138-0 (one abstention) for independence.

In northern Peru, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurs. Three events about 1.5 and 4.8 seconds apart. At least 135 people killed, more than 800 injured and severe damage.

New York City's Zodiac killer shoots third victim, Joseph Ponce.
BPAA US Women's Bowling Open won by Dana Miller-Mackie.
63rd National Spelling Bee: Amy Marie Dimak wins spelling "fibranne".
The pilot episode of Seinfeld premieres.

Members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army shoot and kill Major Michael Dillon-Lee and Private William Robert Davies of the British Army. Dillon-Lee is killed outside his home in Dortmund, Germany and Davies is killed at a railway station in Lichfield, England.
Dow Jones Industrial Average hits a record high of 2,900.97.
The Cowboy Channel on cable TV begins transmitting.

U.S. President George H. W. Bush and Soviet Union leader Mikhail Gorbachev sign a treaty to end chemical weapon production and start destroying each of their nation's stockpiles.
Frederick Mellinger, founder of Fredericks of Hollywood, dies at age 76.

The Lower Ohio Valley tornado outbreak spawns 88 confirmed tornadoes in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, and Ohio, killing 9. 37 tornadoes occur in Indiana, eclipsing the previous record of 21 during the Super Outbreak of April 1974.
Jack Gilford, comedic actor, dies at age 82 of stomach cancer.
The Walt Disney World Dolphin hotel opens at Walt Disney World.
Stump Merrill replaces Bucky Dent as New York Yankees' manager.

U.S. District court judge Jose Gonzales rules that the rap album As Nasty As They Wanna Be by the 2 Live Crew violates Florida's obscenity law; he declares that the predominant subject matter of the record is "directed to the 'dirty' thoughts and the loins, not to the intellect and the mind."
Universal Studios Florida opens to the public.
Phil Bradley hits the 18th inside-the-park home run in Baltimore Orioles' history.
The 1990 FIFA World Cup begins in Italy.
Go and Go wins the 122nd Belmont Stakes horse race.

Monica Salas beats Steffi Graff for French Open women's tennis title.
