The parliament of the Russian Federation formally declares its sovereignty.
Russia Day ? The parliament of the Russian Federation formally declares its sovereignty.
Boeing 767 sets nonstop commercial flight: Seattle, Washington to Narobi, Kenya.
Washington DC mayor Marion Barry announces he will not seek a fourth term.
In the Kazakh-Xinjiang border region, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. One person killed, 3,000 houses destroyed and 20,000 people left homeless.
Detroit Pistons beat Portland Trail Blazers, four games to one for NBA championship.
In Panay, Philippine Islands, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. At least four people killed, 15 injured.
Palmira Henry, fashion designer, dies at age 44 of cerebral hemorrhage.
First sudden death US Open Golf Championship is won by Hale Irwin.
First ever loss for Cameroon in the World Cup, USSR-4 Cameroon-0.

In Iran, a magnitude 7.4 earthquake occurs. One of the world's most destructive earthquakes. Estimated 40,000 to 50,000 people killed, more than 60,000 injured, 400,000 or more homeless and extensive damage and landslides.
Little Richard gets a star on Hollywood's walk of fame.
US House of Representatives vote 254-177 to stop US flag burning, doesn't pass Senate.
New York City's Zodiac killer shoots fourth victim, Larry Parham.
Florida passes a law prohibits wearing a thong bathing suit.
Longest game in Toronto, New York Yankees beat Toronto Blue Jays 8-7 in 15 innings.
Underwater volcano Mount Didicas erupts in the Philippines.
Moldova adopts a declaration of sovereignty.
Kathleen Young and Irene Templeton are ordained as priests in Saint Anne's Cathedral, Belfast, becoming the first Anglican women priests in the United Kingdom.
U.S. President George Bush breaks his 1988 'no new taxes' campaign pledge, accepting tax revenue increases as a necessity to reduce the budget deficit.

Merrill Lynch begins selling up to US$2.25 billion convertible bonds for the Walt Disney Company, the largest such issue in US history. The bond issue is to raise funds for building Euro Disneyland in France.
JosT Canseco signs record $4,700,000 per year Oakland Athletics contract.
Paperback Software found guilty by a U.S. court of copyright violation for copying the appearance and menu system of Lotus 1-2-3 in its competing spreadsheet program.
New York Mets tie their team career high 11 game win streak.
East and West Germany merge their economies.
German Democratic Republic accepts the West German Deutsche Mark as its currency.
In Victoria, Australia, helmetless bike riding becomes illegal.
East Germany accepts the Deutsche Mark as its currency, thus uniting the economies of East and West Germany.
In Masvingo, Zimbabwe, a meteorite falls harmlessly to the ground.
A stampede in a pedestrian tunnel leading to Mecca kills 1,426.
Imelda Marcos and Adnan Khashoggi found not guilty of racketeering.
A stampede inside a pedestrian tunnel leads to the deaths of 1,426 pilgrims in Mecca during hajj.
Mitch Snyder, homeless advocate, commits suicide at age 46 by hanging.
Zina Garrison upsets Steffi Graf in Wimbeldon semi-finals.
Paul Wynne, KGO-TV San Francisco reporter, dies of AIDS at age 46.
In Java, a magnitude 5.5 earthquake occurs. At least 103 people injured and about 10,300 houses, mosques and public buildings damaged or destroyed.
Martina Navratilova beats Zina Garrison for record 9th Wimbeldon title.
Greg Lemond wins his third Tour de France (90:43:20 average 23.3 mph).
West Germany defeats Argentina 1-0 for soccer's 14th FIFA World Cup at Rome, Italy.
Trailing 7-0, Milwaukee Brewers tie California Angels and then score 13 in 5th to win 20-7.
Italy beats England in soccer's FIFA World Cup consolation game.
Stefan Edberg beats Boris Becker for Wimbeldon title.
American League beats National League 2-0 in 61st All Star Game at Wrigley Field, Chicago.
New York City police arrest "Dartman" (stabbed over 50 women with darts).
Chicago White Sox player Melido Perez no-hits the New York Yankees 8-0 in a rain.
In the Hindu Kush region, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake occurs. At least 43 mountain climbers killed on Pik Lenina, USSR by an avalanche triggered by the earthquake.
Tamil Tigers kill 168 Muslims in Colombo, Sri Lanka.
Troy Dixon, rapper (Trouble T-Roy of Heavy D), dies at age 22 from a fall.
New York City's Empire State Building catches fire; no fatalities.
In Luzon, Philippine Islands, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurs. At least 1,621 people killed, more than 3,000 people injured.
In the Philippines, an earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter Scale kills over 1600.
Saddam Hussein's Revolutionary Day speech claims Kuwait stole oil from Iraq.
New York Yankees' player Deion Sanders hits an inside the park homer.
The Minnesota Twins become the first team in baseball history to turn two triple plays in the same game, against the Boston Red Sox.
The Minnesota Twins become the first team in Major League Baseball to turn two triple plays in a single game, against the Boston Red Sox. Despite their defensive prowess, the Twins lose 1-0.
Karl Menninger, psychatrist (Menninger Clinic), dies at age 96 from cancer.
Richard Nixon library opens in Yorba Linda, California.
Cincinnati Reds' player Pete Rose is sentence to five months for tax evasion.
BASF plant in Cincinnatti, Ohio, explodes in flames, one dies.
Justice William Brennan resigns from the US Supreme Court after 36 years.
Haiti asks the United States to send observers to monitor its upcoming elections.
All of Colonel Oliver North's convictions for perjury and other offenses in the Iran Contra affair are overturned by an appeals court.
A Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb explodes at the International Stock Exchange in London.
Rock band Pink Floyds' "The Wall" is performed where the Berlin Wall once stood.
Goodwill Games opens in Seattle, Washington.
Greg Lemond of US wins bicycling's third tour de France.
Nick Faldo of England wins the British Open Golf championship.
Joe Turner, jazz pianist, dies at age 82 of cardiac arrest.
The Serbian Democratic Party declares the sovereignty of the Serbs in Croatia.
George Carey, Bishop of Bath and Wells, is named as the new Archbishop of Canterbury.
US Ambassador tells Iraq US won't take sides in Iraq-Kuwait dispute.
Roseanne Barr sings the National Anthem at San Diego Padres game.
Nadezhda Ryashkina of USSR sets 10km walk woman's record (41:56.23).
Kansas City Royals' player George Brett hits for the cycle.
Comedian Roseanne Barr grabs her crotch and spits on the ground when performing the "Star-Spangled Banner" at a San Diego Padres baseball game.
US beats the Soviet Union 17-0 in baseball at the Goodwill Games.
U.S. President George H.W. Bush signs the Americans with Disabilities Act, designed to protect disabled Americans from discrimination.
Belarus declares its sovereignty, a key step toward independence from the USSR.
The last Citro?n 2CV rolls off the production line at Mangualde, Portugal.
Kim Thomas-Friedland, news anchor (FNN), dies at age 32.
Bobby Day, rocker ("Rockin' Robin"), dies of cancer at age 60.

The parliament building and a government television house in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago are stormed by the Jamaat al Muslimeen in a coup d'Ttat attempt which lasts five days. Approximately 26 to 30 people are killed and several wounded (including Prime Minister, A.N.R. Robinson, who is shot in the leg).

The Jamaat al Muslimeen stage a coup d'Ttat attempt in Trinidad and Tobago, occupying Parliament and holding Prime Minister A. N. R. Robinson and most of his Cabinet hostage for 6 days. The last Citroen 2CV rolled off the production line at Mangualde, Portugal.
Alberto Fujimori becomes president of Peru.
Alberto Fujimori becomes Constitutional President of the Republic of Peru for a first time.
Boston Red Sox set major league record with 12 doubles in a game.
George Steinbrenner is forced by Commissioner Fay Vincent to resign.
A Provisional Irish Republican Army car bomb kills British M.P. Ian Gow, a staunch unionist.
The first Saturn automobile rolls off the assembly line.
Nolan Ryan becomes the 20th major league pitcher to win 300 games.
Iraq pulls out of talks with Kuwait.
Iraq invades Kuwait, eventually leading to the Gulf War.
Radio Kuwait goes off the air, due to the Iraqi invasion.
New York Yankees' player Kevin Mass sets record with 10th home run in first 72 at bats.
For the third time in 1990 a no-hitter is broken up with two outs in the 8th inning. Doug Drabek of Pittsburgh Pirates still beats Philadelphia Phillies 11-0.
US announces commitment of Naval forces to Gulf regions.
European community proposes a boycott of Iraq.
United Nations Security Council votes 13-0 (two abstentions Cuba and Yemen) to place economic sanctions against Iraq in response to its invasion of Kuwait.
New York Yankees' player Kevin Mass sets record with 11th home run in first 86 at bats.
Gulf War: The United Nations Security Council orders a global trade embargo against Iraq in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait
At 12:34:56 (both a.m. and p.m.) the time and date by British reckoning is 12:34:56 7/8/90.
Saudi Arabia allows US troops on their soil to stop an Iraqi invasion.
Desert Shield begins - US deploys troops to Saudi Arabia.
New York Yankees' player Kevin Mass sets record with 12th home run in first 92 at bats and becomes 21st to hit a ball into third deck of Seattle's Kingdome.
At 12:34:56 (both AM and PM) the time and date by British reckoning was 12:34:56 7/8/90 i.e. 1234567890.
Baltimore Orioles pull their 10th triple play (1-6-3 versus Oakland Athletics).
Carlton Fisk ties Johnny Bench hitting 327 home runs as a catcher.
Twelve Arab leaders agree to send pan-Arab forces to protect Saudi Arabia.
American Magellan spacecraft lands on Venus.
The Magellan space probe reaches Venus.
Egypt and Morocco troops land in Saudi Arabia to prevent Iraqi invasion.
New York Yankees' player Kevin Maas is fastest to get 13 home runs (110 at bats).
Iraq President Saddam Hussein says he is ready to resolve the Gulf crisis if Israel withdraws from occupied territories.
The most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex ("Sue") is discovered near Faith, South Dakota.
Sue, the most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex, was discovered near Faith, South Dakota.
California Angels' Louis Palonia is 74th to hit an inside the park grandslam.
Denver votes for a 1 percent sales tax to pay for a baseball franchise.
Iraq orders 4000 Britons and 2500 Americans in Kuwait to Iraq.
Pearl Bailey, American broadway actress/singer, dies at age 72 from a heart attack (born 1918).
B.F. Skinner, American psychologist (Skinner Box), dies from Leukemia at age 86 (born 1904).
Leonard Bernstein conducts his final concert, ending with Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 performed by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

George Steinbrenner steps down as New York Yankees owner.
New York Yankees' player Kevin Mass is quickest to reach 15 home runs (approx 132 at bat).

East Germany and West Germany announce they will unite on October 3.

West Germany and East Germany announce that they will unite on October 3.
Saddam Hussein appears on Iraqi state television with a number of Western "guests" (actually hostages to try to prevent the Gulf War).
Northern Ireland writer Brian Keenan is released from Lebanon after being held hostage for nearly five years.
Iraqi troops surround American and other embassies in Kuwait City.
SinTad O'Connor refuses to perform at the Garden State Arts Plaza in Holmdel, New Jersey if "The Star-Spangled Banner" is played before her show, as is customary.
A judge rules that Judas Priest are not responsible for the deaths of two youths who committed suicide after listening to the band's music.
United Nations security council authorizes military action against Iraq.
Li Hui Rong of China sets the triple jump women's record (47 feet 8.5 inches).
Two slain college students found in Gainesville, Florida.
52 Americans arrive in Turkey from Iraq.
Stevie Ray Vaughan, American blues guitarist, dies in a helicopter crash at age 35 (born 1954).
WWF Summer Slam: Ultimate Warrior beats Rick Rude.
The British Broadcasting Corporation launches BBC Radio Five Live at 9am GMT with a mixture of sports, news, and children's programming. The station broadcasts for eighteen hours per day.
Force 5 tornado strikes the towns of Plainfield, Crest Hill, and Joliet, in Illinois, killing 29 people. Strongest tornado to date to strike the Chicago metropolitan area.
The Plainfield Tornado: An F5 tornado hits in Plainfield, Illinois, and Joliet, Illinois, killing 28 people.
Iraq declares Kuwait to be its newest province.
Seattle Mariners becomes first team to have father-son teammates, signing Ken Griffey to play with son Ken Griffey Jr.
Saddam Hussein declares America can't beat Iraq.
American C-5 transport plane crashes at Ramstein Air Force Base, Germany, killing 13.
Ken Griffey and Ken Griffey Jr become first father and son to play on the same baseball team (Seattle Mariners).
Tatarstan declares independence from the RSFSR.
Nat (Sweetwater) Clifton, New York Knicks player, dies at age 65 of a heart attack.
The Communist Labour Party of Turkey/Leninist is founded, following a split from the Communist Labour Party of Turkey.
Toronto Blue Jays' Dave Stieb pitches the ninth no-hitter of the season beating the Cleveland Indians 3-0, a major league record.
Transnistria declares its independence from the Moldavian SSR; however, the declaration is not recognized by any government.
Transnistria unilaterally proclaimed as Soviet republic; the Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev declares the decision null and void.
Helen Hudson sings national anthem in 26th park of year (San Diego).
David Acer, Florida dentist, dies of AIDS after infecting five patients.
Irene Dunne, American actress (winner of five Oscars), dies of heart failure at age 91 (born 1898).
Jerry Lewis' 25th Muscular Dystrophy telethon raises $44,172,186.
Iraqi President Saddam Hussein urges Arabs to rise against the West.
Ellis Island Historical Site opens on Eliis Island, New York City.
Gabriella Sabitini beats Steffi Graff to win the US Open.
Samuel Kanyon Doe, president of Liberia, captured and killed by rebels in a filmed execution.
US President George Bush and Soviet premier Mikhail Gorbachev meet in Helsinki, Finland.
Iran agrees to resume diplomatic ties with Iraq.
First time in New York Yankees' history they are completely swept in a season series, Oakland Athletics beat them 12 games to 0.
Nineteen-year old Pete Sampras beats Andre Agassi to win the US Open of tennis.
First time since 1966 that all eight grand slam tennis champions are different.
Hard Rock Cafe opens in Las Vegas, Nevada.
Seattle Mariners' Matt Young becomes 21st American League player to strike out four in one inning.
The Basilica of Our Lady of Peace in Yamoussoukro, Côte d'Ivoire ? the largest church in Africa and perhaps the world ? is consecrated by Pope John Paul II.
US President George H. W. Bush delivers a nationally televised speech in which he threatens the use of force to remove Iraqi soldiers from Kuwait.
President George H. W. Bush delivers a nationally televised speech in which he threatens the use of force to remove Iraqi soldiers from Kuwait, which Iraq had recently invaded.
US, England, France, USSR, East and West Germanys sign the Treaty on the Final Settlement With Respect to Germany in Moscow, allowing the two Germanys to merge.
The two German states and the Four Powers sign the Treaty on the Final Settlement With Respect to Germany in Moscow, paving the way for German re-unification.
Iraqi troops storm the residence of French ambassador in Kuwait.
France announces it will send 4,000 troops to the Persian Gulf.
Florida lottery goes over US$100 million.
France announces it will send 4,000 troops to the Persian Gulf.
101-year-old Sam Ackerman weds 95-year-old Eva in New Rochelle, New York.
Iraq televises an 8-minute uncensored speech from US President George Bush.
The Toronto Blue Jays set a major league single-season attendance record of 49,902.
Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia restore diplomatic ties.
A 500-pound 6-foot chocolate Hershey Kiss is displayed at 1 Times Square, New York City.
In Tokyo, Japan, the International Olympic Committee chooses Atlanta, Georgia, to host the 1996 Summer Olympic Games.
500 lb Hershey's Kiss is displayed at Times Square.
Liechtenstein becomes a member of the United Nations.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army tries to assassinate Air Chief Marshal Sir Peter Terry at his home near Stafford, England. Hit by at least nine bullets, he survives.
Saddam Hussein demands US networks broadcast his message.
Pittsburgh Pirates' player Bobby Bond is second to hit 30 home runs and steal 50 bases in a season.
Faye Vincent turns down Chicago White Sox bid to reinstate Minnie Minoso, 68, (so he can play in six decades) because it is a publicity stunt.
Oakland Athletics' Bob Welch becomes the first 25-game winner in ten years.
Andre Dawson steals his 300th base and is only player other than Willie Mays to have 300 home runs, 300 steals and 2,000 hits.
Saudi Arabia expels many Jordanian and Yemeni envoys.
In Canada, three people share a CDN$15 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
Saddam Hussein says he will destroy Israel.
US Supreme Soviet gives approval to switch to free market.
South African President F.W. de Klerk meets President George Bush in Washington, DC.
United Nations Security Council vote 14-1 to impose air embargo against Iraq.
First eight New York Yankeesl players hit safely versus Baltimore Orioles to tie record.
Saddam Hussein warns US will repeat Vietnam experience.
Oakland Athletics clinch third straight American League West title.
Motion Picture Association of America creates new NC-17 rating.
US Senate Judiciary committee approves David Souter's Supreme Court nomination.
Deposed emir of Kuwait address the United Nations General Assembly.
A gunman holds 33 people (killing 1) hostage in Berkley, California.
Marvin Gaye gets a star on Hollywood's walk of fame.
Washington National Cathedral construction is completed after 83 years.
The Dalai Lama unveils the Canadian Tribute to Human Rights in Canada's capital city of Ottawa.
The agreement is signed whereby the Allies of World War II return full sovereignty to Germany as of the agreed-to unification date of October 3.
President George Bush at the United Nations, condemns Iraq's takeover of Kuwait.
Curtis E LeMay, US Air Force General, dies at age 83.
US Senate votes 90-9 to confirm David Souter to the Supreme Court.
Radio Berlin International's final transmission (links to Deutsche Welles of West Germany); final song is "The End" by the Doors.
A Chinese airline Boeing 737-247 is hijacked; after landing at Guangzhou it crashes into two airliners on the ground, killing 132
Stefano Casiraghi, Princess Caroline of Monaco's husband, dies at age 30.

Reunification of Germany after 40 years of division. East Germany becomes the Federal states of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Brandenburg, Sachsen, Sachsen-Anhalt, Thnringen, and Berlin. Chancellor Kohl declares in a message to all nations of the world that Germany makes no territorial claims on any nation.
George Brett becomes first to lead league in batting in three decades.
Detroit Tigers' Cecil Fielder becomes 11th to hit 50 home runs (and 51st).
Re-unification of Germany. East Germany ceases to exist, and East German citizens become part of the European Community, which later became the European Union. Day of German Union.
Regional elections held in area formerly known as East Germany.
Cincinnati jury acquits art gallery of obscenity (Mapplethorpe photos).
Meir Kahane, founder of Jewish defense league, assassinated at age 58.
After one hundred and fifty years The Herald broadsheet newspaper in Melbourne, Australia, is published for the last time as a separate newspaper.
John "Cat" Thompson, basketball hall of famer, dies at age 84.
Israel begins handing out gas masks to its citizens.
In Jerusalem, Israeli police kill 17 Palestinians and wound over 100 near the Dome of the Rock mosque on the Temple Mount.
US doctors Joseph E Murray and E Donnall Thomas win Nobel Prize.
Saddam Hussein threatens to hit Israel with a new missile.
Radio stations around the world play "Imagine" honoring John Lennon.
Leonard Bernstein announces his retirement from conducting. Unbeknownst to anyone other than himself and his doctors, he is fatally ill.
US 67th manned space mission STS 41 (Discovery 11) returns from space.
Dick Jorgensen, NFL referee, dies at age 56.
Center for Urban archaeology opens in New York City South Street Seaport Museum.
Douglas Edwards, WW II correspondant, dies of cancer at age 73.
Oil hits a record US$40.42 per barrel.
Octavio Paz wins Nobel Prize for literature.
Syrian military forces invade and occupy Mount Lebanon, ousting General Michel Aoun's government. This effectively consolidates Syria's 14-year occupation of Lebanese soil.
San Francisco 49ers' Joe Montana passes for six touchdowns versus Atlanta Falcons (45-35).
Soviet Union leader Mikhail Gorbachev is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to lessen Cold War tensions and reform his nation.

Apple Computer unveils and ships the Macintosh Classic. It features an 8 MHz 68000 processor, integrated 9-inch monochrome monitor, and 3.5-inch floppy drive, for $1000. It replaces the Macintosh Plus and the Macintosh SE. Apple also releases the Macintosh LC (68020 processor), and the Macintosh IIsi (68030 processor).
Soviet Union leader Mikhail Gorbachev is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to lessen Cold War tensions and open up his nation.
Art Blakey, jazz drummer (Jazz Messengers), dies of cancer at age 71.
US forces reach 200,000 in the Persian Gulf.
Ralph Abernathy, civil rights leader, dies.
Brian Jewell, teenager in New Jersey, dies of accidental hanging while playing the part of a hanged man for a "haunted hayride".
Cincinnati Reds sweep Oakland Athletics in four games in the 87th World Series.
Antiwar protest marches begin in 20 US cities (US-Iraq).
Iraq announces release of 330 French hostages.
Italian prime minister Giulio Andreotti reveals to the Italian parliament the existence of Gladio, the Italian "stay-behind" clandestine paramilitary NATO army.
In the Hindu Kush region, Afghanistan, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurs. Eleven people killed, more than 250 injured.
Evander Hollyfield knocks out James "Buster" Douglas for heavyweight boxing title.
William Anthony Odom, North Carolina 15-year-old, accidentally hangs himself staging a gallows scene at a Halloween party.
William Paley, CEO of CBS, dies at age 89 from a heart attack.
The New Zealand general election returns the New Zealand National Party with record number of 67 seats.
In Canada, 18 people share a Canadian record CDN$19.8 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
Elliott Roosevelt, son of Franklin Roosevelt, dies at age 80.
The Supreme Soviet of Kyrgyzstan chooses Askar Akayev as the republic's first president.
Xavier Cugart, bandlander, dies from heart failure at age 90.
Supreme Soviet of Kirghiz SSR chooses Askar Akayev as republic's first president.
30 die in a 5.7 earthquake in Algeria.
William French Smith, US attorney general (1980), dies at age 73 from cancer.
Joseph Burrus, amateur magician in Fresno California, is crushed and dies after being bound in a plastic coffin and buried under seven tons of soil and concrete.
Mary Robinson defeats favourite Brian Lenihan to become the first female President of Ireland.
Rhetoric escalates as US President George Bush likens Saddam Hussein to Adolf Hitler.
Last of Margaret Thatcher's original cabinet resigns, Sir Geoffrey Howe becomes Deputy Prime Minister.
A New York City civil jury awards Sandra Miller $100 for battery after an incident in which Mike Tyson grabbed her breasts and insulted her; the jury found Tyson's behavior "not outrageous".
Iraq says it is preparing for a "dangerous war".
Secretary of State James Baker visits US troops in Saudi Arabia.
Disney's Yacht Club Resort hotel opens in Walt Disney World in Florida.
American rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the far-right Kach movement, is shot dead after a speech at a New York City hotel.
Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the far-right Kach movement, is shot dead after a speech at a New York City hotel.
Fire destroys some of Universal Studio's stages.
In southern Iran, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 22 people killed, 100 injured, 21,000 homeless and 18 villages severely damaged.
Arsenio Hall gets a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame.
Saddam Hussein fires his army chief and threatens to destroy Arabian peninsula.
100,000 additional US troops are sent to the Persian Gulf.
US President George Bush announces doubling of US forces in Persian Gulf.
Lebanon releases two French hostages (Camille Sontag and Marcel Coudari).
Akihito is enthroned as the 125th emperor of Japan.
Tim Berners-Lee publishes a more formal proposal for the World Wide Web.
Tim Berners-Lee publishes a formal proposal for the World Wide Web.
Crown Prince Akihito is formally installed as Emperor Akihito of Japan, becoming the 125th Japanese monarch.
The World Wide Web begins, as the first known Web page is written.
The first known World Wide Web page is written.
In England, Michael Heseltine contests Margaret Thatcher's leadership of the party.
Malcolm Muggeridge, WW II spy for Britain, dies at age 87.

Germany and Poland sign an agreement establishing the German-Polish border at the existing points. (There had never been West German agreement to the border along the line of the Oder and Neisse Rivers).
After German reunification, the (extended) Federal Republic of Germany and the Republic of Poland sign a treaty confirming the Oder-Neisse line as the border between Germany and Poland.
US President George Bush signs the Clean Air Act of 1990.
Producers acknowledge that Milli Vanilli, who won the 1990 "Best New Artist" Grammy Award, did not sing themselves on their album.
Space Shuttle program: Space Shuttle Atlantis launches with flight STS-38.
Manuel Noriega claims US denied him a fair trial.
Fugendake, part of the Mount Unzen volcanic complex, Nagasaki prefecture, Japan became active again and erupted.
Saddam Hussein offers to free an estimated 2,000 men held in Kuwait.
NFL New York Giants beat Detroit Lions 20-0, to run 1990 record to 10-0.
Greyhound files reorganization plan so they can be traded publicly.
Iraq announces it will free all German hostages.
Disney's Beach Club Resort hotel opens in Walt Disney World in Florida.
UK Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher fails to defeat Michael Heseltine's bid for party leadership.
US 68th manned space mission STS 38 (Atlantis 7) returns from space.
Michael Milken is sentenced to ten years for security law violations.
Signing of Declaration of "End of Cold war" in Paris, France.

Charter of Paris for a New Europe refocusses the efforts of the Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europeon post-Cold War issues. The successor to the Family Computer; the Super Famicom was released in Japan.
US President George Bush visits US troops in Saudi Arabia during Thanksgiving.
Margaret Thatcher announces her resignation as British Prime Minister.
Margaret Thatcher resigns as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The first all-female expedition (three Americans, one Japanese and twelve Russians) to the south pole set off from Antarctica on the first leg of a 70-day, 1287-kilometre ski trek.
Roald Dahl, British short story writer, dies at age 74 (born 1916).
Bo Diaz, catcher, crushed to death by a satellite dish at age 37.
The first all woman expedition to the south pole (3 Americans, 1 Japanese and 12 Russians), sets off from Antarctica on the 1st leg of a 70 day, 1287 kilometre ski trek.
NFL's New York Giants and San Francisco 49ers after winning their first 10 games both lose, Philadelphia Eagles beat Giants 31-13 and Los Angeles Rams beat 49ers 28-17.
Bill Vukovich, Indianapolis 500 driver, dies in crash at age 27.
Lech Walesa wins in Poland's first popular election.
Russia's Mikhail Gorbachev tells Iraq to get out of Kuwait.
Buffalo Bills become 6th first place NFL team to lose on same weekend.
Britain's Conservative Party chooses John Major to succeed Margaret Thatcher.
The British Conservative Party chooses John Major to succeed Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Margaret Thatcher resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom; John Major succeeds her as Party Leader and is appointed Prime Minister by Queen Elizabeth II.
Margaret Thatcher formally tenders her resignation to The Queen and leaves Downing Street for the last time. John Major is elected her successor.

The United Nations Security Council passes UN Security Council Resolution 678, authorizing military intervention in Iraq if that nation does not withdraw its forces from Kuwait and free all foreign hostages by Tuesday, January 15, 1991.

Gulf War: The United Nations Security Council passes UN Security Council Resolution 678, authorizing military intervention in Iraq if that nation did not withdraw its forces from Kuwait and free all foreign hostages by January 15, 1991.
US President George Bush proposes US-Iraq meeting to avoid war.
Jan H de Groot, Dutch co-founder (Vrij Nederland), dies.
New York Knicks' Patrick Ewing scores 50 points beating Charlotte Hornets 113-96.
Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia hold their first joint session.
Iraq accepts US President Bush's offer for talks.
Hissene HabrT of Chad flees to Cameroon.

132 feet below the English Channel, workers drill an opening through a wall of rock, connecting the two ends of an underwater tunnel linking Great Britain with the European mainland for the first time in more than 8,000 years.
56th Heisman Trophy Award: Ty Detmer, Brigham Young (quarterback).
Channel Tunnel sections started from the United Kingdom and France meet 40 meters beneath the seabed.
Beth Daniel/Davis Love win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
79th Davis Cup: USA beats Australia in Saint Petersburg (3-2).
First parliamentary election in newly reunified Germany: a coalition led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
A coalition led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl wins the first free all-German elections since 1932.

At Detroit Metropolitan Airport, Northwest Airlines Flight 1482 (a McDonnell Douglas DC-9) collides with Northwest Airlines Flight 299 (a Boeing 727) on the runway, killing 8 passengers and 4 crewmembers on Flight 1482.
Mary Robinson is elected the first female President of Ireland.
National League batting champion Willie McGee signs as a free agent with San Francisco Giants.
At Detroit Metropolitan Airport, Northwest Airlines Flight 1482 collides with Northwest Airlines Flight 299 on the runway, killing 8 passengers and 4 crew members aboard flight 1482.
Government of Pakistan formed National Highway Authority.
Due to Persian Gulf crisis gas hits $1.60 per gallon price in New York City, New York.
Iraq announces it will release all 3,300 Soviet hostages.
Salman Rushdie, author (ordered to death by Iran for blasphemy), appears in public for first time in two years.
Toronto Blue Jays trade Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez to San Diego Padres for Roberto Alomar and Joe Carter.
President Hossain Mohammad Ershad of Bangladesh is forced to resign following massive protests.
Shoeless Joe Jackson's signature is sold for $23,100.
Saddam anounces release of all foreign hostages.
Tunku Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of Malaysia (1957-70), dies.
NHL grants conditional membership to Tampa Bay Lightning.
Iraqi parliament endorses Saddam's decision to free hostages.
Delecta "Dee" Clark, US singer ("Raindrops"), dies at age 52.
Cleveland Indians agree to a lease new ballpark in Gateway (Jacobs Field).
Slobodan Milo_evic becomes President of Serbia.
Houston Oilers (58) scores most points against Cleveland Browns (14).
NFL New York Giants' Otis Anderson becomes 8th to rush for 10,000th yard.
Gunda Niemann skates ladies world record 3k ladies (4:10.80).
Lech Walesa wins presidential election in Poland.
Betsy King wins Itoman LPGA World Match Play Golf Championship.
Lech Wa??sa becomes the first directly elected president of Poland.
Armand Hammer, CEO (Occidental Petroleum), dies at age 92.
Hindu-Muslim rebellion in Hyderabad-Aligargh, India, 140 die.
Fernand J Collin, Belgian economist/banker, dies at age 92.
Thirteen die in 83-vehicle accident in Chattanooga, Tennessee (I-75), due to fog.
US ambassador to Kuwait, Nathaniel Howell, leaves Kuwait.
US accuses Iraq of dragging its feet on dates for talks.
Pakistan became the 37th country in the world to send an expedition to Antarctica.
Alice Marble, California tennis star, dies at age 77.
President De Klerk of South Africa meets with Nelson Mandela to talk of end of apartheid.
In Sicily, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs. At least 19 people killed, about 200 injured, 2,500 homeless.
Johannes von Thurn und Taxis, prince in Germany, dies at age 64.
Rocker Rod Stewart marries supermodel Rachel Hunter.
Reverend Jean-Betrand Aristide is elected President of Haiti, ending three decades of military rule.
National League announces Buffalo, Denver, Miami, Orlando, Tampa-St Petersburg, and Washington DC as six finalist for 1993 expansion (Miami and Denver win).
Pentagon warns Saddam Hussein that US air power is ready to attack on January 15.
Robert F X Sillerman purchases WAFL New York-New Jersey Knights for $11 million.
Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze resigns.
Steve and Mark Waugh complete 464 partnership for New South Wales versus Western Australia.
Israeli ferry capsizes killing 21 US servicemen.
Lech Walesa sworn in as Poland's first popularly elected president.
Iraq announces it will never give up Kuwait.
Lech Wa??sa is sworn in as President of Poland.
Slovenians vote to secede from Yugoslavia.
Frank King, cricket player (West Indies fast bowler played 14 Tests 1953-56), dies.
History of Slovenia: 88% of Slovenia's population vote for independence from Yugoslavia in a referendum.
Saddam Hussein says Israel will be Iraq's first target.
Montreal Expos trade Tim Raines to Chicago White Sox for Ivan Calderon and Barry Jones.
The first successful communication between a client and server via the Internet is established.
Due to a financial dispute between the club owners, the Fort Myers Sun Sox franchise collapses causing the Senior Professional Association League to fold in the middle of its second season.
Reggie Williams becomes first general manager of WLAF's New York-New Jersey Knights.
Nancy Cruznan, accident victim/right-to-die case, dies at age 33.
Ed van der Elsken, Dutch photographer (Sweet Life), dies at age 65.
Two die in a New York City subway accident.
Blockbuster Bowl 1: Florida State beats Pennsylvania State, 24-17.
Olympic gymnast Mary Lou Retton weds Shannon Kelley.
George Allen, US football coach (Los Angeles Rams, Washington Redskins), dies.
Russian Garry Kasparov holds his title by winning the World Chess Championship match against his countryman Anatoly Karpov.
United Somali Congress seizes Presidential Palace.
Iraq begins a military draft of 17-year-olds.
The Sci-Fi Channel on cable TV begins transmitting.
Vasily Grigoryevich Lazarev, cosmonaut (Soyuz 12, 18A), dies at age 62.
Garry Kasparov holds his title by winning the World Chess Championship match against his countryman Anatoly Karpov.
The Colorado Buffaloes claim US college football's national championship with a 10-9 win over Notre Dame in the 1991 Orange Bowl.
5 percent sales tax on consumer goods and services goes into effect in USSR.
Iraq rejects peace proposal from Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.
Linus Torvalds buys the computer which got Linux started.
Sharon Pratt Dixon is sworn in as mayor of Washington, DC becoming the first African American woman to lead a city of that size and importance.
Colorado wins its first AP national title poll.
Gulf War: The British government announces the expulsion of 75 Iraqis from the country.
Hockey Hall of Famer Wayne Gretzky scores his 700th goal.
Israel reopens consulate in USSR after 23 years.
Los Angeles Kings' Wayne Gretzky scores his 700th goal, against New York Islanders.
The United Nations Security Council votes unanimously to condemn Israel's treatment of the Palestinians.
Jan Krzystof Bielecki becomes premier of Poland.
Fu Mingxia, 12, of China wins World Swimming Championships gold medal.
Leo N Wright, US saxophonist ("I Left My Heart in San Francisco"), dies at age 57.
Edwin Jongejans of Netherlands wins 1-metre springboard diving title.
Kevin Bradshaw of US International scores NCAA Division 1 record 72 points.
Vasko Popa, Serbian WWII-partisan/poet (Sporedno Nebo), dies at age 68 (born 1922).
Qian Hong swims female world record 50m butterfly (27.30 seconds).
Jorge Serrano El?as elected President of Guatemala.
Joe Hicks, baseball coach, dies of cancer at age 64.
Soviet paratroopers sent to Baltic Republics.
Gaylord Perry, Ferguson Jenkins, and Rod Carew elected to Baseball Hall of Fame.
Steve Clark, English guitarist (Def Leppard - "Hysteria"), dies at age 30 (born 1960).
Tamﬂs Darnyi swims world record 400m medley (4:12.36).
American James Baker and Iraqi Terak Aziz meet in Geneva, Switzerland; talks fail to defuse the Persian Gulf crisis.
Dean Smith of North Carolina is 6th to win 700 career coaching basketball games.
Baseball officially bans Pete Rose from being elected to Hall of Fame.
The Soviets storm Vilnius to stop Lithuanian independence.
Japan ends routine fingerprinting of all adult ethnic Koreans.
US Congress begins debate on Persian Gulf crisis.
Jason Christmas dies of gunshot wound during robbery in New York at age 49.
Ric Flair wins NWA/WCW wrestling title.
Soviet forces storm buildings in Vilnius to block Lithuania independence.
Ben Johnson runs first race after being stripped of his 1988 Olympic Gold medal for steroid use; he finishes second.
US Congress empowers President George H.W. Bush to order attack on Iraq.
Largest crowd to watch Atlantic Coast Womens Basketball game (11,520).
Melvin Stewart swims world record 200 metre butterfly (1 55.69).
Keye Luke, actor (Charlie Chan's No 1 Son), dies after a stroke at age 86.
US Congress gives President George H.W. Bush authority to use military force to liberate Kuwait.
Persian Gulf War: An act of the U.S. Congress authorizes the use of military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
Soviet troops assault the Vilnius TV tower in Lithuania and kill 14 unarmed civilians; many more are injured.
United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar meets with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, Iraq.
A fight and stampede at a pre-season exhibition match between South African football teams Chiefs and Pirates in the town of Orkney near Johannesburg, South Africa leaves 42 dead.
President Mario Soares of Portugal re-elected.
Phil Mickelson wins PGA Northern Telecom Golf Open.
12th ACE Cable Awards: HBO wins 25 awards.
Soviet Union military troops attack Lithuanian independence supporters in Vilnius.
Valentin Pavlov become new premier of USSR.
Jorge Serrano El?as sworn in as President of Guatemala.
Three Palestinian Liberation Organization guerilla chiefs are assassinated in Tunis, including Sallah Kharaf [Abu Iyad], co-founder of Al-Fatah.

Sean Lennon's remake of his father's "Give Peace A Chance" is released to coincide with the United Nation's midnight deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The lyrics were updated to reflect concerns of the 1990's.
Australia beats New Zealand 2-0 to win the World Series Cup.
The United Nations deadline for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from occupied Kuwait expires, preparing the way for the start of Operation Desert Storm.
The United Nations deadline for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from occupied Kuwait expires, preparing the way for the start of Operation Desert Storm.
U.S. serial killer Aileen Wuornos confesses to the murders of six men.
Gulf War: United States begins bombing Iraq in Operation Desert Storm, which began following Operation Desert Shield .
Harald V of Norway becomes king on the death of his father.
Operation Desert Storm begins - US and 27 allies attack Iraq for occupying Kuwait.
Helmut Kohl is formally elected chancellor of united Germany by the Bundestag. He receives 378 yes votes, 257 no votes and 9 abstain.
Mountie Jacques Rougeau beats Hart for WWF intercontinental title.
Harald V becomes King of Norway on the death of his father, Olav V.
Gulf War: Operation Desert Storm began early in the morning. Iraq fires 8 Scud missiles into Israel in an unsuccessful bid to provoke Israeli retaliation.
Iraq fires eight SCUD missiles on Israel; first US pilot shot down (Jeffrey Zahn).
Hamilton Fish, congressman (New York), dies at age 102.
Longest tennis match at the Australian Open, Boris Becker beats Italy's Omar Camporese in 5 hours and 11 minutes.
Eastern Airlines goes out of business after 62 years due to financial problems.
WLAF's New York Knights become New York-New Jersey Knights.
US acknowledges Central Intelligence Agency and US Army paid Manuel Noriega $320,000 over his career.
Eastern Air Lines shuts down after 62 years citing financial problems.
Sergeant Slaughter defeats Ultimate Warrior for WWF championship belt.
Jumbo Tsuruta beats Stan Hansen to win All Japan Triple Crown title.
The Party of the Alliance of Youth, Workers and Farmers of Angola is founded in Luanda, Angola.
42nd NHL All Star Game: Campbell beats Wales 11-5 in Chicago, Illinois.
Twenty-nine people are injured by a SCUD attack on Tel Aviv, Israel.
Matt Barr's field goal with no time left gives New York Giants 15-13 victory over defending champions San Francisco 49ers, for NFC title.
Iraq parades captured Allied airmen on TV.
US Patriot missiles begins shooting down Iraqi missiles.
Bill Riordon, US tennis promoter (Jimmy Connors), dies.
Buffalo Bills beat Los Angeles Raiders 51-3 for AFC title.
Jane Geddes wins LPGA Jamaica Golf Classic.
Sudan's government imposes Islamic law nationwide, worsening the civil war between the country's Muslim north and Christian south.
Richard Bolling, American politician (Representative-Democrat-Missouri)/US civil-rights leader, dies at age 74.
CBS News correspondent Bob Simon captured by Iraqis in Persian Gulf.
Howard "Red" Grange, football's galloping ghost, dies at age 87.
Three SCUDs and one Patriot missile hit Ramat Gan in Israel, injuring 96 people. Three elderly people die of heart attacks.
World's largest oil spill, caused by embattled Iraqi forces in Kuwait.

Eight-man British SAS squad enters Iraq behind enemy lines to destroy Scud missiles. The mission fails and many are captured and tortured and some killed. Eight SAS troopers manage to kill 200 Iraqi soldiers.
The New York Giants defeat the San Francisco 49ers, 15-13, in San Francisco. The Giants win despite not scoring a touchdown, prevailing on five field goals by Matt Bahr.
Mark Waugh scores ton in first Test Cricket innings, versus England Adelaide.
Manuel Noriega is given access to assets frozen by US government.
Brett Hull is third NHL player to score 50 goals in less than 50 games (49).
Johnny van Doorn, Dutch writer/poet, dies at age 46.
New York Lotto pays US$90 million to nine winners (numbers are 5-15-30-35-46-50).
During the final phase of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, an estimated 908 million litres of oil are spilled from terminals, tankers, and oil wells.
Somalia President Siad Barre flees his compound in Mogadishu.
Jan Stenerud becomes first pure placekicker to make NFL Hall of Fame.
Houston Rockets' guard Vernon Maxwell is fourth NBA player to score 30 points in a quarter.
Alfaro Vive guerrilla group of Ecuador gives arms to Catholic church.

USSR launches two cosmonauts to MIR space station.
France performs nuclear test at Muruora Island.

Soviet parliament approves law allowing citizens to travel abroad.

Baseball pitcher Jeff Reardon gains his 300th career save.

Authorised by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Operation Solomon commences.

In Thailand, an Austrian Lauda Air Boeing 767 crashes near Bangkok, killing all 223 people on-board.
Betsy King wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Zviad Gamsakhurdia becomes the first democratically elected President of the Republic of Georgia in the post-Soviet era.
Lauda Air Flight 004 explodes over rural Thailand, killing 223.

Ethel Lois Payne, journalist (Chicago Defender), dies at age 79.
The Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the Minnesota North Stars 8-0 in Game 6 to win their first Stanley Cup in franchise history.
The capital city of Addis Ababa, falls to the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, ending both the Derg regime in Ethiopia and the Ethiopian Civil War.

64th US National Spelling Bee: Joanne Lagatta wins spelling "antipyretic".

Oldest bride - Minnie Munro, 102, weds Dudley Reid, 83, in Australia.
Sides in Angola sign a treaty ending 16-year civil war.
H N "Swanie" Swanson, literary agent, dies at age 91 from a stroke.

At the Consumer Electronics Show, Nintendo announces the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (Super NES). The 16-bit system will use new game cartridges, and compact discs using a CD-ROM drive developed with Philips N.V.
In Japan, Mount Unzen erupts, killing 43 people as a result of pyroclastic flow.
Harry Glicken, volcanologist, killed by Mount Unzen Volcano in Japan.
Thomas C Lasorda, artist/son of Los Angeles Dodgers' manager, dies of pneumonia at age 33.
Mount Unzen erupts in Japan in Kyushu killing 43 people, all of them either researchers or journalists.
The United Kingdom's Conservative government announces that some British regiments would disappear or be merged into others?the largest armed forces cuts in almost twenty years.
Colo-Colo becomes the first Chilean soccer team to win the Copa Libertadores de AmTrica.
Sylvia Porter, economist/author, dies at age 77.
Stan Getz, jazz saxophonist (Girl from Impanima), dies at age 64.
Mount Pinatubo explodes generating an ash column 7 km (4.5 miles) high.
Former New York Jets' Mark Gastineau wins first pro boxing fight in 12 seconds.
Mary Bacon, jockey, dying of cancer, commits suicide by gun at age 43.
Monica Seles beats Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, 6-3, 6-4 for French Open.
World Bowl-World League of American Football first championship.
Jim Courier beats Andre Agassi for the French Open.

A major collapse of ground at the Emaswati Colliery in Swaziland traps 26 miners 65m below the surface. The men have access to a safe refuge chamber and are all rescued by a drill hole 30 hours after the rescue unit was first alerted.
The congress of the Italian party Proletarian Democracy decides to merge with the Communist Refoundation Party.
Mother of All Parades-New York City welcomes Desert Storm troops.
In what was dubbed "The Mother of All Parades," New York City hosts a parade welcoming back troops from Operation Desert Storm.
Boris Yeltsin is elected President of Russia, the largest and most populous of the fifteen Soviet republics.
The Chicago Bulls win their first NBA championship by defeating the Los Angeles Lakers in the best-of-7 series 4 games to 1.
Russians elect Boris Yeltsin as the president of their republic.
NHL owners present contract to players (leads to April 1, 1992 strike).
A spectator is killed by lightning at the U.S. Open.
Leroy Burrell of USA sets the 100m record (9.90) in New York City.
Marshall Ledbetter occupies the Florida State Capitol.

Philippines volcano Mount Pinatubo errupts for the first time in 600 years. In Luzon, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake is felt. This is the largest of a series of earthquakes associated with the eruption. At least 137 people are killed and extensive damage is caused in Zambales Province by the eruptions.
Otis Nixon steals National League record six bases in one day.
With three runs in the 9th, Baltimore Orioles end Minnesota Twins' 15-game win streak 6-5.
Minnesota Twins win a team record 15 games in a row.
U.S. President Zachary Taylor is exhumed to discover whether or not his death was caused by arsenic poisoning, instead of acute gastrointestinal illness; no trace of arsenic is found.
The South African Parliament repeals the Population Registration Act, which had required racial classification of all South Africans at birth.
Apartheid: The South African Parliament repeals the Population Registration Act, which had required all racial classification of all South Africans at birth.
New York Yankees' pitchers pick-off three Toronto Blue Jays.
San Francisco Giants' pitcher Dave Dravecky's cancerous left arm is amputated.
Decision of the Bundestag (in Bonn) that Berlin should become the German capital.
German parliament decides to move the capital from Bonn back to Berlin.
New York Islanders Denis Potvan and Michael Bossy inducted into NHL Hall of Fame.
Underwater volcano, Mount Didicas, erupts in Phillipines.

(to June 28) U.N. inspection teams attempt to intercept Iraqi vehicles carrying nuclear related equipment. Iraqi soldiers fire warning shots in the air to prevent inspectors from approaching the vehicles.
Slovenia and Croatia declare independence from Yugoslavia.
Croatia and Slovenia declare their independence from Yugoslavia.
Slovenia, after declaring independence two days previous, is invaded by Yugoslav troops, tanks, and aircraft, starting the Ten-Day War.
In Sierra Madre, California, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs.
In Canada, one person wins a Canadian record (for a single winner) CDN$13.9 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
Portugal wins the FIFA U-20 World Cup defeating Brazil on the final by 4-2, after penalty shoot out, in Lisbon, Portugal.
The Warsaw Pact is officially dissolved at a meeting in Prague.
The Warsaw Pact is officially dissolved at a meeting in Prague.
In Timor, a magnitude 6.9 earthquake occurs. Two events about 2.5 seconds apart. Twenty-three people killed, 181 injured, at least 5,400 left homeless and about 1,150 buildings destroyed.
In a unanimous vote, final approval is given by baseball owners for the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins to join the National League in 1993.
The Brioni Agreement ends the 10-day war in Slovenia.
Michael Stich beats Boris Becker for Wimbeldon championship.
Yugoslav Wars: Brioni Agreement ended ten-day independence war in Slovenia against the rest of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
South Africa is reintroduced into the Olympic movement after 30 years of exclusion.
International Human Rights Federation cites human rights violations committed by police and military personnel during Oka crisis in Quebec, Canada.
Boris Yeltsin begins his five-year term as the first elected president of Russia.
Gerome Ragal, author (Hair), dies at age 48 of cancer.
Boris Yeltsin begins his 5-year term as the first elected President of Russia.
A total solar eclipse is seen in Hawaii and Mexico.
A Nationair DC-8 crashed during an emergency landing at Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, killing 261. The Canadian charter was ferrying Hajj pilgrims on behalf of Nigeria Airways.
Frank Rizzo, American politician (Mayor-Democrat-Philadelphia, 1972-80), dies from a heart attack at age 70.
In Romania, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs. Felt strongly in western Romania and in northwestern Bulgaria. Also felt in southeastern Hungary and in parts of Yugoslavia.
With New York Yankees victory, 10 of 14 American League teams are at .500 or better.
The United States Department of Defense begins airlifting supplies to Albania
Serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer is arrested after the remains of 11 men and boys are found in his Milwaukee, Wisconsin apartment. Dahmer confesses to killing 17 males in 1978.
Serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer is arrested after the remains of 11 men and boys are found in his Milwaukee apartment.
The government of India announces its New Industrial Policy, marking the start of India's economic reforms.
Isaac Bashevis Singer, Polish-born Nobel Prize winning Yiddish author, dies at age 87.

The US Treasury and the Federal Reserve introduce two anti-counterfeiting features to 1990 $100 Federal Reserve Notes: a clear polyester security thread with "USA100" printed repeatedly on it, and continuous microprinting of "UNITED STATES OF AMERICA" around the portrait of Benjamin Franklin.
Montreal Expos' Mark Gardner no hits Los Angeles Dodgers for 9 innings, but loses in 10th.
Sonic the Hedgehog is released for the Sega Megadrive in Japan.
Paul Reubens, better known as Pee Wee Herman, is arrested for allegedly exposing himself at a Sarasota, Florida adult theatre.
Buffalo Bills beat Philadelphia Eagles, 17-13 in American Bowl football in Wembley.
Montreal Expos' Dennis Martinez pitches baseball's 15th perfect game versus (Los Angeles Dodgers).
Miguel Indurain of Spain wins the Tour de France bicycle race.
The Russian Federation and Lithuania sign a friendship treaty recognizing Lithuania as a sovereign state.
First Sunday Night game at Shea Stadium (New York Mets beat Chicago Cubs 6-0).
Boston Red Sox player Carlos Quintana is 11th to get six RBIs in an inning (third).
Pan Am games open in Havana, Cuba.
The Greek cruise ship Oceanos sinks off the coast of South Africa.
Sergei Bubka of USSR sets pole vault record (20.25 inches) in Malm˜, Sweden.
Soichiro Hondo, CEO and founder (Honda), dies of liver cancer at age 84.
Paul Brown, American NFL founder and coach (Cleveland Browns, Cincinnati Bengals), dies at age 82 (born 1908).
Doi Takako, chair of the Social Democratic Party (Japan), becomes Japan's first female speaker of the House of Representatives.
Tim Berners-Lee releases files describing his idea for the World Wide Web.
Shapour Bakhtiar, former prime minister of Iran, is assassinated.
Court rules Manuel Noriega may access some secret US documents.
US sets 400m relay record at 37.67 seconds.
The World Wide Web debuts as a publicly available service on the Internet.
Shotzie, Cincinnati Reds' dog mascot, dies at age 9.
Shite Muslims release British hostage John McCarthy.
The Warsaw radio mast, the tallest construction ever built, collapses.

Jack Ryan, inventor (Barbie Doll, Hot Wheels), dies at age 65.

750,000 attend Paul Simon's free concert in Central Park, New York.

Collapse of the Soviet Union: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is put under house arrest while on holiday in the town of Foros, Crimea.

Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is put under house arrest while vacationing in the Crimea during a coup. The attempted coup, led by Vice President Gennady Yanayev and seven hard-liners, collapses in less than 72 hours.
Soviet Union President Mikhail Gorbachev is overthrown by a coup. This leads to the fall of the Soviet Union
More than 100,000 people rally outside the Soviet Union's parliament building protesting the coup that deposed President Mikhail Gorbachev.
Estonia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
Lenore Strunsky Gershwin, widow of Ira Gershwin, dies at age 90.

Estonia reclaimed its independence and seceded from the Soviet Union. Estonia had been occupied by the Soviets for more than 50 years.

A drunk motorman speeds into the Union Square station on the No. 4 line in New York City. The train derails on the curve, killing six passengers and injuring dozens.
Maronite general Michel Aoun leaves Lebanon via a French ship into exile.

Joe Coleman's third 100 RBI season in a row with three teams (Cleveland Indians, San Diego Padres, and Toronto Blue Jays).

General elections are held for Swedish Parliament. Carl Bildt is elected new Prime Minister, the country's first Conservative leader in 63 years.

(to September 21) In Sandy, Utah several patients are held hostage and a nurse is killed in the Alta View Hospital hostage incident.

IAEA inspectors discover files on Iraq's hidden nuclear weapons program. Iraqi officials confiscate documents from UN weapons inspectors, refusing to allow them to leave the site without turning over other documents.
Armenia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
Armenia is granted independence from Soviet Union.
The Huntington Library at California University makes the Dead Sea Scrolls available to the public for the first time.

Leonard C Odell, wrote 7,000 Burma Shave poems, dies at age 83.

The Croatian Parliament cuts all remaining ties with Yugoslavia.

Ex-postal worker Joseph Harris kills four postal workers.

The United Nations Security Council passes Resolution 715, which demands that Iraq "accept unconditionally the inspectors and all other personnel designated by the Special Commission". Iraq rejects the resolution, calling it "unlawful".
Chip Beck ties PGA lowest 18 hole score of 59.
In Russia, the KGB is replaced by the SVR.

At a government auction near the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, Roger Judski buys a 1969 Corvette with ZL-1 engine, for US$300,000. This is the only documented Corvette ZL-1 in existence, one of two believed to have been built.
Askar Akayev, previously chosen President of Kyrgyzstan by its Supreme Soviet, is confirmed president in an uncontested poll.

Bulgarian right wing opposition celebrates the end of the rule of the Bulgarian Communist Party.
United States Senate votes 52-48 to confirm Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court of the United States.

Following a bitter confirmation hearing that involved allegations of sexual misconduct, the United States Senate votes to confirm Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court of the United States by one of the closest margins ever, 52-48.
George Jo Hennard, age 35, kills 23 and himself and wounds 20 in Killeen, Texas.

The Harare Declaration lays down the membership criteria for the Commonwealth of Nations.

Dr Jack Kevorkian's suicide machine kills two women.
History of Slovenia: Three months after the end of the Ten-Day War, the last soldier of the Yugoslav People's Army leaves the territory of the Republic of Slovenia.

The Euro Disney Resort, featuring the Euro Disneyland park, opens in Marne-la-VallTe, France, east of Paris. The US$4 billion complex has six hotels with 5200 rooms, and is staffed by 14,000 "cast members". Euro Disneyland park has 29 attractions in five themed lands: Adventureland, Discoveryland, Fantasyland, Festival Disney, Frontierland, and Main Street. 500,000 visitors were expected, but only 50,000 are admitted on opening day.
