Florence Randall, model/designer (Bill Blass), dies at age 54 of cancer.
Start of South Africa's first Test Cricket since 1970 (versus West Indies Bridgetown).
General Abdul Rashid Dostum revolted against President Mohammad Najibullah of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan and allied with Ahmed Shah Massoud to capture Kabul.
Dottie Mochrie wins LPGA Sega Women's Golf Championship.
Robert F Clayton, drummer (Jody Grind), dies at age 26 in a car crash.
Robert Paul Haynes, bassist (Jody Grind), dies at age 26 in a car crash.
Madonna signs $60-million deal with Time Warner.
96th Boston Marathon won by Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya in 2:08:14.
Seville's six-month Universal Exhibition opens, called Seville Expo 1992, in the city of Seville, Spain.
21st Boston Women's Marathon won by Olga Markova of Russia in 2:23:43.
Johnny Shines Delta, blues singer/guitarist, dies at age 76.
The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert, held at Wembley Stadium in London, England, is televised live to over one billion people and raises millions of dollars for AIDS research.
Vladimir Cyrillovitch, Grand Duke/Russian pretender to the throne, dies at age 74 (born 1917).

The death of Grand Duke Vladimir Cyrillovich of Russia results in a succession dispute between Nicholas Romanov, Prince of Russia and Vladimir's daughter Maria for the leadership of the Imperial Family of Russia.
Robert Harris, murderer, executed in California's gas chamber at age 39.
Mobil Oil tug with 12,000 gallons of oil run aground in Arthur Kill.
Joop [Joseph] van Santen, Dutch first Chamber member (CPN), dies.
Plane crash at Perris Valley Airport, California, kills 16 parachutists.
Fuel that has leaked into a sewer explodes in Guadalajara, Mexico; 215 are killed, 1500 injured.
Billy Wayne White, murderer, executed in Texas at age 34.
1992 explosion in Guadalajara, Mexico ; 206 people were killed, nearly 500 injured and 15,000 were left homeless
Deron Johnson, 1965 National League run leader, dies of cancer at age 53.
Marion Berry (former mayor of Washington DC) is released from prison.
McDonald's opens its first fast-food restaurant in China.
Satyajit Ray, Indian film director (Distant Thunder/Agantuk), dies at age 70 (born 1921).
Victoria Kellem Lederman, model, dies of amyloidosis at age 52.
George Steinbrenner drops his lawsuits against baseball.
Firestone World Bowling Tournament of Champions won by Marc McDowell.
Brian Macleod, Canadian musician, dies of cancer at age 39.
In Cape Mendocino, California, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs.
Yutaka Ozaki, Japanese rock artist, dies at age 26 of pulmonary edema (born 1965).
Dany [Dani?l S] Tuijnman, Dutch minister of traffic and water, dies at age 77.
Maggie Will wins LPGA Sara Lee Golf Classic.
Offshore Cape Mendocino, California, magnitude 6.5 and 6.7 earthquakes occur, 3.5 hours apart. Felt throughout much of northern California and southern Oregon.
Betty Boothroyd is elected Speaker of the British House of Commons.
New York Mets trade David Cone to Toronto Blue Jays for Jeff Kent.
New York Jets finish perfect 5-0 pre-season for first time.
The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is proclaimed, comprising of Serbia and Montenegro.

The two remaining countries of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia - the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Montenegro - form a new state, named the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, bringing to an end the union of Serbs, Croats, Slovenes, Montenegrins, Bosnian Muslims and Macedonians that existed from 1918 (with the exception of the period during World War II).
Milwaukee Brewers beat Toronto Blue Jays 22-2 with American League record 31 hits in 9 innings.
Francis Bacon, Irish/British abstract painter, dies at age 82 (born 1909).
Italian President Francesco Cossiga formally resigns.
27th Academy of Country Music Awards: Garth Brooks wins.

In Simi Valley, California, the Los Angeles police officers accused of excessive force in their severe beating of Rodney King, are found "not guilty". The verdict results in several days of riots in Los Angeles and smaller riots around the country, leading to 53 deaths and US$1 billion in damage.

1992 Los Angeles riots: Riots in Los Angeles, California, follow the acquittal of police officers charged with excessive force in the beating of Rodney King. Over the next three days 54 people are killed and hundreds of buildings are destroyed.
Daan van Driel, Dutch cartoonist/WWII resistance fighter (Trouw), dies.
Eric Houston kills four in a California high school where he failed history four years prior.
Los Angeles Dodgers postpone three games due to racial riots resulting from the Rodney King incident.
New York Rangers win their first ever 7th game of a playoff (vs New Jersey Devils).
Philip Dunne, screenwriter, dies of cancer at age 84.
Yugoslav Army seizes Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic.
Wilbur Mills, American politician (Representative-Democrat-Arkansas)/involved with Fanne Foxe, dies at age 82.
Margareth Wallmann, Austrian opera director, dies at age 88.
Lee Salk, baby doctor/author, dies of cardiac arrest at age 65.
118th Kentucky Derby: Pat Day aboard Lil E Tee wins in 2:03.
Elizabeth Lennox, radio singer, dies of heart seizure at age 98.
Danielle Ammaccapane wins LPGA Centel Golf Classic.
Sandra Palmer wins LPGA Centel Senior Golf Challenge.
Ohio Glory wins first WLAF game (after six losses), beat Frankfurt 20-17.
New York Mets' player Eddie Murray is 24th to hit 400 homeruns.
Baltimore Orioles' pitcher Gregg Olson, 25, is youngest to record 100 saves.
George Murphy, American politician (Senator-Republican-California, 1965-71)/actor, dies of Leukemia at age 89.
Henri Guillemin, French historian, dies at age 89.
Vitali Andreyevich Grishchenko, Russian cosmonaut, dies at age 50.
Russian leaders in Crimea declare their separation from Ukraine as a new republic.

Alabama ratifies a 202-year-old proposed amendment to the United States Constitution making the 27th Amendment law. This amendment bars the U.S. Congress from giving itself a midterm or retroactive pay raise.
Stefano d'Arrigo, Sicilian writer, dies at age 72.
Wolfenstein 3D is released, the first-ever first-person shooter computer game.
Marlene Dietrich, born Marie von Losch, actress, dies in Paris, France at age 90 (born 1901 in Berlin, Germany).
New York Mets' Anthony Young begins losing streak of at least 26 games.
Werder Bremen wins 32nd Europe Cup II.
Jilly Rizzo, restauranteur/friend of Frank Sinatra, dies in car at age 75.
Jockey Angel Cordero retires after winning over 7,000 horse races.
Five New York City cops arrested in Hauppauge Long Island for selling cocaine.
Space Shuttle Endeavour is launched on its maiden voyage.
Michigan ratifies a 203-year-old proposed amendment to the United States Constitution making the 27th Amendment law. This amendment bars the U.S. Congress from giving itself a mid-term pay raise.
Three employees at a McDonald's Restaurant in Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada, are brutally murdered and a fourth permanently disabled after a botched robbery. It is the first fast-food murder in Canada.
Addeke H Boerma, director-general (FAO), dies at age 80.
Gul Mahomed, cricket player (8 Tests for India and one for Pakistan), dies.
Mike Tyrell [Red Baron], British air acrobat, dies in an accident.
Michelle McLean, 19, of Namibia, crowned 41st Miss Universe.
America's Cup finals begin in San Diego, California.
After trailing 9-0, Saint Louis Cardinals beat Atlanta Braves 12-11.
At 5:18 a.m. ADT The Westray Mine in Plymouth, Nova Scotia experiences a methane explosion killing all 26 miners who were working.
Jennifer Wyatt wins LPGA Crestar-Fresh Farm Golf Classic.
Sweden wins the Ice Hockey World Championships in Prague, Czechoslovakia.
Sylvia Sims, singer ("Flower Drum Song"), dies of a heart attack at age 74.
Joan Merrill, vocalist, dies of a stroke at age 74.
Bible Land Museum opens in Jerusalem, Israel.
Carlos Herrera, drink inventor (Margarita), dies at age 90.
Elizabeth McDonald, inventor (Spic and Span), dies at age 98.
First Belgian woman (Ingrid Baeyens) to ascend Mount Everest.
Joe Burke, president (Kansas City Royals), dies at age 68.
Three astronauts simultaneous walk in space for the first time.
Concrete foundation for ballpark at Gateway (Jacobs Field) is poured.
Floyd Arceneaux, trumpeter, dies at age 58.
Falun Gong introduced by Li Hongzhi.
WIBC Bowling Queens won by Cindy Coburn-Carroll.
Lyle Alzado, NFL defense linesman (Oakland Raiders), dies of cancer at age 43.
Bruce Hopkins, performer/director, dies at age 44.
Colombo 1992 World's Fair opens in Genoa, Italy.
New York department store chain Alexanders announces closing of all 11 stores.
In Uzbekistan, a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occurs. Three people killed, 5,500 houses completely destroyed and more than 4,000 houses damaged.
Robert Morris Page, US physicist (radar), dies at age 88.
US polls show presidential candidates Ross Perot, George Bush, and Bill Clinton could be in a deadlock.
118th Preakness: Chris McCarron aboard Pine Bluff wins in 1:55.6.
STS-49: Space Shuttle Endeavour lands safely after a successful maiden voyage.
The Toronto Blue Jays reach the one-million mark in season attendance sooner than any baseball team in major league history.
Leonardo del Ferro [Keyser], US epic tenor, dies.
George Hurrell, Hollywood photographer, dies of cancer at age 87.
Montreal Expos' Gary Carter is third to catch 2,000 games (joins Boone and Fisk).
38th Mazda LPGA Championship won by Betsy King.

In Thailand, the so-called Black May begins. Thai police and protestors start attacking one another. By midnight, the current Thai government declares a state of emergency, and military troops, equipped with M-16 rifles, open fire.
US Supreme Court rules states could not force mentally unstable criminal defendants to take anti-psychotic drugs.

The Archivist of the United States issues a proclamation to officially announce that the 27th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has been ratified, despite more than 200 years for completion of the ratification process by the state legislatures.
Englishman Dave Gauder, 224 pounds, pulls 196 ton jumbo jet three inches.
Ric Flair wins NWA wrestling title.
Rap singer raps 597 syllables in 55.12 seconds.
FC Barcelona wins 373 Europe Cup 1 at London.
In Pakistan, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake occurs. At least 36 people killed and 100 injured, at least 400 houses destroyed.
India launches its first satellite independently.
People's Republic of China performs nuclear test at Lop Nor.
New Jersey senate overrides Governor Florio's veto and lowers sales tax to 6 percent.
Elizabeth David, British cookbook writer, dies.
California Angels are involved in a bus crash in New Jersey.
Tony "Big Tuna" Accardo, American mobster (Saint Valentines Day), dies at age 86 (born 1906).
After 30 years, 66-year-old Johnny Carson hosts The Tonight Show for the last time.
A Mafia-planted bomb kills Italian anti-Mafia judge Giovanni Falcone.
New York Yankees play in their fourth straight extra inning game.
President Bush orders Coast Guard to intercept boats with Haitian refugees.
Despite trailing 7-1, New York Yankees tie Milwaukee Brewers and then score one in 9th to avoid 5th straight extra inning game.
Colleen Walker wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Pat Bradley wins J C Penney/LPGA Skins Game Golf Tournament.
The last Thai dictator, General Suchinda Kraprayoon, resigns following pro-democracy protests.
Philip C Habib, US diplomat (Middle-East/Asia), dies at age 72.
New York Yankees score 9 runs before first out in 8th inning, beat Milwaukee Brewers 13-7.
Viktor Grishin, hardline Soviet communist, dies at age 78, dies.
Oscar Luigi Scalfaro elected President of Italy.
Jay Leno takes over as host of The Tonight Show.
Charles Geschke, President of Adobe Systems, is kidnapped from his company parking lot. Kidnappers demand a ransom of $650,000 - they are later apprehended.
Danny Biasone, basketball innovator (24-second clock in NBA), dies at age 83.

Charles Geschke, co-founder of Adobe Systems, Inc. was kidnapped at gunpoint from the Adobe parking lot in Mountain View, California for $650,000 and is held hostage in a rented house in Hollister, California. The FBI rescues him four days later.
65th National Spelling Bee: Amanda Goad wins spelling "lyceum".
Karl Carstens, president of RFA (1979-84), dies.
New York Mets score in 9th to end home shut-out streak at three games.
Peter John "Ollie" Halsall, guitarist, dies of a heart attack at age 43.
Chicago White player Sox Tim Raines steals his 700th career base.
New York Lotto pays US$30 million to one winner (numbers are 12-15-30-33-40-48).
Karl Carstens, President German Federal Republic (1979-84), dies at age 77.
United Nations votes for sanctions against Serb-led Yugoslavia to halt fighting.
New York Yankees' pitcher Scott Sanderson becomes 9th to beat all 26 teams.
Leen 't Hart, organist/composer, dies at age 72.
Barb Mucha wins LPGA Oldsmobile Golf Classic.
Lutz Stavenhagen, top aid to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, dies at age 52.
Terrorist Carlos (the Jackal) is sentenced to life imprisonment.
The Pittsburgh Penguins sweep the Chicago Blackhawks in four games in the NHL Stanley Cup Finals.
The Mabo Decision is handed down, changing Australian Aboriginal land rights forever.
The first World Ocean Day is celebrated, coinciding with the Earth Summit held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
The first World Ocean Day is celebrated, coinciding with the Earth Summit held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
The Orlando Predators of the Arena Football League logged the first (and, to date, only) shutout in league history, defeating the San Antonio Force, 50-0.
The Chicago Bulls win their second NBA championship by defeating the Portland Trail Blazers in the best-of-seven series four games to two.
Ghana Airways inaugurates flights to JFK Airport (New York City).

During a spelling bee at a Trenton, New Jersey elementary school, U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle erroneously corrects a student's spelling of the word potato, by indicating it should have an 'e' at the end.

The United States Supreme Court rules in US vs. Alvarez-Machain that it is permissible for the USA to abduct suspects in foreign countries and bring them to the USA for trial, without approval from those other countries. No reciprocal right is recognized for the reverse to happen in the USA.
A 'Joint Understanding' agreement on arms reduction is signed by U.S. President George H.W. Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin (this is later codified in START II).
A 'Joint Understanding' agreement on arms reduction is signed by U.S. President George H. W. Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin (this would be later codified in START II).
In Estonia, kroon currency replaces the Soviet ruble.
Radio Wimbledon, the Official Radio Station of the Wimbledon Tennis Championships is launched.
US President George Bush presents Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates with the National Medal of Technology.
Two skeletons excavated in Yekaterinburg are identified as Czar Nicholas II and Tsarina Alexandra.
Mafia boss John Gotti is sentenced to life in prison, after being found guilty of conspiracy to commit murder and racketeering on April 2.
Denmark beats Germany 2-0 in soccer to win Euro 92 at Ullevi Stadium in Gothenburg, Sweden.
Estonia holds a referendum on its constitution.
In Landers, California, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs, followed in three hours by a 6.5 earthquake in Big Bear.
A bodyguard assassinates President Muhammad Boudiaf of Algeria.
The one millionth Corvette car is built. It is an Arctic White LT1 convertible, with red interior and black top. Chevrolet donates the car to the National Corvette Museum.
USS George Washington (CVN-73), a Nimitz Class aircraft carrier of the United States Navy is commissioned at Norfolk, Virginia.

(to July 29) Iraq refuses a United Nations inspection team access to the Iraqi Ministry of Agriculture. UNSCOM claims that it has reliable information that the site contains archives related to illegal weapons activities. U.N. inspectors stage a 17-day "sit-in" outside of the building, but leave when their safety is threatened by Iraqi soldiers.
Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe Helsinki Summit creates the office of High Commissioner on National Minorities (HCNM).
In Miami, Florida, former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega is sentenced to 40 years in prison for drug and racketeering violations.
In Miami, Florida, former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega is sentenced to 40 years in prison for drug and racketeering violations.

A major fire consumes an entire city block in tourist destination Gatlinburg, Tennessee, destroying the "Ripley's Believe It Or Not!" Museum and several other local businesses and attractions in the process.
Arkansas Governor Bill Clinton is nominated for U.S. President and Tennessee Senator Al Gore for Vice President, at the Democratic National Convention in New York City.
Independent U.S. presidential candidate H. Ross Perot drops out of the race, saying that the Democratic Party has 'revitalized itself'.
The Splash Mountain attraction opens in Frontierland in the Magic Kingdom at Walt Disney World.
'The Late Show', starring the D-Generation debuts on ABC.
The ten victims of the La Cantuta massacre disappeared from their university in Lima.
Vﬂclav Havel resigns as president of Czechoslovakia.
A TU-154 cargo plane crashes in the suburbs of Tbilisi, Georgia, killing forty.
Vﬂclav Havel resigns as president of Czechoslovakia.
Near Medell?n, Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar escapes from his luxury prison, fearing extradition to the United States.
Near Medellfn, Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar escapes from his luxury prison fearing extradition to the United States.
(to August 9) Games of the XXV Olympiad are held in Barcelona, Spain.
A Thai Airways Airbus A300-310 crashes into mountain north of Kathmandu, Nepal killing 113.
Walt Disney World welcomes its 400-millionth guest.
Games of the XXV Olympiad close in Barcelona, Spain.
The UK government bans the Ulster Defence Association, a loyalist paramilitary organisation that had been legal for twenty years.
Canada, Mexico, and the United States announce completion of negotiations for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
Nigel Mansell wins the 1992 Formula One World Drivers Championship.
In Mbale, Uganda, forty-eight meteorite stones fall, 108kg total weight, damaging roofs, striking a boy on the head.
NBA basketball player Larry Bird announces his retirement after winning an Olympic gold medal as a member of the U.S. Dream Team.
In Kyrgyzstan, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs. An estimated 75 people killed. Several villages, including Toluk, were destroyed and at least 8,200 dwellings were destroyed.
Kristiansund's connection to the main land of Norway, Krifast, opens.

The Republican National Convention in Houston, Texas renominates U.S. President George H.W. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. Pat Buchanan, one of Bush's opponents in the primaries, delivers a controversial convention speech, in which he refers to a "religious war" in the country.

(to August 22) Events at Ruby Ridge, Idaho are sparked by a Federal Marshal surveillance team, resulting in the death of Marshal Sam Weaver and his dog and the next day the wounding of Randy Weaver, the death of his wife Vicki and the wounding of Kevin Harris.
FBI HRT sniper Lon Horiuchi shoots and kills Vicki Weaver during an 11-day siege at her home at Ruby Ridge, Idaho.
(to August 28) Hurricane Andrew hits South Florida and dissipates over the Tennessee valley when it merges with a storm system; 23 are killed.
Diplomatic relations are established between the People's Republic of China and South Korea.
Michael Schumacher wins his first Grand Prix car race in Belgium at Spa-Francorchamps in a Benetton-Ford race car.

Pascal Lissouba is inaugurated as the President of the Republic of the Congo after a multiparty presidential election, ending a long history of one-party oppressive rule under the Congolese Workers Party.

Near the coast of Nicaragua, a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurs. At least 116 people killed, more than 68 missing and over 13,500 left homeless in Nicaragua. At least 1,300 houses and 185 fishing boats were destroyed along the west coast of Nicaragua. Most of the casualties and damage were caused by a tsunami affecting the west coasts of Nicaragua and Costa Rica, reaching heights of up to 8 metres.
In Zaire, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake occurs. At least eight people were killed, 37 were injured and several buildings were destroyed at Kibombo.
Hurricane Iniki hits the Hawaiian Islands, Kauai and Oahu.
Hurricane Iniki, one of the most damaging hurricane in United States history during its time, devastates the State of Hawai'i, especially the islands of Kaua'i and Oahu.
Abimael Guzmﬂn, leader of the Shining Path, is captured by Peruvian special forces; shortly thereafter the rest of Shining Path's leadership fell as well.
NASA launches Space Shuttle Endeavour on STS-47 which marked the 50th shuttle mission. On board is Mae Carol Jemison who becomes the first African-American woman in space.
Mihkel Mathiesen assumes presidency of the pre-WW II Republic of Estonia in exile, and appoints a new government in pursuit to avoid abolition of the government in exile.
The Pound Sterling and the Italian Lira are forced out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism (Black Wednesday).
Black Wednesday: the Pound Sterling is forced out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism by currency speculators and is forced to devalue against the Deutschmark.
Two Kurdish opposition leaders are assassinated by the Iranian Kazem Darabi and the Lebanese Abbas Rhayel.
Undaunted by his earlier withdrawal, supporters of U.S. presidential candidate H. Ross Perot succeed in getting his name on the ballot in all 50 states.
The existence of the National Reconnaissance Office, operating since 1960, is declassified.
Nine formerly pro-Albanian Marxist-Leninist parties hold a conference in Strassburg, Germany.
A large Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb destroys the forensic laboratories in Belfast.
In Canada, three people share a CDN$18 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello resigns.
H. Ross Perot re-enters the 1992 U.S. presidential campaign.

Pittsburgh International Airport's new facility is opened in Findlay Township, near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The new terminal is built as an expansion for USAir and an upgrade from the older Pittsburgh International Airport facility.
The Carandiru Massacre takes place after a riot in the Carandiru prison system in São Paulo, Brazil.
SinTad O'Connor rips up a photo of Pope John Paul II on Saturday Night Live.
An Israeli plane crashes in Amsterdam, the Netherlands; 43 are killed, many more injured.
An El Al Boeing 747-200F crashes into two apartment buildings in Amsterdam, killing 43 including 38 on the ground. See Bijlmerramp
IBM Personal Computer company introduces the IBM ThinkPad line of laptop computers.
Lennart Meri becomes the first president of re-independent Estonia.

Willy Brandt (born Herbert Ernst Karl Frahm) dies in Unkel, Germany; mayor of West Berlin (1957-66), foreign minister and vice-chancellor (1966-69), chancellor (1969-74), Nobel Prize for Peace in 1971.
A 13-kilogram (29-pound) meteorite lands in the driveway of the Knapp residence in Peekskill, New York, destroying the family's 1980 Chevrolet Malibu (pierces trunk and floor).
A 13 kilogram (est.) meteorite lands in the driveway of the Knapp residence in Peekskill, New York, destroying the family's 1980 Chevrolet Malibu.
Floriade (Flower Show) closes at the Hague, Netherlands.
In Egypt, a magnitude 5.8 earthquake occurs. At least 552 people killed, more than 9,929 injured and 8,300 buildings damaged or destroyed in the Cairo area. Estimate of damage about US$300 million.
In the Dominican Republic, Pope John Paul II congregates to celebrate the 500th anniversary on the meeting of two cultures.
The Toronto Blue Jays win a 9-2 victory over the Oakland Athletics in Game six of the American League Championship Series.

IBM and Motorola announce the production of PowerPC 601 microprocessors, in 50 MHz and 66 MHz versions. PowerPC stands for "Power Performance Chip", and incorporates an integer unit, a floating-point unit, and 32 MB cache.
In Game 7 of the National League Championship Series the Atlanta Braves win 3-2 over the Pittsburgh Pirates, winning the series.
In Russia, Andrei Chikatilo is found guilty of 52 serial murders.
In Russia, Andrei Chikatilo is found guilty of 52 serial murders.

Duchess of York Sarah Ferguson files a 1.4 million USD lawsuit against French tabloids for running topless photos taken of her on the French Riviera, including some of Texas millionaire John Bryan suckling on her toes.

Yoshihiro Hattori, a 16-year-old Japanese exchange student, mistakes the address of a party and is shot dead after knocking on the wrong door in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. The shooter, Rodney Peairs, is later acquitted, sparking outrage in Japan.
The United Nations General Assembly declares October 17 as the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty, to be observed beginning in 1993. Resolution 47/196 of 22 December 1992.
In Northern Colombia, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs.
In Morocco, a magnitude 5.2 earthquake occurs.
Akihito becomes the first Emperor of Japan to stand on Chinese soil.
The Toronto Blue Jays win the World Series of baseball in six games, making them the first Canadian team to win.
Lithuania holds a referendum on its first constitution after declaring independence from the Soviet Union in 1991.
Latvia establishes its first post-Soviet constitution.
In Canada, the Charlottetown Accord is defeated in a national referendum.
The command and control system of the London Ambulance Service fails catastrophically.
The Charlottetown Accord fails to win majority support in a Canada wide referendum.
The Food and Drug Administration approves Depo Provera for use as a contraceptive in the United States.
The Food and Drug Administration approves Depo Provera for use as a contraceptive in the United States.
Pope John Paul II issues an apology, and lifts the edict of the Inquisition against Galileo Galilei.
Douglas Adams finally announces why he chose 42 to be The Answer to Life, the_Universe, and Everything
U.S. presidential election: Bill Clinton defeats incumbent U.S. President George H.W. Bush and businessman H. Ross Perot.
U.S. presidential election: Democratic challenger Bill Clinton defeats incumbent Republican George H.W. Bush and independent candidate Ross Perot.
In Detroit, Michigan, black motorist Malice Green dies after a struggle with white policemen Larry Nevers and Walter Budzyn.
The Party for Socialist Turkey is founded.
Helmut Kohl, Michail Gorbatschov and Ronald Reagan are made honorary citizens of Berlin for their contributions to German reunification.
The Church of England votes to allow women to become priests.
The Church of England votes to allow women to become priests.
Absolutely Fabulous airs its first episode on BBC1.
In England, a fire breaks out in the Private Chapel room of Windsor Castle, rages for 15 hours, and seriously damages the northwest side of the building.

In England, a fire breaks out in the Private Chapel room of Windsor Castle, rages for 15 hours, and seriously damages the northwest side of the building (an investigation found that the fire was ignited after a spotlight came into contact with a curtain over an extended period).
In the People's Republic of China, a China Southern Airlines domestic flight crashes, killing all 141 people on-board.
In the People's Republic of China, a China Southern Airlines domestic flight crashes, killing all 141 people on-board.
The Czechoslovakia Federal Assembly votes to split the country into the Czech Republic and Slovakia, starting on January 1, 1993.
The Czechoslovakia Federal Assembly votes to split the country into the Czech Republic and Slovakia from January 1, *1993.
For the second time in a year, military forces try to overthow president Carlos Andres Perez in Venezuela.
Dennis Byrd of the New York Jets is temporarily paralyzed by a neck injury during a football game against the Kansas City Chiefs.
The trial of 14 South Vietnamese accused of murdering 24 North Vietnamese begins in Hong Kong (ends November 29, 1994).
Two C-141B Starlifters collide in Montana and crash, 13 die.
Gary Mascaro, choreographer, dies at age 43.

United Nations Security Council Resolution 794 is unanimously passed, approving a coalition of United Nations peacekeepers led by the United States to form UNITAF, tasked with ensuring humanitarian aid gets distributed and establishing peace in Somalia.
Nureddin Al-Atassi, President of Syria (1966-70), dies.
The Greek oil tanker Aegean Sea, carrying 80,000 tonnes of crude oil, runs aground in a storm while approaching La Coruña, Spain, and spills much of its cargo.

UN Security Council Resolution 794 is unanimously passed, approving a coalition of United Nations peacekeepers led by the United States to form UNITAF, tasked with establishing peace and ensuring that humanitarian aid is distributed in Somalia.
U.S. military forces land in Somalia.
Somali Civil War: President George H. W. Bush orders 28,000 US troops to Somalia.
Sergei Aleksandrovich Yemelyanov, Russian cosmonaut, dies at age 41.

Kent Conrad of North Dakota resigns his seat in the United States Senate and is sworn into the other seat from North Dakota, becoming the only U.S. Senator ever to have held two seats on the same day.
Kent Conrad of North Dakota resigns his seat in the United States Senate and is sworn into the other seat from North Dakota, becoming the only US Senator ever to have held two seats on the same day.
San Francisco 49ers' player Jerry Rice catches NFL record 101st touchdown.
San Francisco Giants renig on $43 million pact with Barry Bonds.
Dottie Mochrie/Dan Forsmann win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
81st Davis Cup: USA beats Switzerland in Fort Worth (3-1).
300,000 Hindus demolish Babri Masjid (a 16th century mosque) in Ayodhya, India. Four die; riots follow.
In Ayodhya, India, Hindus belonging to the nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party demolish the Babri Masjid, a 16th century mosque.
Galileo spacecraft passes North Pole of Moon (Peary Crater).

The last blast is fired in the Falu Copper Mine in central Sweden. The mine operation is claimed to be the world's oldest industrial worksite, operating continuously for at least 1000 years. The site is now shutting down due to lack of workable ore.
Barry Bonds signs the richest contract in major league history: US$43-million over the next six years with the San Francisco Giants.
Galileo's nearest approach to Jupiter (303 km).
Prince Charles and Princess Diana separation announced by British Prime Minister, John Major.
New Jersey Devils organization announces that it will change its colors to black, red, and white for the 1992-93 season.
Cincinnati Reds' owner Marge Schott apologizes for racist remarks.
Carl Barger, baseball president (Pittsburgh Pirates, Florida Marlins), dies at age 62.
1800 U.S. Marines storm Mogadishu, Somalia, first units of a multinational force to restore order and provide starvation relief.
Sri Lanka's third-ever Test Cricket victory (versus New Zealand by nine wickets).
The separation of Charles, Prince of Wales and Diana, Princess of Wales is announced
New York Yankees sign free agent pitcher Jimmy Key.
The National Hockey League votes unanimously to expand to Anaheim, California, approving a new team, "The Mighty Ducks", owned by The Walt Disney Company.
Orlanda Magic scores 14 3-pointers (two shy of record).
Nor'easter storm hits New York, doing $650 million+ worth of damage.
New York Giants lose 19-0 to Phoenix Cardinals.
58th Heisman Trophy Award: Gino Torretta, Miami Florida (quarterback).

In Flores Region, Indonesia, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs. At least 2,200 people killed or missing in the Flores region, more than 500 people injured and 40,000 left homeless. Tsunami wave heights of up to 25 metres.
Bernard Lievegoed, Dutch doctor/psychiatrist/author (Free College), dies at age 87.
Japanese crown prince Naruhito announces engagement to Masaka Owada.
Jasu Patel, cricket player (29 wickets for India, best 9-69 versus Australia), dies.
Julia Kurotchkina, 18, of Russia, crowned 42nd Miss World.
Dawn Coe-Jones wins Pizza-La LPGA Match Play Golf Championship.

Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM inspectors to use its own aircraft to fly into Iraq, and begins military operations in the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait, and the northern Iraqi no-fly zones. U.S. forces fire approximately 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Baghdad factories linked to Iraq's illegal nuclear weapons program. Iraq then informs UNSCOM that it will be able to resume its flights.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents raid the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Texas, with a warrant to arrest leader David Koresh on federal firearms violations. Four agents and five Davidians die in the raid and a 51-day standoff begins.

President of Pakistan, Ghulam Ishaq Khan dissolves the National Assembly and dismisses Cabinet.
George Mickelson, Governor of South Dakota, and seven others, die in a plane crash.
A 51-day stand-off at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Texas, ends with a fire and shooting that kills 76 people, including leader David Koresh.
22nd Boston Women's Marathon won by Olga Markova of Russia in 2:25:27.
Fire in psychiatric institute in South Korea kills 40.
97th Boston Marathon won by Cosmas N'deti of Kenya in 2:09:33.
The 50-day siege of the Branch Davidian building outside Waco, Texas, USA, ends when a fire breaks out. Eighty-one people die.
Uranus passes Neptune (this occurs once every 171 years).
Hal Schumacher, baseball pitcher, dies at age 82.
Mark Koenig, baseball shortstop (New York Yankees), dies at age 88.
Holocaust Memorial Museum dedicated in Washington, DC.
Andries Treurnicht, founder South Africa Conservative Party, dies at age 72.
Seattle Mariner Chris Basio no-hits Boston Red Sox.
Cesar Chavez, US farm worker (United Farm Workers), dies at age 66.
The Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, DC is dedicated.
The web browser Mosaic version 1.0 is released.
The WHO declares tuberculosis a Global Emergency.
Lalith Athulathmudali, Sri Lankan minister, murdered at age 59.
Eritrea votes to secede from Ethiopia.
Eritreans vote overwhelmingly for independence from Ethiopia in a United Nations-monitored referendum.
1000kg heavy Irish Republican Army car bomb explodes in London, killing 1.
Firestone World Bowling Tournament of Champions won by George Branham.
Oliver R Tambo, chairman (African National Congress), dies at age 75.
An IRA bomb devastates the Bishopsgate area of City of London.
300,000 gay, lesbian, transgender, and allied activists march on Washington, DC demanding freedom from discrimination.
NBC announces Conan O'Brien to replace David Lettermann late night TV show.

All 30 members of the Zambia national football team lose their lives in a plane crash off Libreville, Gabon in route to Dakar, Senegal to play a 1994 FIFA World Cup qualifying match against Senegal (the most tragic incident to date in African football history).
Afghan Antonov AN-32 plane crashes at Tashqurgan, kills 76.
New York Islanders beat Washington Capitals four to one in playoffs, Capitals Dale Hunter attacks Pierre Turgeon after scoring, in hockey's worst cheap shot.
Jim Valvano, basketball coach (North Carolina State), dies of cancer at age 47.
Carlo Ciampi forms Italian government with ex-communists.
In western Arizona, USA, a magnitude 5.3 earthquake occurs.
Mick Ronson, English guitarist/producer (Mott the Hoople), dies at age 46.
The World Wide Web is born at CERN.
David Waymer, NFL player (New Orleans Saints, San Francisco 49ers, Oakland Raiders), dies at age 34.
Eric Rowan, cricket player (26 Tests for South Africa), dies.
Tennis star Monica Seles is stabbed in the back by an obsessed fan of rival Steffi Graf at a tournament in Hamburg, Germany.
The Walt Disney Company announces an agreement to acquire Miramax Film Corporation. Disney will acquire Miramax's library of over 200 films.
Virgin Radio (then Virgin 1215) launches in the United Kingdom at 12:15 pm.
The World Wide Web was born at CERN.

During a tennis match between #1 female tennis player Monica Sele? and Magdalena Maleeva, Günter Parche plunged a steak knife between Sele?'s shoulderblades. Sele? did not return to competitive tennis for over two years.
A Tamil Tigers suicide bomber assassinates President Ranasinghe Premadasa of Sri Lanka. 25 others die as well.
119th Kentucky Derby: Jerry Bailey aboard Sea Hero wins in 2:02.4.
Hans [Henri EA] Tuynman, provo (Full-time Provo), dies at age 50.
Pierre BTrTgovoy, former Prime Minister of France (1992-93), commits suicide at age 67.
Sandra Palmer wins LPGA Sprint Senior Challenge Golf Tournament.
Julio Gallo, wine maker (Gallo), dies in a car accident at age 82.
Kristi Albers wins Sprint Golf Classic.
Lenore Kingston Jenson dies of cancer at age 79.
Balak Brahmachari [Marxist Godman], Indies guru, dies at age 73.
South Africa agrees to multi-racial elections.
Lennox Lewis beats Tony Tucker in 12 rounds for heavyweight boxing title.
ABC Masters Bowling Tournament won by Phil Ware.
Sixteen-year old Keron Thomas disguises himself as a motorman and takes New York City subway train and 2,000 passengers on a three hour ride.
Meg Mallon wins LPGA Sara Lee Golf Classic.
Paraguay holds its first presidential and parliamentary elections in 50 years.
Mary Duncan Sanford dies at age 98.
Premier Lubbers opens Terminal West on Schiphol.
World's worst factory fire at the Kader Toy Factory in Bangkok, Thailand, kills 188, injures 469.
Paul CTzanne's still life painting sells for US$28.6 million in New York City.
Last TV appearance of Mies Bouwman.
In Thailand, a fire at the Kader Toy Factory kills 188 workers, mostly young women.
Paramaribo Suriname TV studio destroyed by fire.
28th Academy of Country Music Awards: Garth Brooks wins.
Evert "Eef" Dolman, Dutch cyclist (Olympics-gold-1964), dies at age 47.
Borolas [Joaquin Garcia], Mexican comedian (Santa Sangre), dies of heart attack at age 71.
Kansas City Royals' player George Brett hits his 300th homerun.
Methane gas explosion in Secunda coal mine South Africa, kills 50.
Patrick Haemers, Belgian criminal, commits suicide at age 40.
William Randolph Hearst, US newspaper magnate (Pulitzer), dies at age 85.
119th Preakness: Mike Smith aboard Prairie Bayou wins in 1:56.6.
Alamodome in San Antonio, Texas opens.
Montreal Expos retire their first number, #10 for Rusty Staub.
Snleyman Demirel elected President of Turkey.
Marv Johnson, US soul singer ("You Got What it Takes"), dies at age 54.
Laura Davies wins LPGA McDonald's Golf Championship.
Farmer Sugeng finds 1.2 million-year-old Pithecanthropus IX skull.
Harry Elstr∞m, Danish/Belgian sculptor, dies at age 86.
Danish people vote in favor of ratifying the Maastricht Treaty.
Heinrich Albertz, theologist/mayor of Berlin (1966-67), dies at age 78.
Italian police arrest Mafia boss Benedetto "Nitto" Santapaola.
Pamela M Cunnington, English architect/writer, dies at age 67.
Juventus wins 22th UEFA Cup at Torino.
Boeing 727 crashes into mountain at Medell?n, Colombia, kills 132.
Nemesio Antunes, Chilean painter, dies at age 75.
S W Sohoni, cricket player (4 Tests for India), dies.
Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 3,500 for first time (3,500.03).
Ten-metre meteor comes within 150,000 km of Earth (1993KA).
Intel announces availability of the Pentium processor. Prices are US$878 for 60 MHz, and US$965 for 66 MHz.
Max Klein, inventor (paint by numbers), dies at age 77.
Opposition leader Xanana Gusmao of East-Timor sentenced to life.
Robin Smith scores 167 in England Texaco Trophy loss versus Australia.
John Frost, English Lieutenant-Colonel (operation Market Garden 1944), dies at age 80.
Dayanara Torres, 18, of Puerto Rico, crowned 42nd Miss Universe.
Venezuela president Carlos AndrTs PTrez fired.
Riddick Bowe scores a technical knock-out on Jesse Ferguson in two rounds for heavyweight boxing title.
Mieczyslaw Horszowski, Polish/US pianist (Carnegie Hall), dies at age 100.
Val Skinner wins LPGA Lady Keystone Golf Open.
Milton O Thompson, astronaut (Dynasoar, X-15), dies at age 66.
Kurd rebellion kills 33 soldiers and five citizens in Turkey.
Jesus Posadas Ocampo, Mexican cardinal/archbishop, shot dead at age 66.
Eritrea achieves independence from Ethiopia after 30-year civil war.
Eritrea gains its independence from Ethiopia.
Olympique Marseille wins 38th Europe Cup I at Munich, Germany.
Long fly ball by Cleveland Indians' Carlos Martinez bounces off Jose Canseco's head and goes over fence for a homerun.
Cor de Great, pianist/conductor/composer (Vernissage), dies at age 78.
Willem P G Assmann, Dutch Member of Parliament, dies at age 85.
Dale Murphy ends baseball career at 398 homeruns.
A car bomb at the Uffizi Gallery in Florence kills five; the Mafia is suspected.
Charles Barnett, cricket player (20 Tests for England), dies.
Neo-Nazis kill five Turkish women in Solingen, Germany.
Tiny Hofman, Amsterdam activist (Nieuwmarkt), dies at age 68.
Texas Rangers' player Jose Canseco pitches 8th inning in 15-1 loss to Boston Red Sox, he gives up three runs on two hits and three walks, and he damages his arm.
Betsy King wins J C Penney/LPGA Skins Game Golf Tournament.
Kelly Robbins wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Sun Ra, American blues pianist/orchestra leader, dies of strokes at age 79 (born 1914).
President Dobrica Cosic of Yugoslavia flees.
In Minnesota, a magnitude 4.1 earthquake occurs.
24 Pakistani troops in the United Nations forces are killed in Mogadishu, Somalia.
Mongolia holds its first direct presidential elections.
Mongolia holds its first direct presidential elections.
Prince changes his name to a symbol and comes to be referred to as "The Artist formerly known as Prince".
In Paris, Christian Didier breaks into the home of Rene Bousquet, banker and former Vichy France administrator, and shoots him dead.
The Montreal Canadiens win their 24th National Hockey League Stanley Cup.

Nigerian presidential elections held with the largest turnout ever. Chief Moshood Kashimawo Olawale Abiola (popularly known and called M. K. O.), an international businessman and politician, who was the candidate of the Social Democratic Party overwhelmingly defeated rival Alhaji Bashir Tofa, candidate of the National Republican Convention. After most of the results were announced, the election was annulled by military president Ibrahim Babangida. Subsequent nationwide and international protests forced Babangida to relinquish power albeit to his handpicked Interim National Government.
Tansu ?iller becomes prime minister of Turkey.
Mulitpartyists win a referendum on the future of the one-party system in Malawi.
A weeklong product tampering scare, later proven to be a hoax, occurs as customers throughout the USA discover syringes in unopened cans of Diet Pepsi Cola.
Death by heart attack of James Hunt, former British racing driver and commentator in Formula One (born 1947).
John Sculley steps down as CEO of Apple Computer, remaining as chairman. The board of directors names Michael Spindler as new CEO.
Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM weapons inspectors to install remote-controlled monitoring cameras at two missile engine test stands.
John Paxson's three-point shot in Game six of the National Basketball Association Finals helps the Chicago Bulls secure a 99-98 win over the Phoenix Suns, and their third consecutive championship.
A 7.5 earthquake hits Japan, killing 385 people.
A Unabomber bomb injures Charles Epstein in Tiburon, California.
Japan's New Party Sakigake breaks away from the Liberal Democratic Party.
Andrew Wiles wins worldwide fame after presenting his solution for Fermat's Last Theorem, a problem that has been unsolved for more than three centuries.
A Unabomber bomb injures computer scientist David Gelernter at Yale University.
Yale computer science professor Dr. David Gelernter loses the sight in one eye, the hearing in one ear, and part of his right hand after receiving a mailbomb from the Unabomber.
Litas currency is introduced in Lithuania.
Kim Campbell becomes the 19th and first female Prime Minister of Canada.
After 11 years at NBC, David Letterman airs his final Late Night with David Letterman and leaves NBC for CBS.
Kim Campbell is chosen as leader of the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada and becomes the first female Prime Minister of Canada.
The U.S. launches a missile attack targeting Baghdad intelligence headquarters in retaliation for a thwarted assassination attempt against former President George H.W. Bush in April in Kuwait.
In Bad Kleinen, Germany, GSG 9 troopers arrest terrorists Birgit Hogefeld and Wolfgang Grams.

U.S. President Bill Clinton orders a cruise missile attack on Iraqi intelligence headquarters in the Al-Mansur District of Baghdad, in response to the attempted assassination of former U.S. President George H. W. Bush during his visit to Kuwait in mid-April.
A magnitude 7.8 earthquake off Hokkaido, Japan launches a devastating tsunami up to 30 metres in height, killing 202 on the small island of Okushiri, Hokkaido.
A magnitude 7.8 earthquake off the shore of Hokkaido, Japan launches a devastating tsunami, killing 202 on the small island of Okushiri.
U.S. President Bill Clinton announces his 'Don't ask, don't tell' policy regarding gays in the American military.
White House deputy counsel Vince Foster commits suicide in Virginia.
20,000 policemen gather at Wembley Stadium in London to protest pay reforms.
James Jordan, father of basketball superstar Michael Jordan, is murdered in Lumberton, North Carolina.
Candelﬂria massacre: Brazilian police officers kill eight street kids in Rio de Janeiro.
Israel launches a massive attack against Lebanon in what the Israelis call Operation Accountability and the Lebanese call Seven-Day War.
Asiana Air Flight 733 crashes into Mt. Ungeo in Haenam, South Korea killing 68.
The Israeli Supreme Court acquits accused German death camp guard John Demjanjuk of all charges and he is set free.
The Israeli Supreme Court acquits accused Nazi death camp guard John Demjanjuk of all charges and he is set free.
Riverboat gambling is launched in Mississippi state.
A federal judge sentences Los Angeles Police Department officers Stacey Koon and Laurence Powell to 30 months in prison for violating motorist Rodney King's civil rights.
A federal judge sentences LAPD officers Stacey Koon and Laurence Powell to 30 months in prison for violating motorist Rodney King's civil rights.
Popular trading card game Magic: The Gathering is released. First trading card game to date.
Louis Freeh is confirmed by the United States Senate as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The Fugitive opens in theaters, starring Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones.
Louis Freeh is confirmed by the United States Senate to be the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation
South of the Mariana Islands, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs. Forty-eight people injured on Guam.
King Albert II of Belgium is sworn into office nine days after the death of his brother, King Baudouin I.
King Albert II of Belgium is sworn into office.
The Liberal Democratic Party of Japan loses a 38-year hold on national leadership.
On South Island, New Zealand, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurs. The shock was also felt at Sydney, Australia.
Over 130 die in the collapse of Royal Plaza Hotel at Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand's worst hotel disaster.
A nuclear submarine and a supertanker collide off the French Riviera, creating an oil slick which is quickly contained.
After rounds of secret negotiations in Norway, the Oslo Peace Accords were signed, followed by a public ceremony in Washington, D.C. the next month.
NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Observer orbiter three days before the spacecraft is scheduled to enter orbit around Mars.
NASA loses contact with the Mars Observer spacecraft.
The Rainbow Bridge, connecting Tokyo's Shibaura and the island of Odaiba, is completed.
The Florida DOT decides to cease producing its distinctive colored U.S. Highway shields so that it can make use of Federal funds for those signs.
A dam breaks in Qinghai, China. 223 die.
76 die in an airplane crash in Tajikistan.
The first episode of the Late Show with David Letterman airs on CBS, following Letterman's move from NBC.
The Essendon Football Club wins its 15th AFL premiership over rivals Carlton Football Club.
Near the coast of Chiapas, Mexico, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs. Felt in much of Central America.

NASA launches, on the 4th launch attempt, Space Shuttle Discovery on mission STS-51 which marked the 57th Space Shuttle mission. During this spectacular mission the ACTS was inserted into orbit as well as (temporarily) SPAS. Practice was also gained for the Hubble Space Telescope repair mission through EVA. This mission ended with the 6th night landing of the Shuttle, at The Kennedy Space Centre.
Palistinian Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin shake hands in Washington D.C., after signing the Oslo peace accord.
Norwegian parliamentary election: The Labour Party wins a plurality of the seats, and Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland retains office.
Public unveiling of the Oslo Accords, an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement initiated by Norway.
Liechtenstein Prince Hans-Adam II disbands parliament.
In Poland, a coalition of left parties wins 66 percent of parliament seats.
In Oregon, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurs.
Russian President Boris Yeltsin suspends parliament and scraps the then-functioning constitution, thus triggering the Russian constitutional crisis of 1993.
A Transair Georgian Airlines Tu-154 is shot down by a missile in Sukhumi, Georgia.
The International Olympic Committee selects Sydney, Australia to be the site of the 2000 Summer Olympics.
Christies Auctions sells a US 1868 3-cent rose George Washington postage stamp with "B" grill embossing for US$96,000 (including buyer's fee). The stamp is one of four known.

In Southern India, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake occurs. Nearly 10,000 people killed, about 30,000 injured and extreme devastation in the Latur-Osmanabad area. Nearly all buildings destroyed in the village of Khillari. Felt in large parts of central and southern India. This earthquake is the largest known earthquake to occur in the area.
An earthquake hits India's Latur and Osmanabad district of Marathwada (Aurangabad division) in Maharashtra state leaving tens of thousands of people dead and many more homeless.
Polly Klaas is kidnapped by Richard Allen Davis during a slumber party at her Petaluma, California, home; Davis will be sentenced to death for her murdering Klaas.
A large scale battle erupts between U.S. forces and local militia in Mogadishu, Somalia; two Black Hawk helicopters are shot down; 19 Americans and 500 Somalis are killed.
Russian troops open fire on a crowd of supporters of parliament, killing about 100.
Battle of Mogadishu: In an attempt to capture officials of warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid's organization in Mogadishu, Somalia, 18 US Army Rangers and about 1000 Somalis are killed.

Russian military and security forces clear the Russian Parliament (White House) building by force, squashing a mass uprising against President Boris Yeltsin. About 500 are killed, another 1000 wounded.
Russian constitutional crisis of 1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin orders tanks to storm the Russian parliament building.
Doom press-release version is made available to journalists for review.
Premier Cruise Lines announces it is dropping the appearance of Disney characters from its cruise ships as of April 1, 1994.
After nine years of playing in the NBA, Michael Jordan retires from basketball.

David Miscavige announces the IRS has granted full tax exemption to the Church of Scientology International and affiliated churches and organizations ending the Church's 40-year battle with the IRS and resulting in religious recognition in the United States.
Andreas Papandreou begins his second term as Prime Minister of Greece.
In eastern New Guinea, Papua New Guinea, a magnitude 6.9 earthquake occurs. Sixty people killed and several injured in the Upper Markham Valley.
The Philadelphia Phillies win the National League pennant by beating the Atlanta Braves in Game six of the NLCS, 6-3.
Stack's auctions the Reed Hawn Collection; the Mickley specimen of the Class I US 1804 Draped Bust dollar sells for $475,000. The Reed Hawn US 1913 Liberty Head 5-cent coin sells for $875,000.
Andreas Papandreou begins his second term as Prime Minister of Greece.
Joe Carter hits only the second baseball World Series winning home run as the Toronto Blue Jays win Game Six of the World Series to beat the Philadelphia Phillies four games to two.
In Canada, one person wins a Canadian record (for a single winner) CDN$15 million Lotto 6/49 jackpot.
The Toronto Blue Jays win their second straight World Series.
Canadian federal election: Jean ChrTtien and his Liberal Party defeat the governing Progressive Conservative Party.

Jean ChrTtien becomes prime minister of Canada with a massive majority for his Liberal Party in a general election in which the governing Progressive Conservatives, led by Kim Campbell, lost 149 of 151 seats in the parliament.
The Carolina Panthers become the NFL's 29th franchise and the first expansion team since 1976.
Actor River Phoenix dies of a drug overdose outside of the Viper Room in Hollywood.
The Maastricht Treaty takes effect, formally establishing the European Union.
The Maastricht Treaty takes effect, formally establishing the European Union.
Jean ChrTtien becomes the 20th Prime Minister of Canada.
Jean ChrTtien takes office as Prime Minister of Canada.
A series of fires destroy 1000 homes in southern California, causing between 500 million and 1 billion USD of damage. Half of the fires turn out to be arson.
Bolivia becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
A China Airlines Boeing 747 overran Runway 13 at Hong Kong's Kai Tak International Airport while landing during a typhoon, injuring 22 people.
Bosnian Croat forces destroy the Stari most, or Old Bridge of Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, by tank fire.
Stari most, the "old bridge" in Bosnian Mostar built in 1566, collapses after several days of bombing.

Disney announces plans to build a 150-acre amusement park called Disney's America with a history theme in Piedmont, Virginia. The 3,000 acre, US$650 million development would also include a campground, golf course, 2500 homes, and two million square feet of office/commercial space.
Decree of President of Kazakhstan "About introducing national currency of Republic of Kazakhstan" was issued.
A teacher and ten children, all from Hagley RC High School near Birmingham, United Kingdom, are killed in a minibus crash on the M40 in Warwickshire.
In South Africa, 21 political parties approve a new constitution.
In South Africa, 21 political parties approve a new constitution.

An Avioimpex Yak 42D crashes into Mount Trojani near Ohrid, Macedonia. The aircraft was on a flight from Geneva, Switzerland to Skopje, but had been diverted to Ohrid due to poor weather conditions at the Skopje airport. All eight crew members and 115 of the 116 passengers are killed.
Savings and Loan scandal: The United States Senate Ethics Committee issues a stern censure of California senator Alan Cranston for his "dealings" with savings-and-loan executive Charles Keating.
Rachel Whiteread wins both the £20,000 Turner Prize award for best British modern artist and the £40,000 K Foundation art award for the worst artist of the year.
In the United Kingdom, 11-year-olds Robert Thompson and Jon Venables are convicted of the child murder of 2-year-old James Bulger of Liverpool.
In Liverpool, 11-year-olds Robert Thompson and Jon Venables are convicted of the murder of 2-year-old James Bulger.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act (the Brady Bill) into law.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act (the Brady Bill) into law.
Northwest Airlink plane crashes in Minnesota, killing 18.
Dow Jones Industrial Average hits record 3702.11.
Houston Rockets tie NBA record of 15-0 start.
Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar, head of the Medell?n Cartel, is gunned down in Medell?n when police try to arrest him.
Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar is shot and killed in Medellfn.
Space Shuttle program: STS-61 - NASA launches the Space Shuttle Endeavour on a mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.
Lewis Thomas, American biologist, dies of cancer at age 80 (born 1913).
Dan Jansen skates world record 500 metre (35.92 seconds).
Frank V Zappa, American guitarist and composer (Mothers of Invention), dies at age 52 (born 1940).
Frank Sturgis, Watergate burglar, dies at age 68.
Hetty de Boer-Jongkind, Dutch medical astrologist, dies at age 42.
A truce is concluded between the government of Angola and UNITA rebels.
Melissa Mcnamara/Mike Sopringer win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
82nd Davis Cup: Germany beats Australia in Dusseldorf (4-1).
Alexandre Trauber, Hungarian/French set designer (Harem), dies at age 87.
Arthur Staal, Dutch architect (Shell Tower Amsterdam), dies at age 86.
Douglas Hopkins, American guitarist and songwriter (Gin Blossoms), dies of gun shot at age 32 (born 1961).
Astronauts begin repair of Hubble telescope in space.
Rafael Caldera elected President of Venezuela.
Gunda Niemann skates ladies world record 5 km 7 13.29.
Rouaz Lakhdar, Algerian supreme court justice, murdered.
Professor Wolfgang Paul, German physicist (Nobel Prize 1989), dies at age 80.
Colin Ferguson opens fire with his Ruger 9mm pistol on a Long Island Rail Road train, killing 16 and injuring 29.
Henri Konan BTdiT names himself President of Ivory Coast.
FTlix Houphouet-Boigny, President of Ivory Coast (1960-93), dies at age 88 (born 1905).
Thirty-two member Transitional Executive Committee holds its first meeting in Cape Town, marking the first meeting of an official government body in South Africa with black members.
The Long Island Rail Road Massacre: Colin Ferguson murders six people and injures 19 others on the LIRR in Nassau County, New York.
In South Africa, the Transitional Executive Council is established.
AndrT Cerf, French actor/producer (Nana), dies at age 93.
30 killed at religious rebellion in Algeria.
Storm hits West Europe, 11 killed in England.
Carlotta Monti, lover of WC Fields, dies at age 86.
The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is signed into law by US President Bill Clinton.
Muhammad Reza Golpayegani, ayatollah of Iran, dies.
Danny Blanchflower, North Ireland soccer/union coach, dies at age 67 (born 1926).
Pitcher Randy Johnson re-signs with the Seattle Mariners for US$20.25 million over three years.
First release of Doom, one of the most popular shoot-em'up PC videogames
A block of the Highland Towers collapses near Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, killing 148.
59th Heisman Trophy Award: Charlie Ward, Florida State (quarterback).
Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle wins the election for President of Chile with 58 percent of the vote.
Ales Gartner, Slavic ski trainer of Norway, dies at age 45.
Forty-eight people are killed when a block of the Highland Towers collapses near Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
Jozsef Antall, historian/premier of Hungary (1990-93), dies at age 61.
Ultra-Nationalists make strong gains in Russian elections.
Gerard "GT" Nabrink, Dutch anarchist/NVSH-founder, dies at age 90.
Fire in textile factory in Fuzjou China, 60 killed.
A U-2 spyplane crashes on a local training flight at Beale Air Force Base in California; US Air Force pilot Captain Richard Schneider is killed.
Kazakhstan parliament approves nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and agrees to dismantle more than 100 missiles.
Canadian Prime Minister Kim Campbell resigns as head of the Conservative Party to be succeeded by Jean Charest.
Muslim fundamentalists murder 12 Kroates/Bosnians in Algeria.
John Williams' final appearance as conductor of Boston Pops.
Y-12 crashes at Phonesavanh, Laos: 18 killed.
Lee Aspen resigns as Secretary of Defense.
Uruguay Round of GATT talks reach successful conclusion after seven years.
British premier major/Irish premier Reynolds signs Downing Street Declaration concerning Northern Ireland self-determination.
C-130 flies into a Philippines hill and explodes, 16 killed.
Ratu Penaia Ganilau, President of Fiji (1987-93), dies at age 75.
Brazil's Supreme Court rules that former President Fernando Collor de Mello may not hold elected office again until 2000 due to corruption.
Richard Auwerda, Dutch journalist/writer (Volkskrant), dies at age 68.
Kakuei Tanaka, premier of Japan (1972-74), dies at age 75.
Bentri Seddik, Algerian court judge, murdered at age 46.
Bangladesh Muslims call for murder of feminist Taslima Nasrin.
Frederik "Fried" L˜wensteyn, Dutch lawyer/writer, dies at age 71.
Omar Bongo is re-elected as President of Gabon in the country's first ever multiparty elections.
Kevin Scott skates world record 1000 metre (1:12.54).
Antoon Veerman, Dutch ARP Assistant Secretary of Education (1973-75), dies at age 77.
Michael Clarke, drummer (Byrds), dies of liver failure at age 49.
W Edwards Deming, US economist (helped Japan after WWII), dies at age 93.
United Nations General Assembly votes unanimously to appoint a United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
Philip Christison, British general (Rangoon), dies at age 100.
Interim South Africa constitution approved by parliament in a 237-45 vote.
Gertrude "Trudi" Duby Blom, actress, shot to death at about age 92.
Norman Vincent Peale, reverend (Power of Positive Thinking), dies at age 95.
Yen Chia-kan, Prime Minister/President of Taiwan (1963-72, 75-78), dies.
Floyd, Nicklaus and Rodriguez win Wendy's 3-Tour Challenge Golf Tournament.
Antonov-26 plane crashes at Gyumri, Armenia, 36 killed.
Youssef Sebti, Algerian scholar/poet, murdered at age 50.
Joop Vervoort, Dutch soccer referee, dies at age 61.
John Maclean passes Kirk Muller as all-time New Jersey Devils scorer (521 points).
Dutch Antilles government of Yandi Paula forms.

Argentina passes a measure allowing President Carlos Saul Menem and all future presidents to run for a second term. It also shortens presidential terms to four years and removes the requirement for the president to be Roman Catholic.
Construction of the Tian Tan Buddha, the world's tallest outdoor bronze statue of the seated Buddha, is completed.
Congress Party gains a parliamentary majority in India after the defection of ten Janata Dal party lawmakers.
[Irving Paul] "Swifty" Lazar, superagent, dies of kidney failure at age 86.
Mack David, US songwriter (Bachelor in Paradise), dies at age 81.
Israel and the Vatican establish diplomatic relations.
Israel and the Vatican establish diplomatic relations.
Zviad Gamsachurdia, first President of Georgia SSR (1991-1993), dies of suicide at age 54 (born 1939).
Lambert Fokkema, founder of Dutch Export Combination, dies at age 80.
Arthur Dreifuss, director/producer (Murder in Amsterdam), dies at age 85.
Thomas J Watson Jr, president of IBM (1956-71)/diplomat, dies at age 79.
The North American Free Trade Agreement comes into effect.
The Zapatista Army of National Liberation initiates twelve days of armed conflict in the Mexican State of Chiapas.
The European Economic Area comes into effect.
The Zapatista Army of National Liberation begins their war in Chiapas, Mexico.
Florida State University beats the University Of Nebraska in the Orange Bowl for the US national football championship.
The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) goes into effect in Canada, USA, and Mexico.
Carquest Bowl 4: Boston College beats Virginia, 32-13.
Aleksandr Popov swims world record 100m free style (47.83).
In Canada, a Celebration 1994 ticket on the Lotto 6/49 lottery gives CDN$1 million to a Toronto resident.
Sammy Taft, Canadian businessman (coined term "hat trick"), dies at age 81.
Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, French director of International Monetary Fund (1963-73), dies at age 81.
Battles between army and rebellious Indians in South Mexico; 57 dead.
Dixy Lee Ray, chairwoman (US Atomic Energy Commission), dies at age 79.
An Aeroflot Tupolev TU-154 crashes and explodes after takeoff from Irkhutsk, Russia killing 125 including 1 on the ground.
35-foot-tall Chief Wahoo, trademark of Cleveland Indians on top of Stadium since 1962, is taken down, to be moved to Jacob's Field.
Roel Bazen, Dutch sound technician (Van Kooten and The Bie), dies at age 48.
Tupolev-154M crashes at Irkutsk, Siberia; 122 killed.
Hundreds killed in Venezuela in prison revolt.
Michiel P "Michael" Gorsira, Governor of Cura?ao (1951-67), dies at age 80.
Louis R J Ridder van Rappard, Dutch mayor of Zoelen, dies at age 87.

Dow Jones Industrial Average hits record 3803.88.
Nancy Kerrigan is clubbed on the right leg by an assailant under orders from figure skating rival Tonya Harding.

Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov on Soyuz TM-18 leaves for Mir. He will stay on the space station till March 22, 1995, for a record 437 days in space.

The Superhighway Summit is held in Los Angeles, California. It is the first conference to discuss the growing information superhighway and is presided over by U.S. Vice President Al Gore.

Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies is elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Malcolm X's daughter arrested for plotting Louis Farrakhan's murder.

Erich Honecker leaves Germany for Chile. Honecker had been the leader of East Germany. After the reunification there was the possibility of trying him for crimes against humanity, but due to his cancer he was allowed to leave Germany.
Tonya Harding's bodyguard, Shawn Eric Eckardt and Derrick Brian Smith arrested and charged with conspiracy in attack of skater Nancy Kerrigan.
Johan J Holst, Norwegian minister of defense/foreign affairs, dies at age 56.

U.S. President Bill Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Kremlin Accords, which stop the preprogrammed aiming of nuclear missiles toward each country's targets, and also provide for the dismantling of the nuclear arsenal in Ukraine.
Russian manned space craft TM-17 lands.
Federica Montseny, anarchist/Spanish minister of Health (1936), dies at age 80.
Inna Lassovskaya triple-jumps ladies world record (14.61 metres).

In Pennsylvania, a magnitude 4.6 earthquake occurs. Felt throughout southeastern Pennsylvania and as far as Baltimore, Maryland and New York City. Also felt at Toronto, Canada.

In Northridge, California, a magnitude 6.7 earthquake occurs. Sixty people were killed, more than 7,000 injured, 20,000 homeless and more than 40,000 buildings damaged in Los Angeles, Ventura, Orange and San Bernardino Counties. Severe damage occurred in the San Fernando Valley. Collapsed overpasses closed sections of the Santa Monica Freeway, the Antelope Valley Freeway, the Simi Valley Freeway and the Golden State Freeway. Total damage: US$30 billion.
A magnitude 6.7 earthquake hits Northridge, California; see 1994 Northridge Earthquake.
In Cando, Spain, a minute-long fireball and explosion over a hillside gouges out 200 cubic metres of terrain.

Record cold temperatures hit the eastern United States. The coldest temperature ever measured in Indiana state history, -36 degrees F (-38 degrees C), is recorded in New Whiteland. The coldest temperature ever measured in Ohio state history, -20 degrees F (-29 degrees C), is recorded in Cleveland.
Record cold temperatures across the eastern half of the United States brings temperatures below -20¶F in many locations, such as Ohio and Kentucky.
Jaramogi Oginga Odinga, Kenyan Vice-President (1963-66), dies at about age 81.

Chris Boyd of England makes a single bet of 147,000 pounds on one spin of the roulette wheel on red at Binions Horseshoe Casino. He wins, and returns home.

The first trial of accused murderer Lyle Menendez ends in a mistrial. He and his brother Erik are later found guilty and sentenced to life in prison without parole.

In American football's Super Bowl XXVIII, the Dallas Cowboys hand the Buffalo Bills their fourth consecutive Super Bowl loss, 30-13. Most Valuable Player: Emmitt Smith, Running Back for the Dallas Cowboys.

In Portland, Oregon, Tonya Harding's ex-husband Jeff Gillooly pleads guilty to his role in attacking figure skater Nancy Kerrigan. He accepts a plea bargain, admitting to racketeering charges in exchange for testimony against Harding.

In Southern Sumatera, Indonesia, a magnitude 6.9 earthquake occurs. At least 207 people killed, more than 2,000 injured, 75,000 homeless and extensive damage from landslides, mudslides and fires in Lampung Province. Damage estimated to be about US$169 million.
US asks Aristide to adopt a peace plan from Haiti.

Aldrich Ames and his wife are charged with spying for the Soviet Union by the United States Department of Justice. Ames will later be convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment and his wife will receive five years in prison.
Papa John Creach, American jazz musician (Papa Blues), dies at age 76 (born 1917).
Aldrich Ames and his wife are charged by the United States Department of Justice with spying for the Soviet Union.
Cleveland Indians owner Richard Jacobs announces he will pay US$10 million to name baseball field (Jacobs Field) at Gateway (becomes official March 23).

Israeli Kahanist Baruch Goldstein opens fire inside the Cave of the Patriarchs in the West Bank. He kills 29 Muslims before worshippers beat him to death.

Yann Piat, French Member of Parliament (FN/PR), murdered at age 44.

Mosque of Abraham massacre: In the Cave of the Patriarchs in the West Bank city of Hebron, Dr. Baruch Kappel Goldstein opens fire with an assault rifle, killing 29 Palestinian worshippers and injuring 125 more before being subdued and beaten to death by survivors. Subsequent rioting kills 26 more Palestinians and 9 Israelis.

NHL's Saint Louis Blues beat Ottawa Senators 11-1.

XVII Olympic Winter Games close in Lillehammer, Norway.

Brady Law, imposing a wait-period to buy a hand-gun, goes into effect.

36th Grammy Awards: "I Will Always Love You", Toni Braxton win.
Mary Ellen Withrow begins her term of office as Treasurer of the United States, serving under President Bill Clinton.

The grunge rock band Nirvana plays its final show in Munich, Germany.
A lone terrorist kills Ari Halberstam during an attack on 14 Jewish students on the Brooklyn Bridge in New York City.
Former banker Leonard Coleman is elected National League president replacing Bill White.
Jacob "Jimmy" Herman Huizinga, journalist/writer, dies at age 75.
Seattle grunge band Nirvana play their last show in Munich, Germany.
Branch Davidian cult leader David Koresh promises to surrender if taped statement is broadcast; it is, but he doesn't.

Four Arab terrorists are convicted for their roles in the World Trade Center bombing, which killed six and injured more than 1,000.
Four terrorists are convicted for their roles in the World Trade Center bombing which killed six and injured more than a thousand.
